description:
Party was running late, great service by the hostess and the waiters... let us stay late and drink wine and eat food.  Thanks for the hospitality tonight.  

The only minus is the parking and walking around this area... area is bad.  Just take a car to the front door, otherwise you'll get people yelling "F@CK YOU IN THE F@CKING @SSHOLE" .  Yeah.
author: J S.

description:
A great find 2 blocks from the Golden Gate Theater. We were walk ins and got to see in the back at the bar area. 

The menu was full of tasty items but we got great help from our waiter on what to order. 

The salads were on the small side but very tasty. The arance betole (beet salad) had hearty pieces of beets and blood orange with a nice crisp flavor.  We also had Rucalo E Parmigiano which was like a Caesar salad. Tasty but small as well. 

The Burata Acciughe was burata topped with an anchovy and a side of pesto. Magnificent. Omg. I could've eaten this myself and ordered more. Had it with the bread we asked for. 

We ordered 3 pinsas for 4 of us and it was plenty.  The crust was thin. The flavors in each pinsa were heavenly. 
Casal Bertone. Mozzarella. Pecorino and honey. 
Quadraro. Tomato. Pecorino. Red onion. Hot chili pepper.  Not spicy. More sweet 
Pinsa pesto/prosciutto. The pinsa special.  Yummmmm

We ordered a Tagliere Misto which was a board of three cheeses and meats since we saw it being served to someone else. Really didn't need it. It was a small portion. 

The pinsa pistachio for dessert was interesting. I liked the piatachio filling but would've preferred a sweeter crust. 

This place was packed and a diamond in the rough of a neighborhood. Loved the pinsas. Price point a bit on the high side. But it will be my regular foodie place when i see shows at the Golden Gate Theater.
author: Mitzi W.

description:
Nina Y. and I met for another pre-musical dinner... and ordered too much food as usual. She got there a little before me and found seats at the bar. We had a pillar right in our faces which wasn't ideal, but the rest of the restaurant was packed.

It's a cute little spot that feels authentically Italian. Our waitress was super sweet and helpful to suggest wines. We paired this with a charcuterie platter, which was a terrible idea in hindsight. SO. MUCH. FOOD!! It was tasty though. I'd come here again for that. 

We also ordered the Maranella pizza, which had mozzarella, broccolini, spicy pork sausage, and and burrata. This sounded irresistable, but so did everything else on the menu. The cheese melted in our mouths, and the flavors and textures were perfect.

The only downside is the service. Several times we had to scan the restaurant for our waitress. She was multitasking while other staff members seemed to be hanging around in the back. Conversations with customers took forever, and maybe it's because we were in a hurry to get to a musical.

At any rate, this was a delicious new place to get pizza. I'd love to take my Italian fiancé here. I read in someone else's review that they're technically "pinsas" which have fluffier crust, less cheese, and more concentration on the toppings. Interesting. I love it!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Super cute spot. Super sketch street. We came here for happy hour/early dinner before a volunteer gig. The place was really empty the entire time between 4-5 and we were the only customers which kinda diminished the atmosphere but assume it fills up later in the evening.

We ordered the Quadraro pinsa ($19) and it was bomb. Would definitely order again. It was pretty light though because the dough as they said it mostly water so that plus an app of porchetta ($16) -- thin slices, served cold, delicious but with tougher skin and more fat than I'm used to -- was more of a solid snack than a meal for 2.

The happy hour was $1 off certain beers and wines I think, and I didn't see any complimentary bar snacks, nor were we offered any.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Hidden in a scary back alley way, my heart fell in love with brocollini, sausage with ricotta cheese pizza.  I couldn't stop eating this one.  And when asked if I wanted to take the leftovers home?  Hells-to-the-yea-I-did!  And I did.  So, my love affair moved from the back alley and continued at home.

So grateful to have co-workers who know foodies way better than I do.  That way, my taste buds get to experiment in ways it's never experimented before.

Horray for food!  I MUST COME BACK with the fambam and friends someday!
author: Jenny T.

description:
Montesacro Pinseria-Enoteca is a moderately priced Italian/Sicilian/Sardinian restaurant that serves a wide variety of dishes but focuses particularly on its "pinsas" which are pizza-like dishes that have fluffier crust, less cheese, and more focus on unique flavors such as fish roe, honey, sausages, and arugula.

The pricing on their pinsas (~$16-22 as of July 2018) is a bit pricier than say California Pizza Kitchen but the volume of bread makes up for the price differential. We ordered 3 pinserias for 3 people and were nicely full afterwards.

The menu is a bit difficult to read as most of the cheeses and cured meat/sausages are named very specifically (examples of cheeses = straciatella, pecorino, burrata, crescenza; examples of cured meat/sausages = 'nduja, guanciale, bresaola) though the servers are very patient and will answer all question you have regarding the menu with a smile. 

The pinsas themselves are very unique, with an emphasis on the bread rather than the toppings. The bread is fluffy with a bit of crunch and is a simple rectangular blob rather than the traditional circular pizza. We had the Casal Bertone (mozzarella + sausage), the Ostia (burrata + fish roe + sunflower sprouts), and another sausage based pizza and the Casal Bertone was hands down the tastiest and most similar to a pizza. We also enjoyed both of the other pizzas and notably the Ostia's purposely tepid temperature combined with the texture of the roe was a very fun and unique food experience. 

The establishment oozes style and while 6th street is awful, this place is a little beacon of hope. It's tucked in an alleyway close to Mission Street with lights strung between the buildings and the restaurant itself is decorated with lots of traditional items that you might find in Italy. In the back is a small deli selling cheeses and cured meats.

Service was initially slow and we spent maybe 20+ minutes waiting at our table without anyone bringing drinks, taking our orders or answering questions but when we finally got served, all of the wait staff were patient, helpful, and fun to talk to.

Overall this is a wonderful restaurant that deserves to be frequented often. Its food and flavor profiles are unique and the ingredients are authentic, its pricing is decent for San Francisco, the service is upbeat and fun, and the ambiance is perfect for dates or friends visiting from out of town. While the neighborhood it's located in is terrible, I wouldn't let it stop you from coming over to a wonderful experience. I teetered between a 4 and 5 star review and if the pinsas had been more cheese/sausage and less bread, I would have easily given this place 5-stars.
author: Andrew H.

description:
One of the best pizza I've ever had. Yes it's a bit pricier but not by that much. Their dough is very unique, and had the perfect amount of crunch vs softness. The maranella (?) had a slightly viscous cheese that was very different from any cheese I've had before, but was wonderful. The Margherita pizza with sausage was also very delicious. I think the dough they use makes almost any pizza better than the usual, greasy and fatty pizza you find elsewhere.

The location is indeed bad - homeless people literally 10-20 feet from the door in an empty alley, so exercise caution when getting there.

We went on a Sunday evening around 8 and didn't wait at all.
author: John L.

description: Great for a large party of 10, but the only table available for our large party was a table with backless stools. Food was delicious, but could only really focus on the fact that my back was killing me by the second hour. Also, there wasn't really a place to put our purses, so I had it over my shoulder the whole meal.
author: Samantha E.

description:
This pinsa was so disappointing, I cannot believe the high reviews of this restaurant. The pinsa had a tiny bit of cheese bowled up in the middle of the breaded crust...

The pinsa we got with kale literally had a bunch of barely cooked kale piled hardly cooked PILED on top of:

This is the approximate recipe:

1 pound of barely cooked kale 
2 tablespoons of cheese 
1 gram of peppers disguised as pepperoni 

This pinsa was so lame. Pathetic even. The worst. 

What a waste in time ordering, no help with the phone person, and a waste of calories.
author: Elle C.

description:
I died and went to heaven... located in such an unassuming side alley- such so that if I squint really hard and look, it almost feels like Rome. Then once you enter the restaurant, you don't have to squint so hard - it does feel like a regular restaurant in Rome! And then if one would start looking around - they have eclectic things all around the restaurant. Boxing gloves hanging on a door. Crib on the top of the oven... The bar area is extremely cute. It's so visually gratifying. And then we get to the food. We ordered the arugula salad and margherita pinsa. Friends got the charcuterie platter and another pinsa. It was really so good. So fresh. The parmigiano was just incredible. I don't know what I've been eating so far that was also called parmesan. 

The pizza (pinsa) was truly amazing. So light, so well done and so delicious. Definitely one of the best pizza to date.

But what truly stole the show and just blew my mind was the pistachio pinsa dessert. If I'd known about that before we ordered the pizza, I would've only eaten that for dinner is how good it was. Truly exceptional.

You've won a lifetime customer. Please, never change!
author: Namrata J.

description:
I am so happy I finally came to this place! I haven't ever really love pizza in this city until I came here! We got some goat cheese to start and then split the Margherita and the Ostia between two people. 

I would say that is filling enough, but I probably could have eaten more had I wanted to be in food coma. I forget the name of the goat cheese we got, but I don't think you can go wrong with any cheese you choose. The Margherita pizza was incredible, the tomato sauce they use is to die for, so flavorful! The Ostia was also super yummy. The Burrata was served cold, and was soooo good. 

Hands down the best pizza spot in the city, and prices are reasonable for SF standards. Can't wait to come back!
author: Morgyn T.

description:
The place is a bit small, but even so we were seated quickly as a party of 6 without a reservation. That being said we did have to sit at the bar, but the overall experience was still pretty enjoyable.

The pizza was actually pretty good, it's not your typical pizza you get, it taste more like a flatbread with light toppings on top. The toppings were all very high quality, I was particularly impressed with the taste of the cheeses.

Of the three pizzas, we had the Garbatella, Maranella, and one of the vegetarian ones, but the name escapes me right now. The garbatella tasted like tuna with mayo, which while it doesn't sound that great, actually ended up tasting really good on the flatbread.

The maranella I though was only okay, even though its one of the more popular dishes. I thought the spicy pork sausage wasn't as good or amazing as I would have expected, but the cheese was quite good.

The focaccia der muratore was terrible, do not get that. It was literally a piece of flat bread, cut in the middle, with a slice of mortadella (it might as well have been supermarket bologna, it tasted like that) in the middle.

Overall an enjoyable meal, just be aware of some dishes.
author: Tyler T.

description:
A friend had recommended this place, but when I got here, I thought I was on the wrong block at first! This is an alleyway in SOMA with not much going on besides residential entrances and warehouses. However, you'll find an understated doorway, behind which is a loud and clearly popular spot. 

THE WAIT: About 30 minutes for three on a Wednesday at 7:30pm. 

THE COST: More than I was expecting, about $50 each for 2 glasses of wine, 2 starters, 3 entrees, and 1 dessert. However, the dinner was good and I was pretty stuffed at the end!

THE SERVICE: Friendly, but quite slow at times. 

THE FOOD:

INSALATE E PIATTI FREDDI
* Rapette (beets, sprouts, ricotta, pistachio. $14) - 3.5 stars
Simple, good fresh ingredients. Could use a bit more dressing/flavor.

* Sardella e Pane Tostato (sardine spread, toasted bread. $13) - 2 stars
This was way, way, way too salty! Really hard to enjoy this.

PINSA - overall their pinsas were great, almost like a thin-crust pizza, but a little more toasted. 
* Maranella (mozzarella, broccolini, spicy pork sausage, burrata. $22) - 3.5 stars
This was my friend's favorite because of the broccolini, but I found the overall flavor to be dull (but I generally don't like white pizzas/pastas and need that tomato sauce, but I thought I'd give this a try). 

* Quadraro (tomato, guanciale, red onion, pecorino, hot chili pepper. $19) - 4.5 stars
I didn't order this but this was my favorite of our three pinsas. The tomato and red onion give it a nice, sharp flavor.

* Trullo (tomato, lamb sausage, oyster sausage. $21) - 4 stars
This was good! 

DOLCI
* Pinsa con Crema Ai Pistacchi di Bronte ($12) - 4 stars
A great continuation of pinsas for the night - super tasty with pistachio crema and powdered sugar!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Delicious! 

I've had a variety of pizzettas from the kids, and every time I'm super apprehensive of them maybe this time letting me down and being the annoyingly negative yelp reviewer that I am, I'm consistently recommending people try them. 

EAT. FKING. EVERYTHING.
author: Anthony B.

description: This place was super overpriced?? But I guess that's just how it is in SF. The food was fine, but I essentially paid $32 (after tax and gratuity for a 7 person group) for a personal sized pizza, and I shared this pizza which means I got half of the personal for $16. I got the maranella pinsa and the cheese was good (almost like cream). I felt like I ate more of the crust than the actual toppings which is normally fine for Italian pizza, but after a while I just felt like I was eating bread with piece of sausage and some cheese (sometimes a stick of broccolini). Not worth it in my opinion.
author: Danielle W.

description:
The GPS on our group's phones had us traveling in circles and was seemingly trying to thwart our attempts to visit MPE, but with some tenacious trekking we finally made our way to where we needed to be. 

The inside is both elegant and rustic, a perfect foil for the more upscale take on a classic peasant dish. Since we spent a good deal of our lunch hour trying to find the restaurant, most of us opted for their prix-fixe lunch special: green salad, margherita pinsa, and an espresso. 

The salad was simple but perfectly dressed, fresh, and flavorful. The pinsa was really where it was at though. The crust was light, chewy, and bubbly. The menu states its made from a mix of rice, wheat, and soy flours and that it is low-fat and low-cal. I am ready to accept this at face value so I don't feel guilty about downing nearly the entire pinsa in one sitting. I didn't feel gross in the way I would expect to after eating was essentially a large personal pizza halfway through the day. Each pie is served with its own pizza cutter, which was great for letting each of us decide how we preferred to attack our flatbreads. 

I can't comment on the espresso - I lead a caffeine-free existence (ugh) so I would have had to decline mine either way, but in the relaxed fashion of the restaurant it wasn't offered until we were finished with our meals and ready to head out. The rest of the group declined their espressos as well since we had to hightail it back to the office. If you can't take a leisurely lunch, you may want to inquire about getting your espresso a bit earlier. 

I did crave pinsa pretty solidly for a couple months after my visit, and looking at the photos on my phone make me crave it again. Enjoy!
author: Stacey L.

description:
3.5 STARS

It was Pi Day, so my office had to celebrate! We ordered a few pizzas for lunch delivery via Caviar. They arrived on Wednesday, March 14th around 12:15pm.

*Margherita Pinsa: mozzarella, tomato, basil ($16.80) ×2
*Quadroro Pinsa: san marzano tomato, guanciale, red onion, pecorino, and hot chili pepper, amatriciana ($19.95) ×2
*Trullo Pinsa: tomato, lamb sausage, mushroom, yogurt, and mint ($22.05) x2

The pizzas were shared by about a dozen plus people, so we cut each into sixths. The pizzas are about the size of a personal pizza, so for a meal, I'd say you should get one each. For me, this was more of a snack. I tried one slice of each. I like my pizza with a lot of toppings and a thin crust, so these weren't really up my alley. The crust was slightly crispy and soft with a nice chew. My favorite was the lamb pizza. Only cuz it had the most toppings. And there was meat! Overall, I found the tomato sauce a little too acidic. Especially in the margherita.

More like a flatbread with toppings instead of a pizza. Not really my style, but quality ingredients and great crusty bread.
author: Elena N.

description:
We rolled out of here last night with overstuffed bellies and promised to be back. Made a reservation for 8:45pm on a Saturday night and had to wait about 15minutes for our table to be ready. Guess everyone was having a good time and weren't ready to leave yet. 

For two people, we ordered the cold zucchini, the casal bertone, and the garbatella. We shouldn't have finished everything, but we did and regretted it later. The zucchini was a cold dish that was simply flavored with olive oil, parsley, and chili. It was a refreshing dish but nothing to rave about. I personally like my zucchini a little more caramelized to bring out the sweetness. Of the two pinsas we got, I prefer the garbatella (tuna, mozzarella, red onion, fresh calabrian chilis) to the casal bertone (guanciale, mozzarella, pecorino, honey). The crust on the pinsas was amazingly flavorful. I'd get the garbatella again but would skip the bertone and try a different pinsa next time. 

The wine selection had a variety of wines from California and all over Europe. There's also a good selection of beer and Italian non-alcoholic drinks. I wanted to try the spuma nera but sadly, they were out that night. Service was friendly, and despite being busy, we never felt neglected.
author: Judy C.

description:
Where has this place been all my life?! Seriously gold. Service was great and the place itself was quaint and charming. I gobbled down the San Lorenzo Pinsa which, for being a vegan dish, wow. They are absolutely correct in that the bread is easily digestible and leaves you feeling normal vs traditional pizza dough where you leave feeling full, nasty and ready for a nap. Also tried the cauliflower salad appetizer which was delicious (the cold cauliflower threw me off a little but I overcame that within seconds!). 
The location is in a pretty seedy area of the loin- so don't let that pull you away from the incredible food and experience you'll receive inside. 
Grazie!!
author: Rob M.

description:
After a busy Pride weekend, all we wanted was some food. Pizza to be exact. Up popped this joint on Yelp and I am so glad this came up under pizza or I never would have found this Roman nirvana. It's a really cool looking joint and for being a small place, the seating with the bars and long tables is conducive to getting a lot of people in at once which was a huge plus. We were seated at the bar and I had a lot of time to observe the decor. Everything is curated very tastefully and it's really fun to look around the room. 

I've never had a pinsa before this experience and I would say I would never go back to pizza but alas, there aren't any pinserias near me in South Bay. I shared a Casal Bertone, the stars being guanciale and honey, as well as a Trullo that featured a lamb sausage. I heard that the Trullo was one of the favorites on the menu and it was very tasty. For me, the Casal Bertone way overshadowed it because it was so incredible. I've always been a sucker for honey on white pizzas but this took it to the next level. The combo with the salty and crispy guanciale was a dream. Also the big difference between a pinsa and a pizza is the way the crust is made. I don't not like crust but I will tend to leave it if there's more "main" to finish. I did not leave any of the crust this time. It was that good. 

With the incredible entree pinsa experience, I jumped at the chance to get a dessert pinsa. The pinsa was filled with a smooth, creamy *pistachio nutella* and dusted with sugar. The filling was absolutely divine. The whole thing is served warm and I can't get it out of my head 2 days later.
author: Emily L.

description:
The place is a literal hole in the wall transporting you to a little spot in Rome. 


Amazing ambiance. I came for date night here. They were quick to make reservations a priority. The host was a slender man who found us a cute spot by the window, very helpful and friendly. Our waiter was an Italian gentleman who really understood what it meant to provide great service. He made us feel as if we were apart of the restaurant's family. 

The food was incredible and PACKED WITH FLAVOR.

Hands down, a gem.
author: sufi s.

description:
I love Montesacro! I've been here maybe over 10 times and each time has been fantastic. Both the food and service are nothing short of excellent. The only thing that I might complain about if I were being picky is that it can get quite loud sometimes when there's a big group at the restaurant. 

Regardless of what pizza you order here, it's going to come on this delicious crust. The crust is thin, crispy, and has an al dente bite to it, kind of like what you might expect from naan. My personal favorite pizza to order is the maranella (according to Yelp's keyword aggregation, it looks like it's Yelper's favorite pizza as well). When it comes to appetizers, you're going to be satisfied no matter what you order. I'm usually not one to order salads but the salads here are great. Definitely order one if you're here as a group to share. I'd say for a single salad, that will be enough for about 3 people. YMMV though depending on how hungry your party is. My favorite appetizer to get here is the burrata with anchovies. 

If you're in the area and looking for good food, I highly recommend Montesacro. If you're a tourist, you should come here instead of waiting in line for Dottie's True Blue Cafe which is grossly overrated.
author: Austin W.

description:
In an assuming alley, seats about 50. Each pinsa is "individual" and you cut it yourself, about 10 inches long. The chili oil is fantastic but don't douse your pizza or you'll fantasticly regret it. #burns

We ordered 1 appetizer and four pizzas to share among 6.

Carpaccio app - cured meat with argula and lemony sauce. Delicious!!

Quadraro Pinsa - the best pizza we had all night. Spicy with cured meat prepared from pork jowl or cheeks
Maranella Pinsa - came with 7 spicy pork sausage meatballs, and while burrata on a pizza sounds fantastic, it was really soupy because of the oven. Felt like creamy soup on a flatbread
Tor Di Quinto Pinsa - great combination of salmon and grilled zucchini
Corviale Pinsa - mushroom and cured pork fat back, not as memorable because I can't remember what this pizza was like!

If I could offer one suggestion, I'd say to put enough toppings on the dough that the toppings cover to the ends of the pizza. The ends were VERY doughy/fat crust, while their dough is delicious, from Rome, and leavened for 72-hours, most people don't eat that much crust and the people who got the middle slices got lucky because of all the good-goods.

Really special (weird) bathrooms as well, and kind servers. I'd come again!
author: Debbie L.

description:
The pinsa here is excellent -- my wife and I shared the Casel Bertone (Mozzarella, Crispy Guanciale, Pecorino, Sardinian Corbezzolo Honey) and the Garbatella (Caper Mayonnaise, Cured Line-Caught Tuna, Buffalo Mozzarella, Calabrese Hot Chili, Pickled Red Onion, Parsley), and they were both delicious.  Likewise, the Burratta e Acciughe appetizer (imported Burrata di Corato, Cetara Anchovy Fillet, House Pesto, & Extra Virgin Olive Oil) was top notch.

The service is friendly and efficient, and the wine and beer options are solid.  Nice rustic-ambiance too.  The only disappointment was the fennel panacotta, which was very bland.  Try one of the other deserts instead.
author: Andy S.

description:
The word "pizza" in America conjures up images of a greasy pie with tons of cheese and toppings over a mediocre cardboard crust. But pinsas, a flatbread dating back to the days of the Roman empire, are a world away, and Montesacro Pinseria recreates them in a lovely setting. The definite standout of every pinsa that this place turns out is the chewy yet airy crust, which is much lighter than a typical American pizza crust, as it's made of a blend of rice, soy, and wheat flours and is therefore much easier to digest. 

Coming in for lunch, we started with a few small plates--the rapette, or roasted baby beet salad with ricotta and sunflower sprouts, contained some of the sweetest, most tender beets I've had. The cavolfiori, or roasted cauliflower dressed with black olives, capers, and tomato was nice as well (though I wonder if it would have been better served warm). But of course the standout was the pinsa flatbreads--the Quadraro pinsa contained slices of guanciale (cured pork cheek) and a light tomato sauce, while the Montesacro came with some of the creamiest stracciatella buffalo cheese, along with lacinato kale, chilies, and even garum (an ancient fermented fish sauce)! Both of these were amazing, and definitely made the visit to this restaurant worth the trip!
author: David K.

description:
Montesacro is offering up something unique and special for a great experience.  This place produces a Roman version of the pizza called PINSA.  The shape is oblong, 10" x 7".  A little pricy, $18-21 for what it is.  But, what it is, is good!  The dough is light, crisp, salty, crisp, and airy -- very flavorful with a great texture.  It's located in an alley-like street, 4 doors down from the corner, in the Tenderloin -- run inside if your able.

Decorated rustic, charming, and open.  Distressed paint, mismatched metal chairs, a few church pews (thank god, they have a seat cover vs that hard wood), playful, with cute artifacts.  The servers are casually dressed in jeans and sweatshirts or flannels, friendly, and all with personality (led by my server Nic, the floor manager, and the hostess).  All of this makes this pizza place unique with a wonderful vibe.

The menu is small, 12 apps and salads, 4 paninis, 12 pinsas.  The toppings are not Americana -- you won't find meatballs and/or pepperoni, but you will find beets, prosciutto, tuna belly, capers, smoked mozzarella, spicy pork sausage, anchovy, so be prepared for that.

I started off the evening with Tempranillo (from Spain) -- $12.  I've had that before, and it was a safe choice.  I didn't recognize any other wines off their list. [4.0 stars]

For my PINSA, I got an Maranella -- $21 + $3 for ricotta.  Mozzarella, broccolini, spicy pork sausage, burrata.  I'm so glad I added the ricotta, I don't know if I would have been satisfied with the amount of toppings it normally had. [4.5 stars]

For dessert, Torta Ghetto -- $7.  A ricotta based, dark cherry, and chocolate.  Nice taste, but very dry.  Wouldn't order this again. [3.5 stars]

In LA, I recently ate Roman-style PINSA crust and it blew my mind, and honestly, it was better than Montesacro.  But all in all, this is a great place worthy visiting (again, and again).
author: Randy B.

description:
Don't overthink it. Just dive in with a drop the needle approach to the menu. Flatbread topped tuna -- order it. Flatbread stuffed with mortadella -- order it. Random pecorino choices -- ask the waitress for her preference and go with it. 

Four of us came for a birthday. We each ordered two things. I ordered the special "flauto" which was rolled flatbread with artichokes, peppers and ham. So good! I also chose a pecorino -- they have two -- and went with the waitress's pick. Why argue. 

We ended with a mix of marinated veggies, a tuna flatbread (I wouldn't have ordered it but it was my favorite dish), beet salad, pork roast and something I can't remember.  Plus a forgettable Portuguese wine and a fantastic Spanish wine. 

The "ghetto cake" was a desert hit as was the fennel pannacotta. 

The dessert wine list included "chinoti" which are wines enhanced with herbs. Not unlike an Italian vermouth but more complex. The Barolo chinoto is excellent. 

We brought in a bottle of champagne and the corkage fee was waived coz we ordered their wine as well. No champagne flutes, alas. 

They have an extensive wine list, which is no surprise. 


It's a delightful surprise on an unprepossessing alley. I've been getting services at an agency in the area for years. Montesacro was a brave pioneer in a very rough area just off Market Street. Don't be put off by the street people. Montesavro is worth a trip into an alley.
author: Tim P.

description:
It's been 6 months since I've visited Montesacro, and let's just say there isn't a day that goes by where I don't think about their delicious pinsa, a highly weighted sentence coming from a New Yorker.

Montesacro's pinsa/pizzas are easily in my top 3 list of all time favorites. The style is different, a more flatbread approach, but truly remarkable in its delivery.

It's rustic, it's pricey (but worth every penny), with an attentive and caring staff to complement the experience.

If life ever carries me back to San Fran, I know where I'm going first.
author: Leena T.

description: We had pizza, salad, and wine by the glass. I was tempted to order the prosciutto and cheese plate, it looked amazing! If you like pizza this would be a good stop before or after a show at a nearby theater. The staff was nice and attentive.  The location is down an alley off 6th street, the sidewalk was crowded with homeless folks selling items. (heartbreaking) I'm a tall man and somewhat adventurous, but i was initially hesitant to walk down the alley until I saw the Montesacro sign. (Totally worth walking down the alley) I'd recommend Uber/Lyft right to the front door.
author: Geoff O.

description:
We went to Montesacro Pinseria yesterday for the first time before visiting the MOMA. While not inexpensive it was outstanding and had a very authentic feel. Here is what we ate:

Sardella e pan tostado- a dip made with Calabrian chilies and sardines. Briny, spicy and umami rich dip served with toast. Excellent.

Ostia pinsa- Pinsas are Roman style pizza. This one was was topped with Burrata, shaved botarga and sunflower sprouts. The crust was outstanding- perfectly crispy, charred light and fluffy. Paired perfectly with the creamy cheese and salty botarga. Excellent. 

Very interesting wine list.

According to the owner this place has been open about three years. This was our first visit and we were blown away. We will definitely be back.

Located in SOMA in a somewhat sketchy neighborhood 

http://www.montesacrosf.com/
author: George T.

description: One of the best meals that I have enjoyed ever period. I went here a few months ago and had the Pinsa ( I don't think that's how it's spelled, oops) which was so bubbly and crunchy at the same time. The staff are so nice and were able to sit me and my friend right away at the bar. I think this is because we went on a weekday. But, I would definitely recommend making reservations if you want to get in. I tried going again recently but forgot to make them and the line was out the door. Just make reservations and be ready for an awesome meal.
author: Megan G.

description:
This is a cute place and it is kinda hidden in the ally. I would say only people who works & live around here knows this place. It's very rustic, with lots of nick-knack all over even in the bathroom. If you miss Italy you would love the food, I don't really enjoy cheese or anchovy so I though it was okay. There's only selected food i would eat/try. BUT do not get me wrong, the food is good nonetheless.

I forgot what my flat bread was called but it was good. Cute place for hanging out, dates, and work event if it is a small group.
author: Christina H.

description:
Awesome! Tucked in a small alleyway that I would not walk by myself at night. When you walk in you are transformed to another world. 

Came here for a work party which means ordered virtually everything on the menu.

Highlights for me:
- Cavolfioro: roasted cauliflower 
- Burrata (always amazing)
- Villa Gordiani pizza : mushroom and garlic goodness
- Infernetto: I surprisingly liked the smoked buffalo pork pizza

Pizzas are not big we had almost 1 per person (oops). 

Had amazing Italian wine ( in pictures).
author: Kevin Y.

description:
Awesome pizza ...I mean amazing . Get the maranella and the margarita with sausage 
Place is on away from the main union square
Only a 15 min walk. Totally worth the walk 
If u want pizza in SF this is your place
author: Vince K.

description:
This was a complete surprise y'all. When my co-worker and I walked in I was thinking it would be some beat up little pizza shop trying to be upscale but how wrong I was. 

First off I want to shout out the staff who was extremely kind and catering as we had a baby with us and they were holding him and playing with him while serving us (which the service was quick). The owner was there and he offered us free wine on the house but since it was a work day we couldn't but it goes to show that they care about their neighbors and customers. The pizza was small for the prize but the taste was 5/5 and I was in love with their appetizer selection. the cauliflower was on point and I've gone back since to order just that a few times. 

For two people (2 appetizers and 1 pizza) was about $45 which was a fair price and the inside is so cute! Old school NYC vibe with a sandwich shop as well so I need to go back to try some of the fresh meat cut sandwiches. 

Don't let the outside shy you away from going on and if you need a nice pizza night before going to a show at the Warfield or Civic Center I would recommend this place.
author: Ankita C.

description:
Good pizza (pinsa, the Roman oval version), one of the best in SF.
Tasty samplers of Italian cured meats (salami) and cheese.
Service is friendly but a bit inaccurate while managing orders.
However too overpriced, especially wine (pretty back quality) and even considering hugly places all around.
Overall: just once (or twice if you forget the first time...)
author: Marco S.

description:
My new favorite pizza place in San Francisco, nay the world!

It doesn't matter which pizza you order because they will all be delicious because they all share the same amazing dough. Wow. The pizza dough is phenomenal. Crisp and crunchy on the outside and practically gooey on the inside. If this pizza place weren't basically in the Tenderloin, I would eat here all the time. It makes me a little sad I have to pay for an Uber Pool since the risk of Express Pool making me walk around the Tenderloin is too high.
author: Charles L.

description:
There are a lot of good food places in SF. Like really, really good places. So many that it's really hard for anything truly, truly exceptional to really get the time of day. We don't have words for it. There's no way to tell if a line means it's truly exceptional or if it's Mama's (which in my opinion is not worth the wait but I digress).

A friend of my husband, who happens to be a recent transplant from Southern Italy, recommended Montesacro Pinseria to us, saying it is an amazing traditional little pizza spot down an assuming alley off a shady street in the TL. I made a mental note and then promptly forgot (it's a rather long name too so it's not something you might easily remember). 

A few weeks later, my coworkers were chatting about and amazing Pinseria not far from our office that one of my coworkers stumbled upon. Same description, amazing traditional Italian spot in an unassuming alley off a shady TL street. I knew it was the same spot and this time picked up the name. Montesacro Pinseria.

I was just telling my husband that I wanted our next date to be here when I saw my friend on Instagram happened to be hosting a happy hour at Montesacro and I was like - babe, this is destiny. We can eat some pizza and see Meliza. Winning. 

We ended up missing the happy hour but sweet Meliza made a reservation for us (something we didn't know we needed! Thank you Meliza if you ever read this). 

Anyway, all of this is a rather long typical SF story of how you find out about an amazing traditional Italian place on an unassuming alley off a shady TL street. 

The decor is a. bit vintage, a bit industrial, and overall stunning in its unique way. We enjoyed cheese the staff recommended to us and pizza. While we waited the owner gave us caprese salad as a kind gesture to us as friends of a friend, which made our hearts melt. It was delicious. 

I had the margherita pizza which is my go to when eating at more traditional Italian places. I prefer to taste the flavors in a good crust and fresh tomato sauce that have bells and whistles (I save that for when I want dominos). It was the most I've enjoyed a pizza since I was in Florence itself (I know, I sound like a prick, I am sorry). Really, we had a great time. I told my husband that this was the vision like teenager me had of older me haha :)

When I got to work the next day, I told my coworkers who had mentioned it about our experience and recommended it to the ones who hadn't heard the previous conversation. And now, I'm writing this, because I think you should know this place is truly exceptional. You should really try it and when you're done, tell someone about it :)
author: Sarz S.

description: Went again and had much better experience. Definitely worth checking out especially as a date night place
author: Sahil B.

description:
The hostess was completely clueless. First, it took her a while to acknowledge us (she was on the phone - but how hard is it to look up, make eye contact, and acknowledge our existence). 

The restaurant was completely enmity, yet we were asked about reservations (pretentious a bit there...). And told that they only had bar seating. We pressed her a bit on that, and after doing some advanced math she figured that she could give us a table, but we'd have to be quick. 

Yes, because all of your reservations will show up exactly on time... 

Anyway, no wonder the place was empty. 

There was another Italian place just down the street that was happy to feed us. (Their tables were actually full, yet they did a better job accommodating us).
author: Gigio S.

description:
Our group of seven has really enjoyed the dinner here tonight. Their pinsas were delicious, and the service was great. The desserts were ok. 
Overall, this place is great for groups!
author: Anna S.

description:
If you want to try really good pinsa and want to be served by beautiful Italian waiters, then you definitely need to check Montesacro Pinseria out! (And by beautiful, I mean bearded male waiters)

I ordered the margherita pinsa which seemed to be a Yelp favorite. It was so basic; tomatoes, mozzarella, and basil... but it was so good! The dough was chewy yet crunchy on the sides. And there were enough toppings without the pinsa having to be soggy.
(I know they don't like comparing pizza to pinsa but.... you know when you eat pizza and leave the crust untouched? Yeah, that's not the case here. Even the slightest bit of charred pinsa tastes good!)

We ordered the Crostata di Visciole for dessert which was a tart consisting of berries & ricotta cheese. It was super light and the perfect portion for dessert.

This spot does recommend making reservations but you could just walk in. We got lucky by getting seated right away because shortly after we got seated, several parties were walking in with reservations.

Oh! Just a heads up, you do need to walk through a sketchy alley to get to Montesacro Pinseria but that doesn't stop this review from being 5 stars.
author: Love K.

description: Great dining atmosphere, delicious food. My favorites are the new Aranche de Bertoli (blood orange beet salad), Rapette (beet salad), Casal Bertone (bacon honey), Maranella (sausage broccolini), and Margherita (cheese basil) pinsas. If you like spicy, ask for the chili oil!
author: Rich W.

description:
Wow. We were hungry and ran into this place by accident. We had a Pinsa with burrata, spicy sausage and broccoli. It was amazing! 
Their staff is friendly and attentive. We will definitely be back when we're in the area again. This place is not cheap, but it's worth it.
author: Alexander K.

description:
I really wish I were more hungry when we stopped into this joint. Super cute place with some weird decor...but it's cool. 

Boyfriend was craving some pizza before we headed to the airport so we found this place on yelp and gave it a try.

Waitress recommended the Infernetto, so we went with it - and we were so happy that we did.  The BF was in a sharing mood which is RARE, and let me have a slice. Yum.  He is lucky I wasn't hungry or we would have fought over who would eat the rest.  OR, we would have gone with his original plan to order two pizzas. Haha..

$20-22 for a personal sized artisan pizza is a bit expensive but the ingredients were noticeably high quality.  The spicy sausage on our infernetto was delish.  And it was actually spicy, so YaY!
author: Jessica C.

description: Atmosphere was magical- everything you could want in a pizza restaurant. Professional, warm staff and delicious pizza that was perhaps the best I've ever had. I ordered the chefs special, pear gorgonzola, was not disappointed.
author: Elle A.

description:
Amazing restaurant to get Roman style Pinsa. 
Pinsa is a flat bread that's based on how people used to eat back in the day in Rome. It's very similar to Pizza, with an emphasis on delicious dough and quality ingredients.
Make reservations! This place is pretty small, but quaint and cozy.
My friend and I opted for the porchetta, the burrata, and the Maranella pizza.
The porchetta is a small serving, but holy hell was it delicious.
the burrata was served with pesto and anchovies and was creamy and rich and perfect on bread.
The maranella was the star of the show. Crispy, flaky, and chewy dough topped with cheese, sausage, and broccolini. 
Must try!
author: Michelle L.

description: Nice.  Fresh and crunchy arugala salad with shaved parm is delicious  Pinsa is the thing to order.  The crust is yum!
author: Bleep S.

description: This place was a amazing find!  We arrived 15 minutes before they close for lunch and they still seated us and didn't make us feel rushed. Our server was very knowledgeable about the Italian wine list and helped me pick out a white that was wonderful.  The pizza was so good, and gluten free which we weren't looking for. I've never had gluten free crust and I might be hooked. To top it off, the owner bought my husbands beer because our drinks weren't on the bill. We were honest and pointed it out. He came by and thanked us and said he really respects honesty in people.
author: Cricket M.

description: Can't say enough about this beautiful establishment and the incredible food here. So yourself a favor and just go, NOW. Like a trip to italy right here in our own back yard. Real italian pizzas, an amazing selection of cheeses from around the world, the best charcuterie you ever had and **porchetta**.
author: linda a.

description: Very snobby workers.. while the food was good the environment was hostile. Must make reservation in advance
author: Lauren V.

description: Be transported to Italy when you step through the doors of this gem.  Seriously, you'll feel like you're not in San Francisco (which is a good thing because the neighborhood you have to go through to find this place is nasty), and arrived in Rome.  I love the decor and the warm servers (all Italian).  Sonja and Adriana are wonderful.  And the pinsa?  Delish!!! I like every one I've tried so far.  Light crust that almost melts in your mouth.  I adore the shaved asparagus with peas appetizer that tastes like it's fresh out of the garden.  I have a hard time sharing that plate and should learn to just get my own!  Haha.  I love this place.  (I just don't love getting there.)
author: Erin P.

description:
I would eat something from the Pinsa section of their menu everyday if I could. Five stars just for that section of the menu. 

It's an experience getting there, but once you are in the restaurant it's lovely. Friendly staff, great atmosphere, and fun decor.
author: Theresa D.

description: Meh. Pizza was off. You definitely don't know what the hell you're ordering. Pricey and was hoping for better. I get it, it's authentic, but I'd prefer traditional Italian pizza.
author: Basil B.

description:
Came here for pizza with a friend.  We walked here in the rain after work and it's in a very nice alley with lights strung up overhead.

We ordered the pinsa breads, of course:
1. Maranella,
2. Margherita (with sasuage),
3. Formaggi e affetati: PECORINO "Mastorazio" Casa Madaio and PROSCIUTTO S.Daniele

I will say that I loved the Formaggi e Affetati.  Our waiter recommended both the cheese and the meat after we told him kind of what we were looking for.  It came with toasted almonds and raspberry jam and honey.

My friend ordered the maranella and his sausage had a small kick to it that I liked.  The sausage on my margherita was less flavorful.  I'd say all the ingredients were very fresh but I would try something different next time.

The CASAL BERTONE, INFERNETTO, and VILLA GORDIANI all seem more flavorful and interesting than what I ordered.  I'd probably up it to 4 stars if I found something great in the pinsa selection.

Our waiter was great! I'd come again to try out more pinsa before I make a final decision.
author: Julia Y.

description:
This restaurant is everything I want in a dining experience. The menu feels like the people who created it really care about the food and wine experience you are about to have. Every single item feels like a new experience and opportunity to be delighted. This will sound weird, but it feels like the sexiest meal I have had in forever. Each dish is so thoughtfully put together and of such exceptional freshness and quality, I just found myself groaning and saying "mmm" repeatedly!! I love that the wine list is so unique and that it has a strong emphasis on natural wines - it's so exciting to have those type of flavor profiles to enjoy with this quality of food.

As for the pinsas - DEAR GOD WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN ALL MY LIFE. I am someone who doesn't understand what the big deal is about pizza being God's gift to the world, but these pinsas were LIFE CHANGING for me. The crust is otherworldly. Chewy, light, crackly, with a dusting of some ethereal flour, and then topped with the most delicious things, it was just perfection. All other pizza IS DEAD TO ME. I will dream about the pinsas here. 

Finally, our waitress (and sommelier!) Sonia was outstanding. She knew about everything on the menu, picked the most perfect wines, was beyond hospitable, and had a sassy sense of humor that just made us want to stay all night.

LOVE THIS PLACE.
author: Celeste R.

description:
I came to Montesacro this weekend with a few friends, and I am already dreaming about my next visit. This place is absolutely magical. We made a reservation for 4, and it took them an extra 15 minutes or so to seat us which wasn't ideal (there's no place to wait inside the restaurant and it's in a gross part of town so we didn't want to wait outside). Once seated, the restaurant is cozy and warm. Everyone is extremely friendly and attentive.

We ordered two appetizers and two Pinsas. We had the Rapette salad which was out of this world- the nuts and sunflower seeds provided just the right amount of crunch, and the dressing was light and brought out the natural flavor of the beets. The Cotto e Bufala was just a hunk of mozzarella on some ham- all high quality and delicious ingredients, but it wasn't my personal favorite. The Maranella pinsa was my favorite- the flatbread is pillowy and tasty, and the broccolini tied the whole thing together. We also had the Infernetto which was also incredible, but on the drier side compared to the Maranella. For dessert we had a slice of chocolate cake which was rich but just the perfect amount for sharing. It came with an espresso cream that was to die for! And the extensive wine list would appeal to anyone- plenty of price variance too.

Overall, I would highly recommend Montesacro to anyone- and I will be back soon.
author: Ayushi A.

description: Love this place. The atmosphere is really special and a nice location. Food is very good and the stuff fantastic.
author: Käthe R.

description: Enter from Stevenson St. alley just past the homeless and trash and you will be magically transported to Italy.  Authentic as it gets.  Pizzas are the real deal.  Waiter had that crazy italian-english accent that I love and rarely hear.  You know what I am talking about.  Drink some vino, eat some pizza and after it is all over you are back into the real world and need to get back to safety and away from Stevenson St.
author: Mike D.

description:
I found this place because we were meeting some friends at BuzzWorks later in the night so we wanted something close by because as you know, getting from one area of SF to another takes some time (driving 2 miles in SF takes approximately 25 minutes)!

We arrive at Montesacro and I am immediately impressed with the decor and thank god there was only a 5 minute wait on a Saturday night. I read on yelp that they serve "pinsas" which, to me, looked like a regular Italian style pizza but according to the description on the menu, it's more like a flatbread. 

We ordered the Maranella and Margherita (added prosciutto) pinsas.. they were both sooooooo good. I like this combo because we were able to try a red sauce and non red sauce pinsa. The maranella was something I'd not normally order as I am not a big fan of "white pizzas" but the creamy burrata, broccolini and pork sausage worked SO well together. The margherita was just as good. We couldn't decide which we liked more because they were both equally yummy! Although the pinsas looked heavy and carb-y, they were very light and didn't leave me feeling bloated or sluggish. 

There is a spicy chili oil that we dipped and drizzled our pinsas with so ask for this! 

So glad we got to try this place and now one of my favorite spots for "pizza" in the city. :)
author: Oanh L.

description:
Top, top, top!!! Staff so nice, most of them Italian. 
The place look like one of those Roman osteria. 
We got pizza and.... Omg! So light and delicate, yet tasty. You HAVE to stop here! 
The area outside at night is not very nice, but please manage to get here at least once, you will totally not regret it!
author: Maria M.

description: Phenomenal. Amazing crust, delicious toppings, unique combinations, authentic vibe.  Never heard of "Pinsa" as opposed to   Pizza - rice, wheat soy crust is perfect combination of crunchy and chewy.  We need Pinsa in Boston.
author: Seth E.

description:
The pinsetas were amazing! The shaved asparagus salad was fresh and delicious. The chef's choice charcuterie board was on point. 

The service on the other hand was atrocious.  Other people were attended to before we were, and we had gotten there first. Also, as a newly sober person, I was chastised for not ordering beer or wine. It's already hard enough trying to feel "normal," and that is what you are presented with.  I was very disappointed with the judgement.
author: Mariela L.

description:
My boyfriend recently tried this place with his co-workers and loved it - he ate the Porchetta appetizer and the Infernito flat bread pizza. We went here for dinner to try something else on the menu in the hopes that their whole menu was a mesmerizing as his first experience. This place is obviously popular, so maybe we just ordered the two most unimpressive things on the menu. 

We waited over an hour with two [disappointing recommended] glasses of wine. Unfortunately they were out of the Porchetta (a popular item) so we ordered the Foccacia Der Moratore (flat bread with sliced ham) which was about 13$, and incredibly underwhelming. It was so boring, not flavorful, and overpriced for what it was. If it had some pesto or some sort of sauce or cheese in/on it we probably would have been much more satisfied with it, but it was just so dry and plain. 

The pizza we went with was the Trullo. This was decent, but nothing special. It was topped with Italian sausage, mint, and shaved mushrooms. It was...alright. For a 20$ pizza, I was unimpressed. I will be giving this place a second chance, as my boyfriend continued to rave about the items he had a few days ago, but I might call ahead to make sure they have the appetizer he loved in stock before I eat here again. 

The service was also nothing special. While our server had an impressive Italian accent, he was sparce, never came to ask how the food was, refill our drinks, or ask about desert. I ended up having to wave him down for our check before we left. 

The ambience is cool - the vibe is definitely a good one; I'm just hoping we happened to go with the two duds on their menu. Fingers crossed that next time is a better experience. As I mentioned, this place is popular, so you would be doing yourself a favor if you make reservations.


UPDATE:
I tried this place again....will NOT BE RETURNING. Our waiter was basically non-existent. We had to flag him down every time we needed anything. Also we ordered 3 pizzas for a group of 4, as the pizzas are fairly small, and they brought all of them at the same time rather than staggering them to our table. The table was so small there just wasn't room for everything. Also he did not refill out drinks even once, and I had to ask 2 different people to bring some water to our table after the waiter neglected to bring it twice.

The bill ended up being about $150 before tip for one appetizer, 3 pizzas, and a bottle of wine. A little bit pricey considering the small size of the pizzas, and the fact that the ($18) appetizer was literally just 5 small, thin deli slices of porchetta..but I would have been fine with that had we gotten any sort of customer service. I was very unimpressed. Will not be returning.
author: Taylor D.

description:
My fiancée and I love this neat spot tucked away in an otherwise sketchy part of SOMA. I don't think we can go back to pizza after having pinsas here!

Our favorite things to order include: the porchetta, the Maranella pinsa (burrata and spicy sausage), the Tor di Quinto pinsa (smoked salmon and dill), and the olive oil cake.

Though the food is amazing on its own, what really puts Montesacro Pinseria-Enoteca over-the-top is its authentic European feel and ambiance. It really transports you and makes you feel like you're not in America, and it's not just because you hear Italian being spoken by the staff and many of the guests!

That all being said, this restaurant rightfully comes up every time my fiancée are brainstorming for a date night dinner. As long as we make a reservation, we never mind making the trip or searching for parking deep in the heart of SOMA to dine at this San Francisco gem!
author: Ryan M.

description:
We were happy to be able to grab a table here around 10pm on a Friday. I knew the character of the immediate surroundings and was a bit dubious that a high-end restaurant would be found here, but there it was indeed!

Our table started with a mozzarella and ham salad, followed by a few selections from the nice cheese and salami lists. We finished up with a margherita pinsa, which was thicker and airier than a pizza. We enjoyed all of it.

I had a glass of a Corsican red from their nice list of wines by the glass; plenty of bottles, and some beers, are available as well.

Service was spot-on, and it was a good experience all around.
author: Aron N.

description: Great Pinsa! It's my first time trying that, even though I'm Italian. Great restaurant with quality ingredients and very friendly staff. Highly recommended
author: Theo G.

description: I came here last Sunday with some friends - the restaurant is in a rather sketchy location (I came here for dinner). However, the food was amazing and the restaurant itself was very cute and homey. The food was delicious - very flavorful and it tasted fresh! We ordered the porchetta, chef's charcuterie plate, and 2 pizzas. Highly recommend this place - great for a dinner with fruends, family, or a date!
author: Katarina L.

description:
Just in case you haven't heard already, Montesacro is all about pinsa, not pizza. While the toppings might be the same, pinsa takes on an oval/rectangular flatbread shape and uses rice, wheat, and soy flour. It's all heated in their brick ovens which feature prominently in the venue, and the result is quite a thin, flavorful crust. When you add ingredients like mozzarella, broccolini, spicy pork sausage, and stracciatella di burrata as in their maranella pinsa, you get quite a delicious treat that's hard to put down, even if you try to pace yourself with the cutting wheel that they give you. 

Service is courteous and professional here. Despite the fact that it's made fresh to order, the pinsa doesn't take terribly long to come out. The venue is tucked into a SoMa side street and is not necessarily easy to spot, but once inside, it's a warm, inviting space that fits lots of parties big and small. A welcome addition to the West Bay dining scene!
author: Vincent L.

description:
Holy Moly!  $25 Bottle of Beer


We had read the reviews and looked at the menu before making reservations for a Friday evening (strongly recommended) so we had a pretty clear idea of what we wanted.  We were seated and the wait staff was exceptionally friendly.  We placed our food order and then ordered two draft beers.  For whatever reason, they had no draft beer so I looked at the bottled beer on the menu focusing on the description and not the price and trying to make a quick decision as the waiter stood there waiting (all the draft beers were $7 or $8 and mentally that's what I assumed the bottled beer would be).   

Our Panzanella salad arrived - tomato, cucumber, red onion, black olive, basil, crouton and red wine vinegar.  A rather small portion and at $15 I would have expected more than a few slivers of onion and two olives sliced in half.  All in all, rather disappointing.

Next, our pinsa arrived.  Unlike pizza, the pinsa crust is made of rice, soy and wheat.  We ordered the Maranella (broccolini and sausage).  It was absolutely amazing and we enjoyed it very much.

We didn't sample any deserts and then the bill arrived.  Imagine my shock when I saw a $25 charge for one of the beers and a $19 charge for the second bottle of beer.  In disbelief I looked at the menu.  Sure enough, in black and white, that was the cost of the two beers I ordered.  Yes, I accept responsibility for failing to note the cost (though to repeat I was feeling rushed having already chosen two draft beers they didn't have and hurrying to make a decision for bottled beer while the waiter waited) but Good Grief! $44 for two bottles of beer?  That was more than the salad and pinza combined.

Bottom line:  the pinza is excellent, the salad is mediocre in taste and portion size and, I'm sorry, there is NO reason in the world to have outrageously priced beers on the menu (they weren't even that good or cold).
author: Gary E.

description: If you like pizza the way America made it, I doubt you'll love the pinsa here. No complaints - the bread was light, the dishes were flavorful, service was quick and friendly. The pinsa felt healthy but it's definitely not your regular pizza. The only tiny gripe I had was the topping to bread ratio in the montesacro was not sufficient compared to my husband's veggie pinsa. I will come back not for the pinsa but the  delicious spicy chocolate mousse. Try it!
author: Shalini C.

description: Had their Vegetarian Pizza. The bread was really good, very light which doesn't make you feel bloated. Taste was authentic Italian and serving size was pretty big. Would highly recommend for authentic pizza.
author: Mohit A.

description: By chance my son and daughter and I had lunch here Friday, we sat at the bar and had some delicious pizza salad and a few beers.  I am so glad we found this place, very cute atmosphere nice service and great food.  We'll be back for sure, can't wait.
author: Kent P.

description: Super sketchy walking here from Hilton union square pregnant and with a toddler but all worth it. If you like spicy food ask for the chili oil so good.
author: Kenia G.

description: Best Italian food outside of Italy! Visit this gem now!
author: J M.

description:
Pinsa instead of Pizza. It's like a flatbread pizza but the crust is with a slightly different base. Ordered the maranella pinsa, which had mozzarella, pork sausage, broccolini, and burrata. I'm a big fan of burrata, and this came with a lot of it, which is great. Each pinsa is pretty nice size - a very full meal for one person - and they give you a rolling cutter thing for you to cut your own pinsa. It's not the easiest to cut, but it's nice to be able to split up the pinsa into however many slices you want (and makes it easier for sharing). We also ordered porchetta as a starter, which was great as expected.

The restaurant is kind of tucked away in an alley, so it wasn't the easiest to find, but they had many strings of light over the street in front of them.
author: Wayne H.

description: Simply put...amazingly authentic. I will return whenever I am in the city! Fantastico
author: Christopher C.

description:
This Roman hideaway is a fine informal place to eat before a show when you don't wanna splurge on a big meal. We had plenty to eat and drink and it didn't break the bank.
The seating and tables are very rustic.  We sat in what seemed like retired church pews, or train station benches. More kitchie than comfy, but alright. The tables are close enough to make the atmosphere friendly, like a trattoria in Rome. 

They have wines by the glass, but only one unremarkable rose' among them. As for the food, we really enjoyed everything we had, The Prosciutto San Daniele was one of the pricier "small plates" at $12, but the portion was eminently shareable.  The Sale Cheese small plate that came with honey, almonds and rosemary was a good sized hunk of chess, and delicious.
We had a Margharita Pizza, enough for two to share, but sparse on cheese and basil. Fresh and delicious, though. Oh, And, the Carpaccio! Oh my! Too good, with a good size salad, and shaved Parmigiana Reggiano.... the best.

The location is dicey, but once you're inside, you're back in Roma.

Two of us, all that food, one beer, one wine, with a nice tip... $84. A gourmet lunch.

Note: They are CLOSED on Sunday.
author: James G.

description: I loved the pizza in Rome and it was equally delicious at Montesacro.  Their cauliflower salad was also very good.  I now have a reason to come to this part of SF (and it's an oasis away from grungy downtown).
author: Janelle F.

description:
This is a very high quality restaurant!! 
Excellent service!!! 
We enjoyed a cheese platter 
Shared 3 different pinsa's  all we're delicious Maranella pinsa was the favorite at the table 
Overall I recommend this place quality ingredients, good service and delicious food
author: Big A.

description: Let me start off with the service. The service was amazing, not very fast but just good genuine service. We were seated at the bar which is great for 2. We started off with the mozzarella de buffalo - basically ham and cheese but delicious. The wife had the house pinto noir and it was tasty. For the main course we had the Maranella and the gordiani. Both were equally amazing , light fluffy and great toppings. Great place , glad we stopped in.
author: Thomas G.

description:
I really wanted to enjoy this pizza but the entire experience and Pizza itself was very lackluster and did not live up to what I was expecting based on the other Yelp reviews.

Pizza looked very different from the pictures and was much smaller than expected for an $18 pie. We ordered takeout and it didn't come with any utensils for our salad either.

Additionally the location is rather difficult to locate and in a less controlled area.

Overall the food was tasty but nowhere near what was expected and way to small for $35 worth of food.
author: Aleric H.

description:
What an interior! Part deli, part old time wine bar and description does not do it justice. Look at the pictures. 

It's down an ally and can be hard to find. Its San Francisco so the nearest parking spot is your driveway, where it is. 

Margherita pizza is excellent. Try the lunch special. Small simple tasty salad, pizza and an espresso. $15.
author: Danny S.

description: Y'all. I cannot say enough good things about this joint. *The* best pizza--or pinseria--I've ever had. And I've had a LOT of pizza. Delicious wine. The staff, especially our sever, José, was extremely friendly and very helpful. I can't wait to come back here and eat and drink again.
author: Stacey L.

description:
On foot we walked, why on earth would we walk on 6th street befuddled me, knowing it practically is a war zone now, like the 70s of the Lower East side.  but I think he was absent minded, having only considered the shortest distance from the hotel. Shortly we came upon an alleyway that looked more Little Italy New York than San Francisco, I liked quirky unexpected European looking restaurants as much as those posh, white table linen Michelin 3 star experience, and he liked dive bars with counter space dining. This is a good compromise for both, especially considering that he, despite his flawless American accent, is an European. He appeared impressed with his own choice, and snatched a table for two. I have this theory that people yield to good looking people, especially when a woman (hostess) sees a good looking man. I think he was used to that treatment since he was young, because we've never ever had trouble finding good tables without reservation, the only time he'd failed and I've succeeded was when it was a man greeting us. Not this time, the hostess led us to a table in the back, close to the meat counter, private and quiet, near all the exposed brick walls, treated, like you'd find in old town Italy. I had a view to the kitchen and to the main dining room, and he had a view of me, which he did not seem to mind.

I thanked him for this unusual find. He laughed, "I just used Yelp. You know, some people write reviews about restaurants they eat at...You just pick the ones you like. " Emphasize on "some people". He was mocking me a little,  having read one too many of my ROTD's.

Really, even if you have no other reason but to return that horrible shirt your girlfriend got at Bloomingdales, you should make your way here, it's charming, old school Italian, and quite unusual selection of flatbread. Don't get fooled by the establishment's Yelp category of "Pizza", it's not your typical pizza, not by a long stretch of imagination except for the flat non round bread part that's called pinsa, which is, apparently the street version of pizza.

We start with charcuterie with cheese. He said "I think you like this." I think he knows that we like similar food and yes I do like things that resemble French food. I am due to return to my summer home in Burgundy in three weeks and this was meant to be a goodbye dinner of a sort. Italian cheeses are different from French cheese, more similar to Spanish cheese, but still, somewhat different, milder, more ash than creamy. This place serves good looking Italian cheeses to go with nice assortment of cured meats. It came with jam yet no bread on the table. So I asked for a side of bread. Don't expect baguette however. More of your typical Italian bread that you'd find in New York. 

He ordered two glasses of red. When he's drunk his, he'd switch glasses, leaving his empty glass to me. He'd then finish my glass, and order another. I can only drink a sip or two. I remember the days when he only seemed to drink white. I have this theory (yes, another). People in their 40s go through a phase, they stop drinking red because their body cannot digest it, as they enter 50s, they can drink red again. He was in his early 30s when I first met him. He only drank bier then. In his 40s, we met again, at a restaurant not unlike this one, he told me that he had become a father, and was surprised to find me still looking exactly the same. He was holding a glass of white wine that night, in a dark gray suit that looked slightly too large on him. He ordered a glass of white for me too - but I smiled and told him that I only drank red.

They brought out our pinsa, a flat bread, topped with tuna and other things. It was the first time that I'd seen tuna on a pizza. I handed him the pizza cutter, he gave me the first slice, then he took it back from my plate, said that it did not have enough topping on it, and handed me another. I wondered how many women have their food plated by their partner like this. This was the only way I know how when dining with him. 

I took a bite of the bread, it had a fresh oven burnt flavor to it, there were not excessive cheese, just enough meat and veggies. It's the poor man's pizza, but like many poor man's version of things, it usually is better than the commercialized version. Try this before you go back to Domino's. 

This was a slice of oasis from the 6th street. Here you could feel the old San Francisco charm, not tainted by the street that had begun its decline two years ago. Here you could still get a decent meal, lost in time and space, feeling safe and sound.
author: Victoria E.

description: Amazing pinsa- the crust is unreal and so flavorful. My fiancé can't handle real doughy pizza which made this pizza option the perfect spot for us to finally indulge in some delicious pie together.
author: Colton S.

description:
Montesacro is probably one of the best pizza places I've ever been to. While their specialty isn't pizza, but rather pinsa, it's just pizza with a different, tastier, fresher crust.

The food is delicious for pizza styled Italian food, with the variety feeling authentic, fresh tasting ingredients, and just being overall good food. It's uneven instead of the normal perfectly round pizzas, and gives the food more character. The crust itself is different and brings a lot to change the composition of the food. The ambiance is also great, cozy, with a slight busyness to it that makes it feel alive. It's a great place to hang out with friends, or go on a date.

While enjoyable, there are a couple of things that worsen the experience. First and foremost is you are on 6th Street and Market, perhaps one of the dirtiest, and messed up streets in San Francisco. Not pleasant walking to, or from the place. It's also a little expensive. Maybe it's just a personal thing, but spending $20~ for a small personal pizza, albeit a good one, just seems a little overpriced to me. Pizza is one of the cheapest things you can get, and paying so much just doesn't feel great.
author: James H.

description:
Every single dish was plate-licking delicious!  Montesacro has better than most of the restaurants I went to in Rome (note to self: probably need to go back to Rome and go to better restaurants).  

I loved the antiques and vintage items scattered over all the surfaces of the restaurants, and I was told that they keep adding to their collection.  The amazing service at Montesacro also stood out.  When we asked for a group photo, the server went up the ladder (looks like a library ladder) to get the right angle!! Talk about literally going above and beyond for the job.

FOOD

TIBURTINA Sandwich: Creamy Stracchino Cheese, Prosciutto di Parma Shank "Gambuccio" served on Pinsa bun
- My favorite dish of the meal and is available for LUNCH only
- What I loved is the cheese... melted slightly, not at all pungent but flavorful
- So good with the prosciutto

(Pinsas are really more like flatbreads, not pizza.  We ordered 2 for 5 people, which was plenty of food.  Crust is amazing, and I recommend both of the below.)
MARANELLA Pinsa: Stracciatella di Burrata, Broccolini, Spicy Pork Sausage
- The sausage has a little bit of a kick but not spicy at all

CORVIALE Pinsa: Buffalo Mozzarella, Porcini Mushroom, Lardo, Parsley
- Super rich with the mozzarella and lardo
- Server's favorite Pinsa and a crowd favorite
author: Elle W.

description:
Walking down the alley was pretty bad, and I live in this neighborhood. BUT IT IS WORTH IT. 

Delicious wine, amazing food. Lovely service in a charming space. 

One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco!
author: Crystal M.

description:
The easiest way to win my heart is through .... Pinsa? Pizza ? Pinsa ? Pizza? Whatever it is, it's carbs and I love it! 

I've always been a big fan of thin crust pizza so I was super excited to see what the hype was about for this place. Although it wasn't my typical preference of the Cheeseboard - Arizmendi type of pizza, it was super delicious! 

The food: 
(+) For starters, we got the Chef's Choice of the cheese and salami (we like to live life on the edge lol jk we just suck at choosing).  The salami and cheese selections were great. I paired with a glass of Sangiovese and it was perfect. 
(+) For our pizza, we ordered three different ones for all three of us to share. I'm not sure if the menu changes frequently or not because I couldn't find all of the names on the online menu, but my favorite of the night is the Corviale! I'm a big fan of mushrooms so this was a win. The pinsa was definitely delicious but I feel it's a bit lacking in in terms of toppings, especially for the price that I paid and for the size of the pinsa. That also might be just preferences. I like my pizza stacked with toppings. Your call.

Overall, the experience was great. The restaurant was also very cozy and had a great atmosphere. The area itself is not tooooo great at certain hour of the night but don't let that stop you from trying this place out! Don't overlook this small alley restaurant :)

PS. I strongly recommend that you make a reservation ahead of time.
author: Tram N.

description:
Wow, what hidden gem. Had a great pizza, fresh caprese salad, and attention to detail in finding my wife and I the right wine. 
Definitely will be back.
author: James S.

description: Delicious Pinserias, and a very inviting atmosphere. The food was delicious, and the service was excellent. I do wish they would have had some house wines available, as that would have given it a trifle more affordability and authenticity. Our server was helpful in helping a group of us order the right amount of food. This is maybe not the ideal place to go to with a large group. Reservations are recommended.
author: Jason P.

description:
Incredible service for our large group. Accommodating and FAST! Super friendly and we will definitely be coming back. 

You can't go wrong with any of the pizzas!!
author: Nick W.

description: Infernetto is my new favorite and the Nutella pistachio fried dough dessert was incredible
author: Laura D.

description:
We took a lyft here so we could avoid having to find parking and walking through the neighborhood. They have a nice wine selection (natural wines!)
Ordered the kale salad - so good! The porchetta - ok the serving was kind of skimpy. The prosciutto plate - also kind of skimpy. I would order these again. We added the mortadella as a last minute add on - order this! The bread was delicious with a thin, crispy and pleasantly salty crust. The pinsas were all very good (can't remember exactly which ones we ordered.) The desserts were great as well. Only downside is the neighborhood.. but maybe that adds to the charm.
author: E D.

description:
First off, it's pinsa, not pizza :) It's a modern version of Roman flatbreads!

If you think of what 'hole in the wall' is, this is literally it. We turned down a pretty sketchy alley to find this hidden spot. If you don't look closely, you might miss it!

My group ordered 4 pinsas to share amongst 5 people and that was definitely enough! The pinsas come out uncut- we were able to get about 6 decent slices out of each one. 

Highly, highly recommend the maranella (spicy pork sausage and broccolini)! We also tried the infernetto- definitely tasted the buffalo mozzarella on this one- and tor di quinto. Both were good, but I kept reaching for the maranella so...

Definitely worth a trip if you don't mind the area!
author: Lani C.

description: Amazing pizza and asparagus salad. Will return and order a bottle of Lambrusco after work.
author: Giselle B.

description: So delicious and a cool atmosphere! Pizzas are just as good as everyone says on here. The street is sketchy so just know that going in, worth an uber door to door
author: Katherine C.

description: I was seeking a solid pizza joint that also served gluten-free crust, and Montesacro popped up on the list--and while they aren't technically gluten-free, they apparently make crust w/older, un-modified strains of wheat that don't make your glycemic index shoot through the roof.  I ordered a Margherita, and it was everything it should be--bubbly, thin, perfectly sour crust w/spots of oven char, not too heavy-handed on the sauce, and a smattering of basil leaves.  The price for their artisinal pizza was fair, and I expect to return to order other pizzas on their menu.  The only drawback is that some of their pizzas seem to be seasonal, so if you have the wandering eye for some of the pizza pictures on the Yelp page, they may no longer be available!  I also ordered a panna cotta, and while it wasn't my favorite version, it was still good in my book.
author: Crystal C.

description: Excellent service. The place is cozy with an old authentic feel while still feeling super clean. I got the fixed price lunch at the top of the menu and I'll definitely come back. Next time I'll try something more flavorful than marguerita.
author: Hassane S.

description: I probably had the best pizza ever at Montesacro. The ambiance was amazing. I had little hard time understanding the menu, but the waiters were really sweet. I would highly recommend this place for fine dining, or if you just want to have an awesome pizza!
author: Aditya G.

description:
I have officially found my new go-to place for some delicious bites in San Francisco's South of Market's Theatre District. Montesacro Pinseria-Enoteca is the place to get great charcuteries and salads but their biggest claim to fame is their unique flatbread pizzas which are so fabulous and tasty that each of them comes with their own rolling pizza cutter!
