Montesacro is named after a small working class neighborhood in Rome, while the restaurant itself takes its inspiration from the classic "fraschette" or Italian deli so to speak and they offer these delightful "pinsa" which is a modern take on the ancient flatbread that used to be served by peasants of the Roman Empire.  The pizza here at Montescaro with its numerous toppings and rice based and therefore gluten free flatbreads made for a meal of divinity.

But let's begin a the beginning, so to speak, my friend managed to get great theatre tickets at the nearby Orpheum Theatre, which is literally only a five minute walk away. This restaurant is very hard to find, it's on Stevenson Street, which itself is an alleyway and it's not in the safest area in the town. There's no real big sign announcing the place, just a small sandwich board with an arrow pointing to the entrance. Our four-top table was not in the most ideal location of the restaurant, as we were sat right behind the hostess desk smack dab in the middle of the restaurant. The busier it got at Montesacro ,the louder it got, not to mention the warmer it got. I'm not sure what this restaurant used to be in a previous life, but I can imagine it being some sort of meat or fish market back in the old meatpacking district days, but now that it's firmly ensconced as a restaurant they've still managed to keep that old world ambiance with a number of antiques serving as accoutrements. 

Even though we arrived as Happy Hour was just about to end, our server honored their wine deal which was a Schiavo Red Wine for 7 dollars. We ordered four glasses of that and it went down very smoothly and paired perfectly with all of our bites. When my friend wanted a second glass after 6, they made sure to charge her the regular price, so they know what they're doing even as they are slammed with customers. For my starter, I went with the Sott'oli which was a choice of house-marinated vegetables for five dollars each. Out of six choices they had on their menu, I asked our server what were the most popular, she said the mushrooms, zucchine and eggplant, so I went with those options. I loved the roasted eggplants and the armillaria style mushrooms. They were all seasoned well and nicely marinated and there was so much food on that one dish, we easily could have split it between us all. My friend went with one of the insalatas, the crudo di aspargi which featured thinly shaved raw asparagus, wild arugula, English peas, parmigiano reggiano drizzled with lemon dressing, I thought it was a solid, if slightly over-peppered salad.     

Then it was time to pick out our pizzas, again I went with the recommendation of our server, as she said one of the most popular was the Pietralata which featured grated pecorino/ parmigiano, mozzarella, guanciale, a hard boiled organic egg mashed up, and cracked black pepper. I loved how creamy each bite was with all of the cheese on the flatbread, which had a nicely charged crust topped with plenty of those pizza bubbles we all love. The guanciale, which is basically cured Italian pork, provided a tasty bite with each piece of pizza I cut with my pizza slicer. My dining mates had hits and misses with their choices as the Centocelle was another crowd-pleaser filled with plenty of ingredients including mozzarella, tomato, artichokes, mushrooms, olives, a hard boiled egg cut in half and plenty of prosciutto di parma. The pizza was artwork on a dish as all of the ingredients were laid out perfectly on the flatbread. One pizza that missed the mark with our table was the Torpignattara with its olive oil crushed potatoes, string beans, homemade pesto and toasted pine nuts. This vegetarian option looked good on paper and looked even better on the place but once we all tried a bite we all noticed one thing, the potatoes as it was prepared on that flatbread overpowered every bite and shrouded the other ingredients. Since it was basically a mashed potato spread on the flatbread, it seemed to make every bite soggy.   

But one miss of dinner didn't damper our evening, in fact once we got the bill, our total literally came out to fifty dollars a person including tip and the typical San Francisco health care surcharge, which in this day in age is not a bad deal. I'm so glad I have a new go-to place to eat before I see any show at the Orpheum or Golden Gate Theatres. You'll need reservations as it can get really packed at Montesacro Pinseria-Enoteca during dinner time. A good down home place for uniquely traditional pizza pies from Italy can't be a secret for that much longer!
author: Jason F.

description: Pretty good pizza, really cool space.  The waiter and host were both pretty nice.   I'd love to come back but not many GF options for my wife.
author: Michael E.

description:
Montesacro Pinseria-Enoteca is a relatively small restaurant on Stevenson at 6th street. It's decorated as an Italian workingman tavern with old artifacts and antiqued walls. Check out the bathroom for a surprise!  

The ambience is spectacular and the food is equally good. The salads and pinsa (think pizza) are delicious. Had a cheese and marinara one and a sausage. Both were excellent with the bubbly crust from their large brick ovens. Server suggested an excellent wine by the glass. 

Was there for Saturday lunch and the place was filled. Limited wait staff that seemed to be covering many tables each, so service was a little slow, but nevertheless, was very friendly and the waiter knew his menu really well.

This is definitely one of the most enjoyable meals we've had in the city in quite a while. Very convenient to the theater as well.
author: Phil B.

description:
I'm docking a star for really uncomfortable seating and a location in an alley that is not desirable to walk in especially at night.  Don't drive here just take an Lyft. 

Stepping into an authentic Italian pizzeria, great decor and vibe and everyone enjoying themselves.

We started with the artichokes, a few meats and goat cheese and beet salad. Loved the meats and artichokes, wine was flowing, the salad was forgettable, just kind of thrown into a bowl, couldn't taste the dressing, no presentation. 

The pizza was incredible, so crispy and light, it just melted away and left me feeling great after. It was well balanced, great quality simple ingredients, everything Italian food stands for. They have lots of creative pinsas and the simple favorites. 

The dessert, pot de chocolate was just the right balance of sweet and bitter.

I'd definitely come back here, my new favorite pizza.
author: Inga W.

description: If I'd left a review sooner it wouldve been 5 stars - not that I've been a few times I'm disappointed. Service is glacially slow. No apologies, no explanations. Sitting at a table forever. Food is ok but not amazing - plenty of other, better options especially considering better service.
author: Ryan B.

description:
D E L I C I O U S!! 
Crispy, chewy, light pinsa crust with fresh and simple ingredients. This is my pizza heaven. 
I'll push ppl waiting in line for Dottie's to get through to Montesacro. You had better make reservations or high tail your way here for a spot at the bar. This place is always filled. 
Lunch time you'll have a better shot at the bar, but don't count on it. 
This place is just a skip and across the street from the Golden Gate Theatre. 

My fave= Spicy pork sausage, mushrooms and the lightest, but most flavorful tomato sauce I've ever had. 
At fast food pizza joints I always ask for more marinara on the side because the one layered on the pizza never hits the spot and I have to douse that shiz to help it go down. 
Here, the sauce is incredibly concentrated that I savor the taste but never needing more. It's always perfection. 
We've had 3 types so far.  Prices ranging from $17-26. The spicy sausage with mushroom and tomato sauce, spicy sausage with broccolini and cheese and the porcini mushroom pinsa. 
Get the one with the tomato sauce first, sausage second and the mushroom last. I loved the mushroom, but I saved the sausage slice last to end on a high note. 
The porchetta is an indulgent four thin slices of buttery fatty pork for $16. The first time I had it the edges were crispy. The second time, not so much. Good appetizer, but it depends on the cut and day I suppose. 
Pinsa is my new preferred pizza.
author: Pam N.

description:
This is a traditional Italian restaurant, with a modern approach and  they hospitality is by far top notch. 

Adriana and Leonardo made the night by the light conversation, friendly tone, and expertise knowledge of the menu. We are from LA and my wife is a very picky eater, from the seating to placing our order they made us feel welcomed and like family.They made great suggestions and accommodated us even though we failed to make a reservation. If you're in SF looking for authentic Italian food with great pizza this is the spot.
author: S. Alfonso S.

description:
Went here before a SHN performance of Roman Holiday - and thoroughly enjoyed the German lager, charcuterie platter and cheese, pinsas (the broccoli, burrata one and the margarita add proscuitto), and the roasted veggies - eggplant, zucchini, red peppers. 

Delicious and healthy for eating out.
author: Christine V.

description:
Maranella Pinsa 5/5 Highly Recommended​
Margherita Pinsa 4/5 Crust was fantastic
Misticanza Salad 3/5 Very minimalist salad for the price.

Would recommend​/eat here for sure. 

Overall high-quality​ fresh ingredients, and a Crust that deserves a spot in the hall of fame.
author: Aaron B.

description: Very falovery taste.  Good place to take some friends to try it out. And love he decorations. Super unique
author: Ying D.

description:
I have been meaning to check this place out and finally made it here after walking through a slew of interesting characters on 6th street. 

The pinsa here is a roman style pizza with special dough - tastes a bit more earthy and dense, and less bounce in the dough. 

We had the Maranella Pinsa (not montesacro as mentioned in my photo - when/how could I edit my photos in yelp?), with Italian sausage, broccolini, and burrata. Even though it's a white pizza, it's bursting with flavors, with the perfect balance between the ingredients. 

Get the arugula salad to start, which is great for sharing. 

The ambience is casual and cafe style. If I were the owner, I would invest in the lighting of the place to make it look a bit warmer. 

Wine selection by the glass was excellent - I had a glass of red from Sicily and it went perfectly with the pinsa. 

We loved our waiter who was a super friendly Roman with plenty of singing tones in his English, just like the Romans Italy!
author: Rebecca C.

description: Great place to kick back and enjoy some very interesting and tasty wines with very hearty and satisfying dishes. Ive explored all over the city, this is one of the places always lingering in your mind to go back again.
author: Andrew J.

description: Omg, wow, nom nom, I know they aren't actual words, but verbalizations still that's what I pretty much did during my whole meal. While I am not an Italian immigrant like my grandma, I feel as though her high standards for pizza or in this case pinsas was passed down to me as well. I am not one for just grabbing a slice or sitting down at any random pizza joint in SF or any city for that matter. Yes, even those US or international cities with their own style of pizza. My skepticism had me a little concerned when my husband who is more open to eating anything with pizza or pinsa in the name indicated that we should try this place my excuses rolled in. Oh well, it's down and alley right, it's got a reservation, probably will be too busy, etc. Luckily my husband was able to woo me into a visit. The atmosphere of the restaurant and its alley way location made it feel like a restaurant strait out of Italy. Most of the staff was bilingual and you could hear Romance language being used to answer questions or converse with the clientele throughout the restaurant. The restaurant had its core menu focused on its pinsas of which we tried to two -- the LaMaro and the Margarita. The Margarita was a very traditional pie with five basic ingredients - mozzarella, basil, tomato, sauce, and the wheat/rice/soy base. Unlike the Margarita, the Lamaro was a spicy pinsa with chili threads and pepper. My husband also ordered salmon meatballs as a topping for the Lamaro a item, while not listed on the menu, perfectly complemented this pie. I would definitely return to this restaurant for lunch or dinner and order again. The flatbread crust had the perfect crisp texture and the sauces fresh thick tomato flavor reminiscent of my previous trips aboard.
author: Dawn B.

description:
I've had a string of good luck while dining in SF in the last few weeks. I found some real gems and MPE is one of them.

Came on Friday at 6:15 with a party of 4 and they gave us a table as long as we would be done by the 740 reservation. The space is really cool and the old ovens really do impress. The servers largely had Italian accents and the tables/chairs were old and colorful. Definitely felt like I was dining in Europe!

We ordered a salad with beets and goat cheese to start and shared 3 pinsa. The salad was actually a generous portion and the 3 pinsa were more than enough for our group of 4. We got a margherita, the maranella (spicy sausage and broccolini), and one with prosciutto and pesto/pine nuts. I liked all 3 but the maranella was my fave. 

We also ordered some drinks to start. I highly recommend their Rosé (the Tempranillo blend). They seemed to have a good wine list--comprehensive but not overwhelming. 

Pinsa came out very fast. It's definitely lighter than regular pizza but the claims of it being "low in calories" is BS. It's covered in cheese and meats after all. Just enjoy your food and worry about your diet at another restaurant ;) The char on the crust here is unreal and the pinsa come whole--pizza cutters are given to cut to your liking. 

Everything we ate was simple and delicious. Refreshing to have a pizza place I know is good and is centrally located. Adding this to our dinner and date night rotation! 

*Notes on the location.*
MPE is in an alley on Stevenson/6th. If that makes you nervous, don't come. If you are worried about "sketchy" or "seedy" neighborhoods, stay in a part of the city more to your liking/sensibilities and leave the pinsa for the rest of us. But if you're someone who realizes that living in a major city includes the full array of peoples and situations, then YOU can come! You'll be rewarded with some pretty awesome food!
author: Semuteh F.

description: First time been here to try this food. After did the Yelp review I decided to try their pizza. When I walked inside, I like their design, very classic. I like their music, their atmosphere, it's a good place for a group ppl hang out, chatting each other. After try their pizza, I like their bread, their pizza take different than the regular place. Since this time I order to go, next time I'll sit in there to try their food with my friends . Will come back!
author: Yueming G.

description: We had the pizza  to go. Was lovely and delicious! The kale salad is another stand out, very flavorful. The crust was a little more burnt than I would've liked.
author: Jessica L.

description: Hidden foodie gem in a seedy alley. Bring friends so you can try everything. Italian server sets an authentic atmosphere. Unforgettable bites: cold thinly sliced porchetta appetizer, raw shaved asparagus and peas salad, burratta and pesto, namesake Montesacro pinseta with raw kale, dessert pinseta with pistachio butter
author: Michelle S.

description: Truly the best Pinza(pizza) I have ever had! I forgot the name of the one i chose and tried to find it on line, but could not. The Pinza crusts are a blend of 3 different flours, it comes out thin, bubbled and crispy. Mine  was the first on the list. It has mozzarella , very thin portugese pork cheek, honey and peccorino. The crispy crust, salty pork cheek and sweet honey are a symphony of combined flavors! Hubby got the delicious charcuterie and the teens got a margarita pizza, yum! The food is authentic, service is fantastic, the atmosphere is straight out of Italy including the alley they are located on. They are very popular! We were asked if we had reservations, we did not. The four of us were seated right away. You have to go, no regrets!
author: Kristina D.

description:
I was skeptical. A hidden italian joint in SOMA/Financial district that's not overwhelmed by tourists? No way. Especially not one in an alley way close to Market. 

As it turns out, I was wrong. I now hesitate to even write a more thorough review in fear of making it even more popular.
author: Dora C.

description:
WOW...that pizza/flat bread crust...it's amazing.  It reminds me of those Brazilian cheese balls, but topped with pizza toppings!

We got the honey/bacon one yesterday and it was pretty awesome.  More meat would have been better though since it was too much dough towards the end for just 2 people.

We also shared the beet salad and the roasted cauliflower...both which were SUPER sour. The cauliflower was more cured tasting than roasted. I would pass on both of those next time.

We'll be back for sure!  Their dough is awesome and reservations were easy with Open Table.  Will update once we can try a few more things on the menu.
author: Vi Y.

description: Very authentic and tasty Italian food. We have been here a few times and really liked it. However, today another guest brought their dog into the restaurant and none of the waiters seemed to think that this blatant health code violation would be worth addressing. Yuk! If they don't pay attention to hygiene in the restaurant, I wonder how many corners they cut in the back / kitchen where you can't see it.
author: Fred S.

description:
I could not find anything to take this down to 4 stars so here ya go!  The service was amazing the waiter took me through the Italian wine list and brought me tastes to compare. The crudités was fantastic crisp and cold with delicious olive oil and sea salt. The Pinsa was amazing defiantly loved the porchetta and brocalinni.  I'll be back for the selection of charcuterie!  

While the restaurant itself is warm and welcoming it is in a gritty part of town.
author: renae s.

description: This is a nice spot, very interesting decor, good beer and wine list. The food is generally good, but the entire pinsa thing is sort of overdone. As interesting as the non-pizza dough that is used is, they are mostly "okay" versions of pizza/flatbread, some better than others.
author: David P.

description:
I rarely give out five stars but man, if this place was in Milpitas idk if I could stay away.

I've studied abroad in Rome and after trying pizza in New York and locally, by far this is the closest to the pizza I had in Rome. I've dined here at night and even for lunch and either way it's just so good! It's a hidden gem, where the food and atmosphere can take you back to Italy in an instant! 

For lunch they have this awesome deal for a small salad, margherita pizza and an espresso for 15 bucks!! What a deal!! And during the day it seems like the servers are young but still good service! 

Now at night for dinner, totally different atmosphere! Servers are speaking Italian left and right and when they talk to you their thick accent can be heard, I love it!! Like being in a restaurant in Italy! Except these servers are nice! Now for the food! First of all their pizzas are pinsa! So oblong shaped pinsa with thin bubbly crusts made for you right in their brick oven! And you cut the pinsa yourself :) so you control whether you wana share or not! 

-maranella: not sure if I spelled this correctly but whatever you do, get it! I don't care if you think broccoli can't be on pizza but just get it!!! Comes with broccolini, olive oil, sausage and just wait for it....burrata cheeeeese! If I were to die and go to heaven, I hope this pinsa exists in heaven! That good! 
-margherita: so simple but so delicious! What I miss about Italian food is that their marinara sauce is sweet! And you can definitely taste this here!! 
-porcheta: this is a deli meat selection, and it's delicious, made in house it's slices of cured pork served with delicious olive oil and sea salt! Also very tasty, but if you dine for two, it might make you full! 

Some say well there aren't enough ingredients on these pizzas, but that's the key in Roman style food, less ingredients and simplicity so you can really taste the quality! 

They have a nice selection of wine! Not basic at all! And when you ask your server for advice, it isn't like other places where they're like yea it's good, they really describe the food and get down to what you might enjoy! Just overlook the hustle and bustle at night, it's not that bad! If you are worried then come during the day. 

When you come here, order your food sip on some wine, and take your time eating! In Rome, dinner would last for hours like even 4 hours! Really savor every bite!
author: Monica G.

description: Felt like pizza our last night in San Francisco and thankfully found this little gem of a place. My husband and I walk in and know that we are about to experience something great, and we were right! This is truly an indulgence for us with my husband not tolerating gluten well (he calls himself a failed Italian), and it was all well worth it. We shared the kale salad and Margherita pinsa, which were both to die for. Ended the meal with the pinsa stuffed with pistachio cream.. OMG! We left extremely happy humans. We will be back for sure our next visit!
author: Stacy C.

description: Great pizza (Maranella) food and atmosphere though quite pricey. The neighbourhood is a bit dodgy however, which is a remarkable contrast from the interior of the restaurant tucked away in a small street.
author: Alfie L.

description:
Ask any native San Franciscan and they will tell you "San Francisco" is not even "San Francisco" anymore. San Francisco has changed so much in the last decade that it's disheartening. Do we seriously need a luxury high rise apartment building on every freakin' corner or a $7 bottle of free-range water at the newest haute cafe?

One thing that hasn't changed drastically is the batsh*t craziness on 6th street.

I can have a 10 minute conversation with a metal pole and it would be perfectly normal. If I did that in Pac Heights, I would end up in a straitjacket.

I've been wanting to try Montesacro Pinseria-Enoteca since they opened last year but the location has deterred me. I've had two ubers cancel on me when I was in the area in broad daylight (at noon). I spoke with several drivers and they told me they usually avoid picking up people from this area for safety reasons so plan accordingly via public transportation or your own ride, rice rocket, pocket rocket, whip, etc. If you decide to drive there and have an early dinner, plenty of street parking can be found on Stevenson if you enter through 7th street. 

My friend and I came to Montesacro for an early dinner several months ago in January (sorry, I'm super behind on reviews). Reservations are highly recommended as it was pretty full by the time we finished at 6:30 pm.

On the menu are salads, cheese & charcuterie, and pinsas (beer & wine only). Montesacro boosts to be the only pinseria in the United States to serve pinsa, a roman-style flatbread that came before pizza. They use a blend of rice, soy, and wheat flour that's proofed for 72 hours producing a low-fat and low-carb flatbread.  

My friend and I started with the Radicchio Salad w/ arugula, bosc pear, forme d'ambert bleu cheese, almonds ($13): http://bit.ly/1RpauEF. Everything was fresh but it was just a very ordinary salad. Next time, I would skip the salad and go for a cheese & charcuterie platter that we were eyeing on other tables.

We shared two pinsas. The first one was the Maranella Pinsa w/ burrata, spicy pork sausage, broccolini ($18): http://bit.ly/1SjSCrm. Loved the savory sausage and creamy burrata but we weren't keen on the broccolini. Not only did it weigh down the pinsa but it was difficult to take one clean bite without tearing through the fibers of the broccolini or the entire stalk just falling off. Personally, I think shaved fennel would have worked better. But let's talk about that crust...it was lightly crispy, fluffy, and with a subtle chew. So amazingly simple and delicious. 

For our second pinsa, we ordered the special of the night: Imported mozzarella, chanterelles, shaved black truffles ($30): http://bit.ly/1TgASlz. It was love at first bite. The soft, stretchy cheese along with the earthy mushrooms, and luxurious shavings of fragrant black truffles on that amazing flatbread was sublime. This pinsa is worth the a trip to the batsh*t craziness on 6th street.

Service is very leisurely (read: S-L-O-W). We were one of two tables when we arrived and it took over 40 minutes to get our first pinsa. If you're in a rush, I would go elsewhere. The staff wasn't very warm nor attentive, and I felt our server did the absolute minimum by just taking our order and delivering our food. It would have been nice if she checked in with us at least  one time during dinner but she didn't.

Love the rustic atmosphere of Montesacro so it's great for a casual date; not recommended for large groups but there is one large communal table. There's also counter seating at the bar if you want to go solo which is exactly what I plan to do next time so I can hoard the entire pinsa to myself. Hey, don't judge...it's low-fat AND low-carb remember?
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Every time we eat here (and it's often!) I feel like I'm back in the alleys of Italy. This place has captured all the best parts of a neighborhood restaurant. The food is incredible (we love the burrata & pesto and the roasted cauliflower antipasti for starters, and you can't go wrong with any of their pinsas) and service is just as amazing. It's casual, authentic, and a great value considering the steep costs of San Francisco. They take the time to remember the locals, and serve up a great experience every visit. hands down this is the best food in a 10-block radius, and no doubt the best pizza option in the city.
author: S M.

description:
Wow!  You love cured meats... GO!
You love cheese...GO!
You love flat bread style pizza...GO!
And yuh better invite me!
author: Julie L.

description: My father and I were stranded in SF on our way to china and decided to go into the city with the few hours we had and I am sooo glad we did! Easily the best, most fresh REAL pizza I've ever had. Absolutely delicious; it was unreal. Small restaurant and a very cozy and classy feel. But the food is the real
author: Sydnee W.

description:
The food is Amazing, but dear god what a bad location!!!! Right  in The Tenderloin District on a sketchy alley. I felt like I was going to be shot as soon as I stepped out of the restaurant. I had to take off a star for the location. 

The food and the staff are amazing. Even though the vegetarian options are limited, they make up for that with the limited options being delicious. The Margherita is sooooo gooood!!!! 

You know a place is authentic  Italian when all the customers are speaking Italian.
author: Rishabh J.

description:
Finally got a chance to try this place and everything was pretty damn awesome.

We ordered the following: The Bell Peppers Sott'Oli (grilled bell peppers marinated in olive olive, chili flakes and garlic), Insalata di Rucola (Arugula Salad), the Maranella pinsa (with Mozzarella, Broccolini, Spicy Pork Sausage, Stracciatella di Burrata), and finished it off with the Budding al Cioccolato con Panna (chocolate pudding).  I would recommend all of these dishes again.

Everything was simple, made with fresh ingredients, and wonderfully executed--just the way food should be.  I did not know what to expect from the Sott'Oli and really enjoyed the peppers.  I will be trying different veggies the next time.

I was curious how the crust of the pinsa would compare the "normal" pizza crust (yes, there are lots of different ones to compare this to) and IMHO it had a softer texture.  Still very delicious if you put the right stuff on top.

The decor was pretty simple.  The wait staff (who all seemed to speak Italian) were really friendly and the prices were very reasonable given the food experience.
author: Bob F.

description: Really unique and charming restaurant. The pinsa here is to die for. Basically each person gets a pinsa. My table wasn't ready when I arrived at the reservation time and the hostess was kind enough to give us a glass of wine while we wait. How nice! Their wine selection is unique and the server was very patient with letting us try different wines. Overall a great restaurant with excellent food and service. Location is a bit sketchy but once you enter the restaurant it's like time travel to another space.
author: Sohiroshi C.

description: Wow. Best bread. Wow. Friendly staff, dope decor. The paninis are way better than I'd expect for any panini
author: Dan L.

description:
For the sake of transparency, this review is based solely on my 2nd visit. My first visit was very good in terms of taste, service and experience - in fact, memorable enough for me to go a 2nd time when I returned to San Fran for work.

I returned on a Wednesday night, about 8:30, dining alone. This time, no wait and I was sat at a comfortable table. Clearly not sat or urged to eat at the bar because no one was tending this night.

The truth was it was just fine this time. Not great and not enough to recommend it further. I think it has a lot of potential. The menu and wine list are well developed and the food is good. Something is missing though. My example was that as an appetizer, I ordered a selection of the Gorgonzola Dolce. It was good, very good, and a decent portion, served with roasted almonds and fruit preserve/reduction. What it wasn't served with was any type of toast or bread. I sat and waited for someone to come by so I could ask. Nope, didn't happen. So I ate it with my knife and fork. A hard cheese I could almost understand nothing to smear it on, but not a soft one; it's not like it's easy to pick up and nibble.

I'm sure others have had better experiences here, and I did once before, but this time it wasn't the same and was really disappointing.
author: Roger G.

description: Seriously such a treasure. It feels like one of those places that is in your hood' & you bring your girlfriends and just laugh over amazing pizza and wine. It's not stuffy, or obnoxious and every time I come in there is a new crowd. The food is always excellent and the service is quick and warm. I love bringing friends here and having fun conversations over the pizza with a hint of honey. It's the most authentic Italian pizza I have had in the city so far. Keep the wine & pizza rolling and make sure to make a reservation and just enjoy this hidden spot.
author: Juliana O.

description: Awesome pinsas and Italian cured meats. Walking here was a bit rough though. Not from this area, so as we walked there we were surprised. We saw two signs on the walls outside that ask people not to urinate on the walls. Seriously. Crazy location, but excellent food.
author: Shelley K.

description: Love Montesacro and the pinsa! We order from them all the time and I've eaten at the restaurant a couple of times as well. Margherita is a classic, the ingredients are simple but just absolutely delicious. I also like the Centocelle and the Maranella. The options for delivery via Uber Eats are a little more limited, but still has a good variety. The service was friendly and attentive when I was at the restaurant as well, and I really enjoy the homie vibe. I'm a big fan!
author: Nana L.

description: Popped in here for a glass of wine and a couple of appetizers. We were very pleasantly delighted by the quality and service. There is a historic oven here that is a sight to see for any baker.
author: David B.

description:
If you like pizza, you'll definitely like pinsa, its very similar but more ancient and precious Roman cousin. Montesacro is apparently the first pinseria in the country, and it opened like a year and a half ago. I believe it. Pinsa is not exactly pizza but it is almost exactly pizza. It's enough like pizza that some bad pizza places (the ones that make thick, doughy crusts) are more or less making bad pinsa. It's also enough like pizza that no one would open a pinsa parlor outside of, say, NY/LA/SF, for fear of being mocked into bankruptcy.

I happen to be a NY/LA/SF kind of woman, and I loved Montesacro, though less for its pinseria designation than for its wonderful food, service, and atmosphere. My husband Matt B. and I were staying in Union Square and walked over for a Friday lunch. It was bustling but not packed, and we got a table right away. Lovely space--high ceilings, natural light, casually rustic Italian deli decor. Service was excellent. We had a very warm, helpful waiter who took great care of us. 

We drank a couple glasses of wine--a Rioja and a Bellone--and enjoyed a splendid, relaxing pinsa lunch. I ordered the maranella pinsa, and Matt got the $15 lunch special--salad, margherita, and espresso. The pinsas were delicious, fresh pies with fluffy, flavorful flatbread crusts. The maranella came topped with stracciatella di burrata, broccolini, and spicy pork sausage. I generally prefer tomato sauce on my pizza, but this was just perfect, the cheese creamy and gooey, the broccolini tender and full of fired flavor. The sausage was spectacular--I dropped a piece on the floor and if I weren't in public, I would have picked it up. (Instead, I mourned it quietly.) The margherita was also great, classic mozzarella, tomato, basil pizza with that pinsa twist. The salad was a nice healthy side, if nothing special. Mixed greens, lightly dressed.

We finished our meal with the espresso and a mug of chocolate budino. This is not to be missed. It was rich but not so rich it was hard to eat, with a lush, decadent texture and a dollop of thick whipped cream.

I wasn't expecting anything in particular from Montesacro--it was just a place my husband found on Yelp when we woke up hungry. It ended up being one of the most pleasant, satisfying lunches of my year, and I hope to repeat it when I'm back in the Bay.
author: Steph C.

description:
First, they require a credit card to reserve a table.  Why, do you ask? because it is located in the scary extension of the tenderloin in an alley with excrement and passed out alcoholics on the sidewalk.  If we hadnt used our credit card we would have driven by and not parked in the $15 safe lot for a 1.5 hour lunch.
Second, the pinseria pizza is doughy and the topping cheese was skimpy and the sausage few.  Not worth 20 bucks.
The crudite plate looked like someone had cleaned out the back of the refrigerator.  
The presentation of the salad, the eggplant was weak.
In sum, nothing special here, pricey, and in a terrrible scary neighborhood.  
It should be a place the SF City Supervisors should have to walk to so they can appreciate the beauty of the SF streets.
author: Skip D.

description:
I've been to Montesacro Pinseria-Enoteca probably 5 or 6 times now and I enjoy it more and more every time! It's a small restaurant tucked away on Stevenson off shady 6th street, but once you walk into the restaurant it's like an oasis. Adorable ambiance -- it seems authentic to its Italian roots without trying too hard.

Now let's talk food. Last night, we went for the kale salad to start, which had a wonderful caesar-like dressing with parmesan cheese and very light croutons. It won't blow you away but it's a solid way to start. 

They also have a wonderful cheese and charcuterie selection. We had a delicious soppressata and our server recommended a dolce treviso to pair with it. I had never heard of that cheese but it was a wonderful buffalo, cow and goat cheese blend. Delicious!

Finally, the pinsa! Yum! You really can't go wrong here. I'm very partial to the Maranella, with spicy pork sausage and burrata. The burrata is perfectly creamy and the sausage has just the right amount of spice. And the pinsa dough is incredible. I'm definitely coming back for more of this!

The wine selections are on point and our server guided us to wonderful pairings with our food. The list leans to Italians varietals but I had a wonderful German wine that I never would have selected on my own. 

This is a great spot to have dinner before heading to the theater, and I'd love to come back on the weekend for a more leisurely dinner and explore the menu a bit more. Just be careful on your walk to MPE -- 6th Street is shady at best.
author: Catherine K.

description:
First, the food is great. The quality of the ingredients are top notch. The presentation and creativity of the food is what you expect. We had two nice salads (tomato and mozzarella was simple but delicious). We also had the Tagliere Misto - if you're a fan of charcuterie you'll appreciate the board. The Margherita was perfect for the teens - light, crispy, and perfectly cooked. The Maranella and Pietralata were both tasty combinations of veggies and meats on a flaky crust. And we found a decent bottle of Sangiovese on the wine menu which wasn't over the top budget-wise. 

The negatives...it was hot. A little crank of AC would have been nice. And the greeter (who also ended up being our server) was rude, condescending (correcting our pronunciation of Italian words, really?), forgetful (still waiting for the celebration of the birthday we came for), and inattentive (if you're going to keep it 85 degrees in the restaurant then at least bring us more water). 

In the end, party of 7 with three teenagers, four pizzas, and one bottle of wine was $250. Eh, for a hot-stuffy restaurant with rude service it wasn't well spent. Maybe stick to lunch or happy hour.
author: Michael E.

description:
This is a hidden gem! The ambiance is cozy, comfortable, authentically Italian, and adorable. The cheese tastings were fabulous and came with honey and a homemade jam. They paired perfectly with their wines. 

The pinsa, which is like pizza on top of a crispy, bubbly crust was good but felt a bit understated for my taste. I prefer a heavily sauced, cheesy pizza. They have an interesting selection and I tried the pinsa with fermented fish sauce (salty like anchovies, topped with a generous serving of roasted kale). 

There's a deli in the back. I would come back for lunch, or cheese, meats, and wine!
author: Leeyen R.

description:
I wanted to love Montesacro. I really did. Let me first caveat this review by saying that I did order take-out. However, take-out was not a factor in this review. The food received was clearly not worthy of the 4.5 stars that this establishment has. Let's break it down.

I ordered the Torpignattara pizza. I'm no expert in Italian, but I believe that it translates to "mashed potato, green beans and pine nuts haphazardly thrown on dough". I love potato pizza. But this was a flavorless flatbread. 

Also got the shaved asparagus salad. I'm as open as the next guy to eating dishes that are only one color, and I had high hopes for this all-green salad (arugula, peas, asparagus). Unsurprisingly, it was bland. 

My coworkers ordered pizza. My boss, a well-traveled professional, opened his box to reveal a  margherita pizza (a simple dish to say the least) with small amounts of lackluster toppings on grilled bread. Another ordered a mushroom pizza that looked slimy.

Perhaps had we gone out to eat at the proper restaurant, the food would have been hotter, and a little more crisp. But there is no excuse for a lack of flavor, especially at this price point. 

I'm giving two stars because they offer delivery and have an inventive menu, but ultimately this is not a place that I will be going back to.
author: Ben S.

description: I went to Rome last summer and this place made me feel like I was back in Rome! It's in a very sketchy area that makes you feel like you must be lost until you find it, but as soon as you walk in you are transported to Italy. The pizza was very good! We also had the carpaccio which was only OK... Here's why.... We have always had carpaccio that just melts in your mouth and comes apart  very nicely with your fork. This carpaccio was very different. It was very sliced beef, but I don't think it was raw beef as it is usually. I think it was cured beef and had a texture more like prosciutto. We weren't expecting that. It was a little tough to eat compared to the types we had tried before. It did not melt in your mouth. All around a good experience though.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Our favorite spot for a pre-show meal.
We've tried a fair amount of the menu and haven't found anything we were sorry we ordered.
author: Ken P.

description:
Absolutely brilliant experience. As other reviewers have previously expressed, reservations are strongly recommended, as there are only a few dozen seats, and waiting might be on the sidewalk outside due to the very small reception area. 

The pinsas were really yummy looking, but being gluten-free diners, looking is all that we did. There are many other offerings available to the GF that would allow one to not even miss the pinsa. 

Not being really familiar with cured meats and cheeses offered, the formaggi e affetati a-la-carte was a bit intmidating, so we ordered the chef's selection, paired with a gluten-free baguette we purchased elsewhere, and were not disappointed with what was presented. 

The sott'oli, house-made marinated vegetables in olive oil, garlic, chili, parsley and salt should not be missed. Crudo di asparagi, a salad of thinly shaved raw asparagus, arugula, and raw English peas was perfectly dressed in a lemony olive oil. The other salad we ordered was the carpaccio; the slightly saltiness of the meat was perfectly balanced with the pepperiness of the arugula and marinated mushroom salad atop it.

Lastly, leave room for dolci. Our waiter suggested the panna cotta as a good gluten-free option.  We found ourselves swirling spoonfuls of creamy, vanilla bean and anise flavored custard through the small pool of delish olive oil. Truly lovely flavors.

The waitstaff was attentive, without being obtrusive, and knowledgable with offerings to suggest good pairings of food and wine. 

Will definitely return.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
love this hidden gem! really unique atmosphere and different style pf pizza, apparently it's called pinsa. Go the extra effort to find this place and try it. Not surprisingly there were a bunch of start up brats and tech poseurs in there in the fairly cramped quarters of the place but ignore them and focus on the food.
I rarely rave about pizza (pinsa) but these guys are doing something truly special.
the base is more like a flatbread almost like a turkish style pide but different again. Lots of great topping combinations, think prosciutto, shaved zucchini, artichoke etc.
Can't do it justice in words, you need to experience it yourself.
author: Brett J.

description: Super friendly staff, we appreciated how accommodating they were with last minute changes to our group reservation. The shaved asparagus salad had raw sweet peas and was so vibrant. The pizza crust was crisp and chewy but somehow also light as air. A lot of attention to details done well. I would definitely come back before a show at the Orpheum theatre.
author: Lisa T.

description: Ed U. Was excited to introduce me to the pinsas at Montesacro. Wow! What a delicious food! The crust is delicious and very light. The toppings were very fresh and tasty. We also had an appetizer that offered several vegetable choices mixed in olive oil. We enjoyed the eggplant, zucchini, and olives. A cherry tart topped off the meal. I'll definitely be coming again to Montesacro!
author: Jamie W.

description: Our fave pizzeria!! Pizza just like in Rome!! Love the waitstaff!! Stellar customer service. Sketchy area make sure u look down because there have been syringes and often poop but I go during the day so it's not a big deal. I'll forever be a fan!!!
author: Annalisa T.

description:
I'm so impressed by this cute little unassuming restaurant! I went here for a group birthday dinner recently and was totally blown away by the deliciousness of their pizzas. They are small enough that one person could eat one alone (and maybe then some). 

As I was eating the pizzas here I remembered how Elizabeth Gilbert described the most delicious pizza she's ever had in Ear, Pray, Love: crisp crust, but the dough has a softness to it that is almost naan-like. Go here, you won't regret it. YUM!
author: Sahana U.

description:
This is no regular pizza place! This is a true Italian spot that makes "pinsa" not "pizza". It is a flatbread topped with fine ingredients (I say fine because its not your standard mozzarella cheese and pepperoni). They have truffles, italian sausage (real kind - not TJs), strong flavored cheeses, and amazing salami (for the fan like myself).

This is the definition of "hidden gem". It is on 6th street - the wildest of wild streets of SF. So please be careful. But it is well worth it.
author: Nikita K.

description: I agree with most-- this is a small, very pretty restaurant in an extremely sketchy part of SF. If you're walking, as we were, avoid 6th street at all costs! Homelessness and drug addiction are rampant, and the street people are quite aggressive. 7th is slightly better. Or better yet, take Uber and ask the driver to turn into the alley/street that the restaurant is on instead of getting off at the corner. As for the its raison d'etre, pizza, it's neopolitan style:  chewy, charred crust with quality meats. However, we found the flavors to be rather bland, even the "spicy " sausage. Hard to believe this is the beat pizza in the city. Tell me there's better!
author: Jojo S.

description: The food in this restaurant is heavenly. They use the finest ingredients and the result is freshness and perfectly married flavors. The service was spot on as well. I felt like was in Italy.
author: Barbara L.

description: This is a "must" place to dine for both locals and visitors!  Despite the neighborhood, it's worth the trek. I come here as I work nearby and the pizza is the most delicious I've tasted!  The service is very friendly and the ambiance is quaint and cozy.  It can't be missed especially if you are a pizza lover!
author: Meghan L.

description: This is a little gem despite it's surroundings/neighborhood. Food is delicious, staff is friendly, chefs are happy to show off their pizza making-skills.  We ordered ALL of the pizza on the menu and you know when a place is good when they can make the simple, margherita pizza perfectly.  Go enjoy,...
author: Bhu P.

description: Every from the food to the staff was amazing. Definitely a is you live in the Bay or visiting.
author: Chevaun W.

description: This place is great. Food and wine spectacular. Purveyors spot-on. Feels right. Don't rush this exerience, just dive in and enjoy!
author: Timothy Q.

description: My wonderful husband found this delightful restaurant. Once inside you are comfortably transported to an earlier time with vintage decor and rustic menu items. The pinsa is wonderful - the wine list is very interesting. Good, friendly service - smiles all around. Went back to try more of the cheeses and charcuterie offerings. Very delicious. Highly recommended.
author: Laurie Anne B.

description:
Loved this place!!  Came with our three children and everyone was satisfied. Next time I will definitely just come with my husband. It was fine for a family but it would be more fun for a date or with friends  

We had a board and a couple of pizzas. The food was terrific. Wine and beer selections were good.
author: Tracey K.

author: Dan B.

description:
Not even exaggerating, this pizza is better than the pizza I had in Italy.

I tell everyone about this place! 

Make a reservation as it gets packed since there's probably less than 40 seats in the restaurant.
author: Adamsj87 J.

description: I had the pizza (aka pinsa) that had mozzarella, light sauce, good sized pieces of sausage on it, and broccolini! Sooo tasty and scrumptious. The menu is kinda hard to understand but just ask the waiter and you're in for a good meal! I think you're also supposed to put down a. Reservation but they were accommodating and sat us anyways. Loved it
author: Aaliyah D.

description:
Super slow service. Staff was focused on socializing with one another more so than taking care of customers. 

"Pizza" was good (and the only reason they're getting any stars beyond one).
author: Ashley M.

description:
The best pizza (pinsa) we ever ate!! Amazing crust!!
Great service too! Everything was so good!
author: Scott O.

description: Very good food. Non-existent service.  8 pm dinner reservation for my 11 and 14 year old daughters and myself. Seated promptly and waiter service downhill from there. Non-attentive. Haughty almost. Only time we were approached after ordering (other than being served our food by a runner to whom I had to ask for water) was by the hostess when asking if we were finished. Two pinsas and an arugula salad were served timely and were tasty. Outstanding? Not so much but very good.  It was not a leisurely dinner or positive experience as we'd hoped; we were out the door by 8:35.
author: E F.

description:
Don't let the scary walk there or the sketchy location scare you away--this place is legit. 

I loved their take on classic Italian pizza, and that crust... Ohmygod, that crust. It's light, chewy in places, crunchy in others. It's not bread-y or super filling to the point of needed a nap after lunch. It's perfect. 

I opted for their lunch special, which includes a small salad, the "traditional" pie, and an espresso. Everything was simply prepared with quality ingredients, which are celebrated, rather than covered up. The sauce was light and fresh, the cheese was rich and delicious. And there were little, charred parts that added a real authenticity to this pie. YUM. The salad was simply dressed with a light vinaigrette and shavings of quality parmesan cheese. 

The service was good. We were in a rush and had to eat quickly. I felt they worked hard to make sure we were in and out in the quickest manner possible. One missed mark was the espresso we were supposed to get with our meals weren't offered to us until we had to pay and leave. I didn't really want mine anyways, so I opted out. But, I think they should have been served to us closer to the end of our meals, especially considering we made it known we were short on time.
author: Cara L.

description:
Really enjoyed this place during a first visit last weekend. It was a rather bread and meat heavy meal, but I didn't mind indulging. The pizzas are served on oval-shaped flatbreads. The bread is light (reminds me of a thin focaccia) with a crispy base. Our table ordered a few pizzas and appetizers. Memorable dishes included the rapette, porchetta, and maranella Pizza. I'd skip the margherita next time. 

Service was great and waters stayed refilled the entire night. 

Bottom line: I'd return if I'm in the area.
author: Heather L.

description:
This place serves an amazing pinsa!!! The crust is on a whole new level. Soft yet crunchy with a nice chew!!! Ingredients and toppings are super good!!!
 
Tried a  Margherita, another pinsa with brocolini on it. Also, got the the porchetta on the side. Next time im in the area Im definitely going to come by to grab some more food.

Love the decor too!!
author: Guess W.

description: Great food and great service. There was a mix up when they couldn't find our reservation. They went in the back and grabbed a table and 4 chairs and set us up in the middle of the restaurant and gave each a glass of prosecco on the House.
author: Scott G.

description: Possibly some of the best dough ever made including a recent trip to Rome!   Make a reservation and try it yourself.  You will not be disappointed.  Perfect location for folks going to the theater (Orpheum).
author: Robert H.

description: We got a table for 5 on a Monday night and it was still pretty fairly full around 7-9pm. Unfortunately they were out of the Malbec we wanted but recommended a similar red that we enjoyed. Started off with the buffula and a variety of meats and cheeses. The waitress didn't explain much of what they were, but we really enjoyed them. Ordered 3 flatbreads- strongly recommend the one with green beans pesto and potatoes. Truly unique. Wish I had a better view of their meat and cheese counter.
author: Jordan Z.

description:
After a short walk through the gritty part of 6th Street, we found the restaurant in the alley adjacent to Dottie's. 

As soon as we walked through the front door, we were transported to a warm and rustic  place in Italy. 

Our waiter, Jose, recommended a bottle of light red that was perfect for our meal. 

My husband and I started out with the watermelon salad--which was refreshing and delicious. We also had tastes of the bresola and manchego cheese. 

We then tried the Montesacro Pinsa --A M A Z I N G~!

It wouldn't have been our first choice, but again, Jose was great with his recommendations. 

The Straciatella was so yummy, and the crust was crunch and chewy at the same time. We polished the Pinsa in no time. 

Our plan is make this our regular date night rotation--but order two pinsas instead of one!
author: Mimi T.

description:
This has become a favorite go-to spot for me near Union Square.  The street is very dicey, but that kind of adds to the allure.  I like the food and the service has always been great.  It does have the feel of true Italian joint.  

My only suggestion to the owner might be to dial back the kitsch a little.  The more junk around the more it seems fake; you're doing great with the basics.
author: Douglas E.

description:
Loved this new pinsa and the new make up of the dough which consisted of rice, soy and wheat flour.
All the pinsas had fresh ingredients and they all tasted great. Came with a group and everyone finished everything.
I hope they open one in Los Angeles soon it would do so well.
author: Lila H.

description:
Such a great hole in the wall! 

We literally circled the place 3 times because we couldn't see it since we would pass it easily but once we did boy are we glad we came in. The pizzas were absolutely delicious despite our difficulties of saying the dishes' names lol I just know I had the vegetarian one and it was delicious! The pesto and potatoes on it were super yummy. 

Nic was also a really great server and very helpful!
author: Allenmar S.

description: *HORRIBLE! Abysmal service and a complete lack of graciousness. I've experienced better service at McDonald's. I called at 5:15 on a Friday afternoon (May 11, 2018) and asked if there was availability in 30 minutes. I spoke to the person who answered the phone and he said "yes." I asked if I needed a reservation and he said "no, there is availability." I walked with my wife and two young children from our Union Square Hotel. When we arrived slightly before 5:45 the person at the front - the same person who answered the phone - said there was no availability and then, when I asked him if I had spoken to him, he said "yes" but thought I was asking for a table for two people, not four! I asked him why he would assume that and that he didn't ask about the number in my party. He feigned an apology. When I asked to speak to the manager he went away for a few minutes, attempting to explain to his manager. The manager - named Lucca - was no better, telling us we could sit at the bar I motioned to my children and told him that would not be appropriate (and more than half of the tables were empty). Then he said we could sit at the cramped table directly behind the maitre d' *but we needed to finish in 45 minutes, because the table was reserved!* *OUTRAGEOUS.* *INCOMPETENT MANAGEMENT.* A complete inability to problem solve and be gracious to rectify their mistake.
author: Samer S.

description:
Hidden Gem in an otherwise tourist/homeless area. The service was excellent and accommodating. We were trying to make it to an 8pm show and they put us at the bar and made our pizzas quickly. 

I would return and advise others to try this unique "pinseria". The dough is AMAZING.
author: Frank J.

description: So this South of Market place is on a side street about 1 block from the Golden Gate Theatre, which has been great for us.  It is tiny, so it is hard to get a reservation for dinner before a show.  But I have to say, the food is 100% worth it! The salads, the salumi and formaggi, the Pinsa... all delish and worth the trip over.  We ate there for the 2nd time this weekend and had great service... our waiter was molto bene. We will most definitely eat here again before a show.
author: Dawn R.

description: Last night in San Francisco, I stumbled upon this gem. I definitely recommend the pinsa with pistachio
author: Riccardo F.

description:
Area?  Yeah, totally sketch.
Food?  Totally worth it.

Nothing good comes easy.  That may be my number one mantra. 

The only thing that's easy here is...eating.

Take Uber or take a cab; no parking & you don't want to be walking around here at night.  You don't even want to be walking around here in the daytime for that matter.  Actually, hell, I don't even like to DRIVE around here in the daytime...but I digress.

Romance?  It's in an alley.  Like Bix.  Like Claude  (Cafe Claude, who opened Gitane, in the same alley...).  Incidentally, after having dinner here, we went to Bix for drinks...can you say perfect night?!

Food?  They serve PINSA.  No other restaurant in San Francisco serves PINSA.  

What is PINSA?  Simply, think pizza, only way better.  A fresh, light, clean crust.  Pizza, streamlined.  We were told by the owner, Gianluca, that despite everyone comparing their pinsa to pizza, the only thing the two actually have in common are the toppings.  

Apparently, it's all about that crust.

Funny.  I've been saying that for years.

However you define it, pinsa is friggin fabulous.

They only opened 9 1/2 weeks ago.  In that time, they have everyone going to the most unsavory neighborhood that is 6th & Market...& not even caring.  

The space is minimal & rustic.  No frills.  Thank God.  It has a sort of food hall feel, despite the small size.  The great Federico Fellini himself would want to film here.  I've read several reviews that said eating here reminded them of eating in Rome.  Enough said.

We started w the prosciutto & melon & the caprese salad.  The melon is organic.  It was divine.  Perfectly tender.  And sweet.  The best I've ever had.

The mozzarella in the caprese was also perfection.  Salty, crisp, smooth in all the right places. 

The Porchetta.  I had to order it.  So should you.  Oh so tender & oh so crisp.  

3 pinsas we ordered...Collatina, Maranella, & Quadraro.  

The Collatina...the freshest buffalo mozzarella, greens, & cherry tomato.  They put the toppings on after the crust is made.  So, the toppings are not cooked or even heated.  My friend Marla said it reminded her of the pizza she had when she lived in Rome.  Props, major...for that.

The Maranella.  Burrata, broccolini, & spicy pork sausage.  White sauce.  Delicioso.  Just please do it.  BUT!!!  If you only order one pinsa?  Then it HAS to be the Quadraro...

The Quadraro.  Wow.  The hands down Star.   Tomato, red onion, pancetta, & pecorino.  Really, ORDER THIS.  The red sauce was POETICALLY GOOD.  As in, they should bottle it good.  

Service?  Not perfect, but not far off.  I'm only saying this because my friend, Guido, (Marla's husband) made the comment...our waiter recommended a wine for us that wasn't Italian?!  What?!  He's right, though.  Dude, if you're gonna push something on the wine list here, push the Italian wines for chrisake.

There's only 12 tables.  And one of those is a large group table.  Make a reservation.

5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
I just left this place, and I'm already craving their pizza. We only had two pizzas. And honestly, I would have the same two again.

Their crust, yes... that scrumptious crust. They let their dough rise for 3-4 days. Most pizza places only let the dough rise over night or 2 days at most. This place has the most moist, fluffy, and crunchy crust. That mozzarella here is so superbly delicate and salty that my mouth waters at the thought of each bite. Their arugula is fresh and the pizza slicer at every table makes me so pleased that I don't have to cut the pizza with a knife. 

This place is new and will probably get popular real fast. Definitely a contender for the pizza places in the city.
author: Marlene T.

description: If you're looking for an authentic SF/Italian experience, this place is well worth the wait, close accommodations and the walk. One of my personal favorites. Honestly, good luck finding better.
author: Derek D.

description:
A Word of Warning
While the food remains high quality and the ambiance still authentically Italian, the serving persons last Thursday evening were purposefully and significantly upselling the wine list.  I will take full responsibility for not paying closer attention as the one picking up the tab, but was out of the loop when the server  "suggested" a bottle as the second of the night.   This one ended up costing $60 (the first $39).   Totally bogus and extravagant.  After all is said and done, it's still a pizza place for god's sake.  There are perfectly fine wines available for under $40.
State attenta people.  It's a corporate jungle out there.
author: Steve N.

description:
The restaurant itself is in the worst part of SF.
I suggest you LYFT to it, to avoid parking and walking around the homeless
as they are aggressive there. 

The dough of the "pizza" is thicker than I personally like but still good.
The toppings were thrown with no logic, we had one prosciutto slice on the whole pizza.

The place has a nice feel.
I'd go back if I lived in the city.
Since I don't, I won't as the area is not conducive to good karma.
Would be nice if SF took the billions of dollars in taxes and did something with it.
author: Saar H.

description:
Delicious! Note that it's not a pizza place -- it's pinsa, which is slightly different (More like what many places call flatbreads). With that in mind, the food is fantastic. It's genuine and flavorful. And the restaurant has a sort of pleasant, unpolished atmosphere that I enjoyed. 

The pinsas are pretty affordable and filling, but your meal can get expensive if you order extras (sides, a glass of their expensive wines, etc.). 

The reason why I'm not giving this 5 stars is the chairs were so uncomfortable. They were probably chosen to fit the rest of the decor, but the backs were uncomfortable to lean against to the point where it distracted me from my meal.
author: Valerie P.

description: I went for first time and I loved it. Luckily for me we were a big group and I tried most pinzas they had in the menu, they were all so good I couldn't pick my Favorite. They have excellent service and Salvatore recommended exquisite wines.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Very good Italian restaurant. I liked their nice Pinsa (Margherita) - really worth to try! Fresh basil, nice tomato sauce and mozzarella. Excellent dough.
Only negative point: the first plates are really small, which make them very expensive for their price (about 6 dollar).
Hint: you can eat at the bar if you don't have a reservation.
author: Alex G.

description:
When I complained that I have not found any pizza places that I've liked in SF, this place was recommended to me. It's not pizza but "pinsa", which uses a flour made from three different types of grain. Rice is one of them, and I think that's what gives it a crispier texture. This means, when you're actually craving a pizza, Montesacro might not do it for you. If you're wanting chewy textured satisfying dough, you might want to go somewhere else.

I was all about ordering whatever specialties they had, but asides from the Maranella, my friend wanted a margherita (he says it's the best way to judge a pizza place). And while the Maranella fell a little short of my expectations (the burrata did not come out as much as I had hoped), the margherita was even more average. It kinda felt like not enough of everything, tomato mozzarella or basil. And for a meal that left me still feeling hungry, the bill was pretty expensive.

I still like this place for bringing something different to the neighborhood. Some of the other combinations sound interesting, so I'd come back to try those pinsas!
author: Stella A.

description: This place is spectacular. You could drop this place in Rome and it would fit right in. The owner is great, so is the staff. The food is delicious and unique around here. My only complaint is the hipsters have discovered it and it is getting quite busy!
author: Mike W.

description: Good flatbreads, good ambiance, and friendly staff. The neighborhood isn't great but it's on a cute alley that has nice little lights.
author: Camille E.

description:
From the menu: 

"Pinsa is a flatbread t hat was once prepared by peasants living outside the imperial walls during the Roman Empire". 

I admittedly am not a fan of thin crust pizza but a standout place like Montesacro-Pinseria-Enoteca is what make Yelp awesome. 

I had low expectations but from my first bite my preconceived notions quickly began to change. 

If you come here you have to order a PINSA, why get a sandwich or anything else:
I haven't had a bad one but I'd have to say that my favorite is probably the:
Trullo- Tomato, Lamb Sausage, Mushroom, Sheep's Milk Yougurt and Fresh Mint. 

The Pinsa's range in price from $15 to $ 22  with the average being around $19.  If the prices were a couple bucks lower per Pinsa I think this place would probably garner a 5 star from me (I'm stingy when it comes to 5 stars and believe in a bell curve for ratings). 

As others have noted, in this neighborhood you have to keep your eyes open and be alert. I usually laugh as comments like this but the neighborhood definitely made some people I've come with here visibly uncomfortable so it's worth nothing.
author: Rod M.

description: This is good pizza place. Manu has unusual pizza types but the different topping mix well. Small little bit but always busy. If you like Pizza you will like it.
author: Mohsen I.

description:
Sixth Street? Seriously? Am I in the right neighborhood for such a fashion-forward concept as a pinseria romana? Why yes, yes I am, you jealous Marina and Pac Heights snobs. It's here in SoMa on Stevenson right around the corner from Dottie's True Blue Cafe. And if you expect the neighborhood has gentrified overnight, please remember to fasten your seat belt before returning to your home planet. It's still as cacophonous as ever, but step inside this establishment and you are in Rome near Piazza Navona just coming off your tangerine Vespa. Tall ceilings. Dark wooden cafe tables. Rustic teal chairs, two big ovens in the back encased in subway tile. Ciao, Marcello...Ciao, Sophia.

The owner is, no surprise, a Roman named Gianluca Legrottaglie, a partner at nearby 54 Mint and a genuinely nice guy as he came to each and every table to thank them for coming. Me included. And if you're wondering what a pinseria is. Well, it's like a pizzeria but not. Unlike pizza, pinsa is made of a mix of rice, soy and wheat flours imported from Rome, and it produces a crisper, flatbread-like crust after it spends mere minutes in the traditional brick oven that actually existed in this space for years unused. I just came on a whim as I usually reserve my pizza eating with Jamie W., but I found this place too hard to resist. The menu is pretty robust with marinated vegetables (sottoli), cheeses, salumi and salads present and accounted for (photo: http://bit.ly/1HvmJM5).

I decided to start with the $10 Cavolo Nero Insalate, a baby kale salad with marinated anchovies, shaved pecorino and drizzled with an anchovy vinaigrette. It came with a bowl, and it was just delicious with the kale nicely massaged and the saltiness of the anchovy just right for the serving which was placed in a glass bowl (photo: http://bit.ly/1Dqr1hh). There are ten pinsas to choose from, and to my own surprise, I went for the healthiest one, the $16 San Lorenzo with tomatoes, zucchini, eggplant and bell peppers, which I was told was the vegan option, and the lightweight crust made it almost gluten-free. Presented on a regular-size platter, it was a rustic shape suitable for solitary diners without leftovers (photo: http://bit.ly/1Ptteju).

It was absurdly delicioso and fresh tasting with all the vegetables strewn on the top in strips and the crispiness of the crust just right with the char. I didn't even miss the cheese because the fresh tomatoes provided all the lubrication I needed with each bite. It's billed as "low-fat, low-calorie and easy to digest" which only made me want to try the other nine pinsas. Some of them looked gorgeous as they passed by. I must have really thought I was in Rome because I decided to have an Espresso (photo: http://bit.ly/1Hze6OW) and the $7 Crostata di Visciole, a slice of the wild cherry tart dusted with powdered sugar (photo: http://bit.ly/1QqOUOH). A tasty treat, and Gianluca was right. You don't feel overstuffed at the end. I didn't want to leave though that had more to do with going back into the land of sirens and unprovoked screaming.

FOOD - 5 stars...never had pinsa before and now I'm hooked...what a delicious way to eat a healthier pizza
AMBIANCE - 5 stars...like a Roman oasis amid the guerilla warfare on Sixth Street
SERVICE - 5 stars...staff is great, very attentive and Gianluca is my paisan
TOTAL - 5 stars...such a welcome addition to a neighborhood that really needs a unique eatery like a pinseria
author: Ed U.

description:
If it weren't for Yelp, Montesacro's high rating and being close to the Orpheum Theater (Book of Mormon!) I would have never considered walking down sixth street, going down a side street and entering a fairly unassuming door. But it was totally worth it, the food/drinks/service was superb.

We started off with a wine suggestion that was really nice, the wine list is extensive and a bit overwhelming but just ask for advice. We then had the beet salad, it was really good, a good chunk of flavor but not too heavy. Then it was time for the main event, the Pinsa pizzas! We had the infernetto (spicy) and maranella (sausage and broccolini) and they were amazing, awesome crust, big flavor.

We didn't have time for dessert as we had to run, the good thing is that it is only a 5-10 min walk from the theater.
author: Tristan L.

description: Pinsa was nothing to complain about, other than the fact that they're all about 20 dollars each. My only complaint is that while waiting for my second pinsa (ordered because I wasn't full) I saw a cockroach crawl out from the kitchen area towards our table. Not only that but an employee accidentally stepped on it and it was left there squirming as I waited for my food until another employee saw it and nonchalantly picked it up and took it to the furthest trash can. Good food but can't help but imagine what kind of hygiene they have behind the scenes.
author: Gerardo A.

description: Fabulous Italian bistro with amazing food.... great vino selections. Perfect when visiting the Orpheum.
author: Maria D.

description:
If you've ever been to Italy then coming here is like dying and going back to Italy (heaven)!   You must experience a pinsa (flatbread, read the story on Pinsa) among so many other amazing Italian starters, formaggi, salumi, vegetables and for lunches add companatico (sandwiches). Don't expect an Italian (American) pasta restaurant. Expect a slice of Italy. True Italian atmosphere and food. Don't miss the original ovens at the back of the restaurant. Another don't miss is having a conversation with Mirco (Meer-co). 
Saluti!
author: Dawn M.

description: Felt like I was back in Italy! Great vibes, wine and food- the perfect spot to grab dinner before a show.
author: Jenna B.

description:
My friends and I came here to celebrate an early birthday. It was my first time here and it's one of those really unique hole in the wall restaurants which I find are the city's hidden gems.

The venue is in the tenderloin but once you're inside the ambience I absolutely spacious, airy, and unique. I really like how the set up of the venue is and the vibe it sets up. 

The three of us shared Rapette, Prosciutto di Parma, Margherita Pinsa, and Primavalle Pinsa.

The service was quick and attentive and the employees were all really friendly and had great customer service. The first two things that came out were the Prosciutto di Parma which was really fresh and the Rapette. The Rapette which had beets, farmers mixed greens, sunflower seeds, chives and we asked to replace the goat cheese with Parmesan. I really enjoyed how fresh everything was and the change in cheese complimented the salad really well.

The last two things to come were the Margherita and Primavalle Pinsas. The Margherita had a delicious fresh basil taste I really enjoyed. My absolute favorite was the Primavalle Pinsa, it has tomato, mozzarella, olive oil marinated eggplant, parmigiano reggiano, and basil. The best part for me was the eggplant, I think it was well seasoned and baked perfectly into this Pinsa.

I will be coming back here again to try more stuff on their menu!
author: Michele W.

description:
Ate there for dinner tonight. I'm a big fan and will return.

Vegan notes: The menu's vegan options are limited. The meat- and cheese-heavy menu has a couple of nice roasted vegetable options, and my server volunteered to remove cheese from a salad to make it fit my dietary constraints. Props to my server -- I really appreciate your willingness to be flexible!  There's one pizza option marked "vegan" (which was nice, because one usually has to hunt pretty hard to find the hidden vegan options) -- but several other pizzas could probably be made vegan with modifications. 

I ate the artichokes ($5) and roasted eggplant ($5), followed up with the San Lorenzo-style pizza ($16), and washed it all down with a wonderful glass of Andreola - Rose Extra Dry  ($12) from the substantive wine list. The rose was the server's suggestion. Nailed it.

The eggplant was sliced thin, oven roasted just enough to be soft but toothsome, and finished with an amazing olive oil and nice granules of sea salt. Couldn't have been happier with this dish. The artichoke was plentiful, beautifully plated, but not remarkable.

The pizza was tremendous -- a nice, high hump with a few black blisters. The underside was crisp and just strong enough to hold the weighty vegetable toppings of broccoli rabe, beautiful crushed tomato, mushroom, and roasted red bell pepper. The ingredients went well together; the pie was perfectly cooked. 

I can't give this place a five because it was pretty loud and echo-ey. A table near the entrance were having to yell to each other to be heard. An investment into sound-dampening engineering would go a long way to bring the noise down so that we can really listen to the flavors of our food. 

Can't wait for my return visit.
author: Vladimir C.

description: Totally awesome and worth the walk from where ever you are.  We had my son's birthday here as my in-law family is Italian.  We will all be going back.
author: Laura P.

description:
Excellent Italian spot for a different take on pizza that they call pinsa. It's supposedly a style from outside of Rome back in the day that's been updated with a new type of dough. 

Sampler charcuterie platter "tagliere misto" (3/5) - the cheeses were quite pungent/strong and the hard cheese was very tough. Hate to dock for that as I do love interesting cheeses but this just wasn't for me. The meats were good. The salami wasn't your run of the mill as it has some sort of nut or seed. Presentation was very nice.

Vegetables "sott'oli" (3/5) - solid but unremarkable veggies. They weren't crazy overpriced but I'd say just to get it for variety. 

Centocelle Pinsa (5/5) - overall the most variety per slice. I found it very flavorful. If you don't like the idea though of not having each ingredient on each slice, probably not for you.

Maranela Pinsa (5/5) - pretty solid with a hearty amount of veggies

Service was super friendly and you get a feeling the restaurant is run by a warm Italian family. It's cozy/upscale in a hipster renovated way and not the traditional Italian-American or upscale authentic Italian way.
author: Victor W.

description: I wanted to love this place. The alley, the great ambiance inside...but I couldn't. Our server cared little about our experience yet was falling over himself to attend to two gentlemen at the table across the aisle from us. Wah. It was our first time in and it was their first time in too. The Sott'Oli zucchini was yummy but very salty. The margherita pinsa didn't take long to bake & I loved the crust. The porchetta was succulent and flavorful it way too fatty. The wine had to much of an aftertaste but it's imported and I'm used to California wines. That was the closest I'm going to get to the sixteenth quarter of Rome anytime soon, and it wasn't as magical as I had hoped.
author: Carla W.

description:
The area was a little too sketchy for my taste but the food and service was great! Three of us shared the carpaccio which came with a mountain of parmesan and arugula and that was tender and delicious. I chose to get the burrata, broccolini, and spicy pork sausage pinsa, and I would definitely recommend that to people! My friends got the Centocelle (mozzarella, tomato, artichokes, mushroom, olives, egg, prosciutto) and the Quadraro (tomato, red onion, pancetta, pecorino). Both were also pretty delicious (but I have to say mine was my favorite)! Each pinsa is definitely more than enough for one person, and, if you're not feeling too hungry, 1 is enough for 2 people to eat.

The service was pretty good and I thought the space was really cool! Again, the only downside was the area it was in. While we were eating, we saw someone rolling a joint and some guy getting arrested all in the frame of 2 hours.
author: Grace C.

description: Ciaoo I high recomen this pinseria I work Italian restaurants for the last 10 years this pizza it's really good (salmon pizza ) service amazing very friendly feel home I go back next week grazie Chef
author: Saulo P.

description: This was our second visit to the restaurant and we were impressed by the salad and the TAGLIERE MISTO - Chef's Selection of 3 Cured Meats and 3 Cheeses. We were underwhelmed by the CORVIALE Pinsa , it was OK but not great. The neighborhood is horrible, we walked by people shooting up in the street and multiple homeless people, so it might be a better place to go for lunch. (Clearly the neighborhood didn't keep us from going back again.)
author: Molly M.

description:
MARANELLA!!!!!! Best pinsa!!

Came here for my roommate's birthday party with a group of 11. The restaurant is pretty small so I recommend making a reservation if you're coming with a large party. We ordered multiple pinsa ("pizza") to share--maranella, margherita, centocelle, some house special, and some other pinsa with tuna, capers, and onions on it. Out of the five that we shared, the maranella (burrata, broccolini, spicy pork sausage) was hands down the best.
