I thought I would like the tuna one more because I love tuna and capers, but that pinsa was just too dry and salty.

Great service! Location sucks (6th and stevenson). Cozy atmosphere.
Next time I come back, I'll definitely just get a glass of wine and maranella.
author: Annie S.

description:
I was very sceptical and thought that all the reviews of this place are completely fake because you know - Sixth street.... etcetera, etcetera... :) 

I arrived for the dinner party of 10 people and we ordered EVERYTHING! I think we left no stone unturned and no menu item not ordered. 

Pizzas, oh wait, those are called pinsa here, were amazing! I also enjoyed the vegetable appetiser. 

Rustic and cozy atmosphere, a glass of Italian wine and a slice of pinsa in my hand - made this dinner party so much more awesome!
author: Anelya S.

description:
Tried out Montesacro on Wed 4/22/15 for lunch.  It's on a small street Stevenson off 6th St.  If walking you'll see Dottie's, then turn Rt which is Stevenson Street, restaurant is on the Right.  Small restaurant, has a bar area where you can eat too.

They have Sottoli - house-marinated vegetables in extra virgin olive oil, parsley, chili flakes, garlic 1 for $5; 3/$12.  I didn't try any.

Insalate & Piatti Freddi - salads $10-13.
We tried Panzanella-tomato, bread crouton, red onion, capers, cucumber, oregano $11 - we liked it.  

Formaggi (cheeses) 1 for $6; 3/$15 - didn't get any

Salumi 1/$6; 3/$15 - didn't get any

Porchetta - slow-roasted pork $10 - didn't try

Tagliere Misto - selection of cheese & salumi $22 - didn't try

Pinsa - flatbread made with a blend of rice, soy, & wheat flour imported directly from Rome.  All GMO Free, low-fat, low-calorie & easy to digest (Menu said).

We tried Centocelle-Mozzarella, tomato, artichokes, mushroom, olives, egg, prosciutto $17 - It's a long & I think good enough for 1 person!  We liked it.  Thin, light, crispy, good cheese & stuff on it.  

Panini - LUNCH ONLY!  I didn't notice that until later or I would have liked to try it.  Must go back to see if it's any good.  Served on Pinsa bun w/ farmers market greens

Buffalo Mozzarella, olive oil cured eggplants $12
Gambuccio E Stracchino-prosciutto shank, soft crescenza cheese $11
Porchetta E Provolone $13

Soft drinks from Italy $5

Takes credit cards, One unisex bathroom near the entrance/side wall.

Hrs:
Closed Sun
M-Sat 11:30am-2pm; 5pm-11pm
author: Ann L.

description: Amazingly delicious Pinsa and Porchetta! Friendly staff, great value. I'll definitely coming back to try all the other Pinsas
author: Roberto R.

description: Wow! This place reminds me of dinners we had in Italy at our friends villa. I'll be back with my wife and friends.
author: Jeff S.

description:
We had a group of 10 and many dishes. The Proscuitto sandwich was the best, but I also enjoyed the Sausage pizza. My mother-in-law got it too, and decided she wasn't a fan of the broccolini, but that's probably just a matter of personal preferrence. 

Our waiter recommended a tasty white wine to compliment the meal & was very helpful.
author: Stephanie A.

description: Best Porchetta (thinly sliced, roasted pork) this side of Rome!  The Cavolo Nero (kale, with pecorino cheese and anchovy vinaigrette) will explode any notion you have of tasteless, boring kale salads from other places.  The selection of salumi and cheeses is excellent and unique.  The flat bread pinsas will make pizza lovers reconsider their addictions.  And to boot: great wines, beers, and cider selections.  If you love the city of Rome and its surroundings, you will thank God for MONTESACRO.  One cautionary note:  one of San Francisco's worst neighborhoods around the corner.  So only urban saavy people should brave the sidewalks coming here.  But if you are adventurous, the rewards at this restaurant will delight you.
author: Al M.

description: Was taking a client out to lunch and he selected Montesacro.  We had the Carpaccio, a mortadella type sandwich and porchetta.  Everything was amazing including the service and decor.  By far my favorite was the porchetta.  This is a spot I have to come back over and over to have everything on the menu.  The service was excellent and for a small restaurant fast and attentive.
author: Tan D.

description:
I came to this place because it was close to the Orpheum for a show and it delivered what I wanted. I wouldn't say this is overhyped, I think it delivers what it claims - a quality pinsa made the way the restaurant claims is a tradition. They also claim the wheat flour is imported from Rome, not sure if that would truly make a total difference.

The lunch special is hard to beat - for only $15 you get a salad (subtlely oiled and salted), a beautiful and generously sized margherita pinsa (well cooked with nice chewy dough), and an espresso.

Location is less than desirable on a side street next to a plethora of homeless people. After the sun sets, it may not be the kind of street to walk down for some folks.
author: Julia P.

description: You would never find this place unless you looked on yelp first. It's located just off of 6th street (sketchy block) on what seems like an alley. The food was absolutely delicious though! We were two couples and shared 2 pizzas and salads. This is not your typical Americanized Italian restaurant the pizza toppings were unique and well paired. I wish the pizzas were a little bit bigger because they felt like personal size. The salads were also delicious and fresh. Overall a great meal, but the kind of place you only go once.
author: Karim I.

description:
Probably my favorite spot to get Italian food in the entire US, knowing I am Italian (like someone whose parents are Italian and has spent a real part of her life in Italy - not just some far ancestry)
The pinse have an authentic Italian taste, subtle without too many garnishes. The salumi selection is probably my favorite. I love that we can bring our own wine.
Please open in Boston, I would be your first customer
author: Sandrine R.

description: Delicious "pinsa" with a large enough serving to share between two people, or split into two meals (which is what I did). There were six of us who came for a late lunch on a Monday and our servers were very attentive, always refilling water and asking if we needed anything. The neighborhood is a little seedy but as soon as you step inside you're transported to a whole other world - the decorative details are all lovely, from the mismatched chairs to the rustic props. Our waiter explained to us that due to the nature of the pinsa batter, it is a lot lighter and easier on your digestive system than pizza, a win-win! Can't wait to come back and try another one of their menu items.
author: Ariana M.

description: I am a Pizza fanatic, and Montesacro has the best Margarita pizza in San Francisco by far. Delicious, fresh ingredients, flour imported from Rome. I've tried a few of the other Pizzas and they are good, but the Margarita is by far my favorite. Be sure to make a reservation - it's often packed.
author: Nicholas P.

description: Never in my life have I tasted pizza like this. It is truly an amazing experience. Cherry on top is the interior of this place...truly a gem. This place is almost too good I don't want anyone I know to know about this place.
author: Lyn M.

description:
The journey walking to this location was intimidating to the 10 year olds and women in our group. We walked the wrong way from the hotel and walked off Market St at 5th and looked up Stevenson which looked like a tough alleyway. We avoided it and we kept along 5th to Mission St and walked by the old Chronicle building - talking of Hearst and his castle and publishing empire. We pushed onward and past the pimps, pushers, prostitutes and transvestites. Up to 6th and backtracked to Stevenson and looked left up Stevenson through clouds of sweet leaf and urine soaked sidewalks into a dark alley. The women and 10 year olds were singing a "no way" chorus. But we squinted though the haze and saw the Montesacro sandwich board sign out front. 

We braved the 50 yards down the alley and found paradise. The food and wine and service were excellent.  Location?  Meh...
author: Thomas L.

description: Pizza wasn't tasty, but just small and pricy. I ordered the chocolate budino and it was hardly edible. Good service and good wine list
author: Roberto C.

description:
Oh my gosh, pinsa is amazing. So light and airy and crispy and delicate. Whichever one you pick, make sure it has a tomato sauce base to it because their tomato sauce is absolutely DIVINE. One full pinsa should be good enough for one moderately hungry person. 

I'm a big fan of the Pigneto (tomato, mozzarella, anchovies, and oregano). It's simple, exotic, and to the point. This pinsa made me fall in love with the concept of anchovies on pizza...not that pinsa is pizza because it's technically not ;-) 

Just how I feel about the ambiance of its sister restaurant, 54 Mint, I absolutely love, love, love the ambiance of Montesacro. Rustic but modern, metal chairs, slightly loud, and there is a huge, electric vintage oven in the back. Italian farmhouse takes on an artsy, retro 1980's garage? 

With its novel concept and successful execution, restaurant is always very busy. Unfortunately, service is quite slow too.
author: Arushi S.

description:
Nice vibe.
Excellent food.
Good service.

We were a party of eleven at lunch and we tried a wide variety of the salads, pizzas and sandwiches.  Fair to say that everyone enjoyed the food and the atmosphere.  This place is definitely worthy.
author: Lewis C.

description:
We stopped here for dinner specifically because it was between our parking garage and Orpheum theater. We got there a few minutes before 6 pm on a Monday 12/26/16 and were seated right away.  

It's small and cozy inside so I would suggest reservations.

We literally finished everything we ordered, just shy of licking the plates. 

Rapette salad - Beets, goat cheese, and pistachios - good, but not memorable
Tagliere Misto - Chef's selection of 3 cheeses and 3 meats
Maranella Pinsa  - broccolini, spicy pork sausage, and burrata (we love spicy and that pork definitely had a kick)
Budino al cioccolato con pannna  (Chocolate mousse) - thick and rich (how my husbands love his chocolate but me, not so much)
Espresso and Americano - I was very pleasantly surprised by the sweet taste of the Americano. If it weren't for the show we had to get a to, I would have ordered another.

The staff was very friendly and helpful with recommendations on the menu. We will definitely go here again!

We were finished and paid by 7:30, which was perfect for our 8pm show at the Orpheum.
author: Lisa L.

description: Nice casual atmosphere, great service, and wonderful food.  Everything, from the beet salad to the Margherita pinsa to the Lambrusco to the ciambellone, was wonderful.  I'd go there again anytime.  Great if you're wanting to catch a bite on the way over to the theater or to the Warfield,  It's almost across Market St. on Stevenson.
author: JoAnn C.

description:
There are VERY few things I'll brave the Tenderloin for, and even fewer things I'll brave the TL for at night.  But, after having pinsa (which isn't the same as pizza) at Montesacro, it's absolutely something I'm willing to add to list. I don't pretend to know or understand the difference between pinsa and pizza, but honestly, the food here is good enough to where I know I'm willing to come back and try it again to figure it out.

My husband and I were fed up with Thanksgiving leftovers and decided that we needed something that looked nothing like turkey and sweet potatoes.  Montesacro had been on my To Try list for awhile now, and knowing that the day after Thanksgiving usually means that restaurants aren't always open, we went with what was available in Montesacro. We made a reservation for dinner and much to my surprise, this place was PACKED.  After perusing through the menu by our server (who was just as authentic and Italian as the decor and ingredients), we decided to go with the Pecorino Calabrese Riserva cheese and Finocchiona Salumi to start, and shared the Margherita and Maranella Pinsas. For two (very) hungry adults, this was definitely the right amount of food to share. Between the two pinsas, I definitely loved the Margherita.  The Maranella was good, and if you like spicy, this is definitely one you should consider.  It was a little too spicy for me, but I know my husband loved it.

Service wise, dinner moved at a fairly slow pace.  I know we shouldn't always be in a hurry to eat, but when pinsas are being dished out right behind you and you can't wait to dig into the delicious looking flatbread that's been slathered in sauce, cheese and toppings, it's hard to not want your food ASAP.  Some people complain about the fact that the pinsa doesn't come pre-sliced, but honestly, what's wrong with working for your food just a little bit?  I loved our entire meal here, and will absolutely brave all the craziness and weirdos that 6th/7th Street & Market has to offer for dinner at Montesacro.
author: Lisa I.

description:
The Best Dinner in SF I've had in 2016!
The bustling atmosphere, great service, lovely smells and gorgeous tastes at Montesacro makes one feel transported to bygone times at a homely rural Italian village:-).
author: Roy H.

description: Wow. From the menu to the service to the atmosphere to the food to the drinks you will be happy you came. I wandered in during lunch by chance, a little under the weather, and felt like I'd stumbled through the backdoor to heaven. The best restaurant experience I've had in at least a year.
author: Andrew F.

description: When in Rome eat pinsas like the Romans! Seriously, we were just in Rome, and this restaurant tasted, felt and looked like some of our favorite places there. Cannot recommend this gem enough.
author: Natalie J.

description: Delicious and authentic. We had a prosciutto tasting of 3 hams, a gorgeous fresh salad of peas and shaved asaparagus, a gorgeous globe of burrata with a minty pesto, and 2 pinsas which are they're specialty here - crunchy and fluffy pizzas made of a special mix of flours. Everything was perfectly executed and the service was attentive and generous.
author: Ria B.

description:
This is not your typical pizza joint. First, they don't serve pizza but rather pinsa--more like a puffy flatbread--delicious.
Also, their selection of Italian meats and cheeses is exceptional. Salads are also special as are the small vegetable plates marinated and served with olive oil , salt and other spices.
Despite its Italian authenticity, they could offer a few CA wines by the glass, but otherwise the food selections and quality is fabulous.
author: Harvey P.

description:
Really great little spot south of market in the Tenderloin with fantastic "Pinza" (more of a flatbread pizza) and great cheese and charcuterie selections.

Definitely try the Stracchino.  Had to order two of these as the kids loved it so much.

Only downside was our table was just behind (literally, inches) the hostess stand and we got to listen to their conversations with customers and a lot of gossip all night.

Good spot for before the show at the Orpheum.  Just be careful in the neighborhood...
author: Bob K.

description:
Does anybody know if this restaurant is open? 

Over the last 4 days, I called the restaurant two times, each during "open hours" only to have my call go to voicemail? Four days later no one has called me back. 

Guess I'm eating someplace else

John p Kennedy, Menlo Park, CA
author: John K.

description:
Totally awesome pizza! The salad was a delight as well. The space is in a gross alley and the interior looks far older than it really is. It has a kinda' cool vibe with a staff that is pretty energetic. They have some very deep ovens that I became obsessed with. 
I will return for more food when I'm feeling more wealthy
author: Tommy W.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  The food is amazing and wine list is very good.  We usually start off with bottle of txakoli wine and order the porcetta and the burrata and pesto.  Both dishes are outstanding. If I'm with a larger party we get the Tagliere Misto, 3 meats and 3 cheeses.  The sott'oli is also really good if you want to go the veggie route.  Pinsa's are next and we usually order 2-3 for 4 people.  I tried almost of the Pinsa's and I haven't had one I didn't like.  If I were to pick a few favorites I would choose the Casal Bertone, the Garbatella, the Maranella and the Quadraro.  The deserts are amazing, again all good, though the fennel pannacotta is out of this world.  I like to end with a chinato or the blanco atxa vermouth.  If you want to eat great food in a lively atmosphere, Montesacro is a must. Parking is hard near there so Uber or Lyft is recommended.
author: Scott A.

description:
It always amazes me when a pizza place remains the best pizza you've ever had (well, in California at least), and for a long time, sometimes years, it holds true, even after you've tried many challengers that aspire to, but don't quite beat it out. Until one does. This is it.

To be fair, my grandmother made some pretty good pizza, and there are one or two places in Detroit (yes, Detroit) and Chicago that are up there. Let's count those as a different style (although Little Star gives the Chicago places a run for the money). I also don't have the chops to compare pizza from Italy and elsewhere abroad; I'm a rookie when it comes to the foreign pizza scene. But I am including NYC, Boston, and everywhere else in the USA! This place is legit!

One last point. I like some of the choices here for sure better than some of the others. And I wouldn't say every choice is better than any other pizza anywhere. But some, like the Infernetto (Smoked buffalo mozzarella, 'nduja) are going to be tough to beat. I can't wait for that to happen, if it ever does.
author: Bib G.

description:
This place isn't bad. We came here on a last-minute weekend double date with a reservation a couple of months ago. We started with the Sott'oli, veggies marinated in oil and spice. 3 for $12. Good enough for an appetizer, something different. For our main course, we ordered 3 different pinsas (the Centocelle, the Margherita, and the Montesacro I believe). They were light, the ingredients were fresh, though in our opinion, nothing really blew us away. And while we're talking about pinsas, which apparently use a different combination of flour than regular pizza, my partner and I were still kind of iffy since pinsa basically just tastes like thin-crust pizza. I wasn't a huge fan that there were several burnt portions. And at how many of them it took to fill us up, I wasn't a big fan of the prices either.

The service was attentive and friendly, but also dreadfully slow. The space has that dimly-lit, mostly minimalist, just enough European-ish touches to be interesting vibe to it. The grit of the surrounding neighborhood I think is one of the restaurant's coolest features. I wouldn't write home about the pizza (oops... strikethrough...) pinsa. But maybe we just came on an off night. Willing to try it again.
author: Kate V.

description:
this place was super legit! i had put off visiting because it's in an area of town that i dont typically frequent - but i took my parents here they first night they were in town and they reallly enjoyed it too! lots of good beers and wines to wash your pinsa down with as well!

we got - radicchio salad with almonds, pinsa of the daily (burrata and potato) and the maranella with spicy sausage and broccolini - delicious combination! the crusts on the pinsa were perfect - thin but with a good bite, and chewy around edges. it was also my first time having potato as a pizza topping, and it was nicely done.  potatoes were soft and yum!  service was attentive and friendly too. i'd love to come back and try their panini's at lunch time!
author: Christina L.

description: Don't be turned off by the walk to get there. Turn down the sketchy alley and find your way inside. Authentic ingredients and technically it's not pizza, as they actually serve Roman "pinsa" which is a slightly different crust, but whatever you want to call it, you'll want to eat it. Great charcuterie selection as well.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Oh what and experience it was! It's worth the slightly sketchy walk through Tenderloin to enjoy their food! 

My friend and I went late on a Friday night and the place was still very busy. We were able to be seated immediately. The ambiance is very warm and cozy with wood touches, vintages photos of Italy and a view of the oven. 

Our waitress was very pleasant and explained the menu very well. 

We ordered 2 Pinsas to share; the Corviale (Mozzarella, Lardon and Porcini) and the Maranella (Burrata, Broccolini and spicy pork saucage). 

The dough was perfectly chewy and fluffy. Super tasteful pinsa and a very generous portion. I enjoyed every bite and the different ingredients mixed perfectly well. 

The prices are very reasonable for the quality of the food!
author: Bruno G.

description:
What a surprise to find this place in a street you would never think of walking through.
The atmosphere and decor take you back hundred years.
The food is simple and true using the best ingredients.
Our Burrata with anchovies and pesto was perfect. The Porchetta was flavorful and perfectly seasonned.
And the Pinsa was one of the best I ever had. The dough was crispy and perfectly cooked topped with an Italian bacon that reminded me the flavors of my childhood.
A little gem lost in the big city...
author: Chef M.

description:
I just left this place without even placing an order and had the worst service experience that I have ever had, in my entire life, at any restaurant, anywhere in the world. 

First of all, it's located in the most disgusting block of the city. There is no easy way to get to this place so I had to take a Lyft from my meeting downtown and then walk through several blocks of human stench composed of shit, urine, and people who have not bathed or washed their clothes in years. 

After all that effort, I showed up, and waited while the hostess was engaged in a social dialog with 4 tourists, discussing every detail of their day. This went on, and on, and on, and on. The topics kept changing. The conversation never ended. I waited, and waited, and waited, patiently. The hostess never once took her eyes off these folks and acknowledged me. While I was waiting, more people arrived, then more, then, more, and eventually there was a line forming out the door. It was 5:00pm and the restaurant was nearly empty. Only 2 tables had guests at them. That hostess just would not budge, would not acknowledge or serve anyone. Finally, I interrupted this conversation and politely asked if I could be seated and she gave me an attitude like I'd committed the most horrific crime imaginable. She continued to give me attitude and body language of disgust while she walked back and forth trying to "set a place" for me at the bar. Eventually, I was seated. 

The guy behind the bar was even worse. The whole time I was there, he had is back to me, and two other guests who were seated just before me. For a very long time, he ignored all of us, and meticulously arranged wine bottles in the fridge with a degree of precision that even a brain surgeon could not achieve. While he was doing this, 3 other servers walked past us at the bar, and completely avoided all eye contact. After the guy was finished precisely lining up every single bottle of wine in every shelf of the fridge, he went to the end of the bar and continued to look down or away, managing to absolutely avoid any form of connection, communication, or contact. For a very long time, everyone at the bar waiting to order was totally and completely ignored by every single server in the area. 

I was so fed up with this terrible, completely disinterested service, that I just picked up my stuff and walked out. 

Now, my body stinks from walking along 6th and I am going to take a long shower then make my own dinner.
author: Eater S.

description: Location is sketchy as hell, but the pizza more than makes up for it. Unlike any pizza I've had here in SF! Make a reservation in advance, especially for larger groups.
author: Mileen Z.

description:
Just great.  The pinsa is breadier than my favorite pizza, but cooked perfectly.  

I like the atmosphere,  I like the wine list, and I like the service.  Don't go.  It's already too busy.
author: Kean S.

description:
I came here after suggestions from some coworkers and reading the reviews from friends here. It's close to the Orpheum before a friend and I were watching a show later that night. 

The food was pretty good, but at a certain point, the service deteriorated and it took us quite a while to get our check and then even longer to get them to take our card.  

We ended up order 2 items off of the salumi portion of the menu (prosciutto and mortadella). Both were delicious! Definitely loved the prosciutto the most since that's probably got to be my favorite cut of meat currently.  We also ordered the Maranella Pinsa which is like pizza/flatbread with burrata, broccolini, and spicy pork sausage.  The three items together create a great combination and I can see why it's a popular choice here. I will admit, I wished the restaurant cut it for us because it's so much pressure to cut it myself.  Still though, those were delicious and enough for us. 

We sat for a bit longer since our dinner took less time than through so we sat around for a little longer - they moved us slightly and the waitress gave us dessert on the house! That was definitely wonderful - the dessert they gave us was the ricotta pie which was pretty good as well. I had considered ordering it, but it wasn't the best thing there. 

Overall, great place to check out with pretty good food. The restaurant was really hot inside though - probably both the weather and the pizza oven - wish they could have had a fans or something to move the warm air.  

Protip: order a pinsa!
author: Nina Y.

description:
The space is funky and interesting, but it was the HOTTEST restaurant I've ever been to.
I've been to many other places with pizza ovens going full steam, but this place was insanely hot.
Everyone at our table and the table next to us was sweating.

The pinsa was good, but not that different from Neapolitan style.

Our server started out great, and then basically forgot us when he got busier.
Getting water refills, and drinks was annoying, as we had to search and flag him down several times.

Dessert sounded good, but we were all so uncomfortable, we just wanted to get out as soon as we were done.

If I'm in the neighborhood in the winter, I'd likely give it another try.
author: Amanda G.

description: The pizzas here are delicious. Great ingredients and yummy pinsa dough baked to a nice crispy. Love all the flavors!
author: Stephanie D.

description: This is another great find near my office. San Francisco has so many great places to eat. I walked in, because clearly I'm touring restaurants. Needless to say, I will be eating here for lunch as well. You're welcome.
author: Ro B.

description:
This exceeded our expectations in so many respects. We are huge neopolitan pizza fans so were put off by some of the reviews here saying to look out for overly crispy pizza. Not so -- more on that in a second.

Great, fresh charcuterie on offer with a wide selection across all styles. We had 3 cheeses and 3 meats as an appetizer which felt slightly overpriced but not nauseatingly so. Great quality.

The pizzas were extremely enjoyable - a great combination of cirsp and chew, and good sized too. Beer selection was good with draft pours across a good range of styles, though the go to lager / pilsner was out and if you are into only 1 style you're pretty much forced into bottled at that point.

Service was friendly and polite, actually very much so, but sometimes a little slow.
author: David J.

description:
The food was good, but the service was HORRIBLE. Because of that, I definitely don't plan on coming back here. 

 A couple of my girlfriends and I came here for dinner last night, and were rudely ignored half the time. The hostess at the front, and other staff members, couldn't care less that we were waiting WELL past our reservation time. When I asked if our table was ready, I was was told it would be 'a few minutes' and that the 'table was being set up'. That was a blatant lie, because we stood there waiting for 20 more minutes while other groups of people who came after us were promptly seated. I had to ask two more times after waiting that long and she finally sat us at a table that had been empty for as long as we had been there....the entire ordeal made absolutely no sense to us. There were multiple open tables, and one especially large one that was open that could've easily sat our group of 6. What's the point of making a reservation when you have to wait 30 minutes after it to get seated? The hostesses obviously have no clue what they're doing, and definitely don't care about good customer service.

My friend who made the reservation earlier that night had called and spoken to someone (probably the same careless hostess) who for some reason couldn't understand her over the phone, and told my friend 'she was speaking another language to her'. Um...excuse me? Do you not understand American English? That's a pretty rude thing to say to a prospective customer. 

You just lost the business of 6 girls (and any of our friends who ask us about this place) who live in sf and love to eat out. Congrats!
author: Snigdha G.

description: My sister and I came in pretty late on a Saturday night, but they were kind enough to accommodate us. We started with a raw kale and anchovy vinaigrette salad. The shaved pecorino and choice of Lacinato kale were both really smart. I think the salad could have been heavier on the anchovy, or at least salt which is what the dish lacked. The name of our pizza escapes me but it had a stroccino cheese which acted as the sauce because of it's creamy texture, and was topped with mozzarella  and dandelion greens. The dough was absolutely delicious, thin, crisp, but lightly doughy around the crust, literally cooked to perfection. I think the pizza could have used garlic, along with finishing of olive oil and sea salt. Overall the food was yummy and I'll definitely be back to try some other pizzas on the menu.
author: Adriana G.

description:
Hmmm...you may be thinking on google maps, it only shows its a block away from the Westfield Mall. I'm here to tell you that it's a long block filled with quite interesting individuals. I would recommend taking a uber, lyft, taxi if possible. It really is in an interesting alley/area.

Restaurant is very charming, reminds me of being in a rustic Italian cafe that you would see in Rome/Florence. The place is known for their cured meats, cheeses, and their version of a flatbread pizza. We ordered the roasted pork, the grilled veggies, and the meatball pizza. All were very good. The place is small but it's not as inexpensive as it looks.

Definitely a "hidden little gem" in SF.
author: Betty C.

description:
The Pinsa was absolutely delicious! A nice mix of salty and sweet. It was very well balanced.
The Tagliere Misto was an excellent sampling of cheeses and meats! 
Loved the Cavolo Nero! Dressing was not overwhelming and tasted phenomenal!
author: RS E.

description: This place is delicious and such a gem. Unpretentious decor and so charming. This place continues to impress. Delicious charcuterie and cheese plate, a must.  My two Pinsa's of the six that I have tried are the Maranella and Tufello. The wine our server recommended was spot on and very smooth.
author: melissa l.

description:
Very unique spin on classic Italian pizza, they take it super old school with the pinsa. Tucked away on Stevenson St, you can almost escape the weight of the 'Loin and feel like you're in an old world Italian village sampling vibrant tastes of history.

Pinsa: the primordial pizza dough made with a unique combination of high-protein, high-soy, high-rice flour and just a touch of olive oil. It makes for a lighter, crisper, lower-carb, and overall more digestible pizza base.

Try the Quardraro (tomato, red onion, pancetta, pecorino) and the Maranella (burrata, broccolini, spicy pork sausage).  The former is a perfect combination of textures and flavors against that unrivaled crust.  The latter is a meditation on spiciness on a bed or molten burrata.  

Wine selection is formidable, the staff the opposite.  Service was friendly and informed.  There's a great bottle of '11 Sangiovese for $40, get it.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Love love love this little gem!

Whenever my boyfriend and I have friends/family visiting from out of town, we take them here.

The atmosphere is awesome. Get some wine pouring and you'll be sitting and talking for hours. 

The meats and cheeses are my favorite part. I always wish we'd order more!

I also love their mushrooms and eggplant drizzled with olive oil. 

Service is great. The wait staff is super knowledgeable and attentive.
author: Courtney S.

description: Great service and delicious pizza.  They have a good selection of red wine to chose from. It isn't a big place so the space can get a bit loud.  I think it's one of the better places in the neighborhood so it's perfect to go before the theater.  The hostess was very nice and really made an effort to squeeze us in for our 8pm show.
author: John C.

description: Was so excited to eat here until I saw a guy shooting up right by the entrance. It's gonna be a no from me dawg
author: Sydney B.

description:
Gianluca Legrottaglie continues to knock it out of the park at Montesacro.

A second visit to Montesacro is like walking in to a Roman version of "Cheers." Visit once, you are an honored guest.  Visit twice, you are family.

Seriously, walking in to Montesacro feels like a discovery--like you've found a gem in the midst of the gritty city.  And, guess what?  You have.

With a variety of seating areas, the old space has an eclectic style, at once polished and at the same time distressed, but in a good way: the large bread ovens from a long defunct baking company, a new pinsa oven and the original colorful floor tiles make the space cool.

What make the place warm and homey is Gianluca, his staff, and the great food.  Cavolo Nero salad with anchovies: delicious.  Centocello pinsa:  awesome.  The rustically shaped crust is light and airy with just the right amount of char and the toppings--from half a hard cooked egg to olives and prosciutto--are as fresh as fresh can be.

Get over to Montesacro to experience the best (and perhaps the only) pinsa you've ever had.
author: CJ G.

description:
Don't worry--once you step inside the restaurant you'll have no idea you're in an alley off of Sixth Street. It's worth it!

They do sandwiches and their take on pizza, so don't come in search of pasta or anything. 

Their meat and cheese place is AWESOME. Get it. It's pricey, yeah, but share with your friends. Don't hoard your food, geez. 

The ingredients are great (buffalo mozzarella, yes please) and the wine list is good, as long as you like French and Italian wines. They have by the glass and bottles. Up to you! 

Make a rezzie during dinner hours and you'll be good to go. Enjoy! 

The good: tasty food, nice staff, quirky interior and great furniture. 
The bad: limited menu, but that's still cool.
author: Amanda B.

description:
I've never had pinsa before and I was curious to check this place out to see how it differed from classic "pizza." To be honest, I'm not sure if I see a distinct difference, as it just tasted like fluffy, delicious crust! I can't say that's a bad thing either. 

It's too bad it's located in a sketchy part of town, as I'd be happy to frequent it more often if it were not. The inside is pleasant and home-y feeling though. We got the melon & prosciutto appetizer which was delicious, albeit a bit pricey, and then went on to try the quadraro pinsa with pancetta, tomato, pecorino, and red onion. The crust was wonderfully fluffy and chewy, but I do wish they were more generous with the toppings. Next time I'll try the maranella as that looked delicious. 

It looked pretty busy on Saturday night but we were able to get seated for 2 with minimal fuss; they also have a great selection of wine and beer. Definitely a worthy choice if you happen to be near the mall/mid-Market.
author: Kate M.

description: What a delightful surprise. Randomly picked this place as the reviews were good and it was near my hotel -- but the area is a bit sketchy and I wasn't sure what to expect. It couldn't have been a more lovely evening. The staff were warm and made excellent suggestions, I felt like I was in Rome with the delicious fresh tastes, the bustling environment, and the very reasonable prices. It was definitely the best restaurant I've experienced in a very long time. I will definitely be back next time I'm in San Fran...maybe every time I'm in San Fran!
author: Joy M.

description: This was a total surprise as it's in a tiny street Stevenson between 6th and 7. If you are looking for a downtown location its an easy walk to Market,one block.  i love the uh, decor. It is funky and fun. Supposedly a take on after world war 2. it attracts people who like good food so expect  all kinds from all walks  of life, old and young. The best pizza and great salads. Go .             DIANE DEVINE
author: Diane W.

description:
Pick a pinsa, any pinsa and you will be happyyyyy! 

Would definitely recommend getting a reservation. Came here for a double date on a friday at 6:30 and it was packed. Though this feast came with a pretty unexpected price tag we had a fantastic time and really recommend everyone to try it out. We ordered 3 pinsa's, prosciutto and melon, burrata, a salad and 3 bottles of wine. Seems like a lot of food but it was perfect/filling for 4 adults. From what I was able to see the bill was (far) over 300.00 w/o tip. Im sure you can get away with spending less. Maybe we could have cut back on the wine, but hey, it was FriYay. 

Next time I work from home I will be trying something off their lunch menu. Until then I will dream of pinsa.
author: Denniz S.

description:
I recently adopted a paleo/low-carb diet, with exceptions here and there when I go out to eat, and this place is definitely one that is on the list of places where it's worth it to go on a carb-splurge for me. I came here with one my ex-boyfriend who is from Italy (born and raised), and has a high standard for pizza and it passed his test. This is now on my list of favorite pizza places in San Francisco (I have gone to Flour + Water, Del Popolo, Una Pizza Neopalitana, Il Casaro, Pizzeria Delfina), and I think this one will become my new go-to-pizza spot from now on. I almost wish I hadn't come here with my ex because now this will remind me of him, but it's so good that I'll come back over and over again. 

The location is a bit gritty, located on 6th St. Once you turn on 6th St, you'll want to walk very briskly / run - not just because you're anxious to eat good pizza, but because you'll want to escape all the crazies in the area. But it's worth dodging all the sketchiness of the area to come here. When you come inside, it's a warm, friendly place that makes you feel like you stepped inside somewhere in Italy. The owner is really nice and came over and talked to us several times and explained the difference between the pizzas that they make here vs. other places. The dough is made up of different types of flours and leavens for 2-3 days. The type of pizza they make is typical of Rome, vs. the other neopolitana pizzas that come from the South of Italy, or the thinner crust from the North.

Bresaola salami (3-4 pieces for $6), and it was delicious. It tasted like high-quality salami, without all the fat.

Collatina ($16) - Buffalo Mozzarella, Rucolo, and Cherry Tomato. This was delicious with big chunks of buffalo mozzarella (no heavy cheese on top of tomato sauce at this place), a generous serving of arugula, and cherry tomatoes. It almost felt like a salad on top of fresh pizza dough. If you love arugula, get this - it's so good and makes you feel slightly healthier because of the arugula.

Quadraro ($17) - Tomato, Red Onion, Pancetta and Pecorino - This has basically tomato sauce, bacon, and a small amount of cheese. Don't expect anything super cheesy, but for me, it was the right amount of everything and you could really taste the pizza dough.

We also shared a cherry crostata which was just okay, and a bit on the sweet side for me. I wanted to try the Pinsa Nutella, which is basically pizza crust with Nutella (how can you go wrong?) but decided I had had enough carbs for the day.

This is a much better value than Una Pizza Neopolitana which at $25 a pop (excluding tip and tax) is just highway robbery for pizza, and without trying to hunt down a food truck (Del Popolo) or waiting for an ungodly amount of time (Pizzeria Delfina, Flour + Water). I like that you can make reservations here ahead of time, and that everything is reasonably priced. This is now my favorite pizza place in the city - I waver between telling too many people because I want to make sure I can go whenever I want! I love the two flavors of pizza that I tried and look forward to trying the rest of the menu.
author: Christina L.

description: Must try! Truly unique food and experience! This is not another pizza parlor with a theme. This is a true blue restaurant with unique food offerings. Don't come expecting pizza. Come with an open mind and leave very happy!!!
author: Enrico C.

description:
I absolutely love this place!  The pinsa is delicious. They also have a great wine list that is affordable.  We just discovered this place about a month ago and have already been there 3 times.  

My two absolute favorite things about this place (other the pinsa and wine) is the customer service and the Panna Cotta.  Julia is an absolute doll and extremely friendly and attentive. The Panna Cotta is the best I have ever had.  I have dreams about it.  

Please try this place!  You will not be disappointed!
author: Heather S.

description: Arrived in SF looking for a slice of of pizza for a late dinner but found a pinseria instead. Fabulous flat bread like pizza. Roasted eggplant topping soaked in olive oil for two weeks. Great crust. Tasty buffalo mozzarella cheese. Great ambiance in mid-market district.
author: Peter Z.

description:
While the name of this place doesn't bode well for easy communication ("hey, meet me at Montesacro Pinseria Romana Enoteca!"), most everything else about it is lovely. We first got a drink nearby at Farmer Brown before our reservation. They had a bar area that was pretty empty, I think you could eat there as well. 

Salads were good, not mind-blowing. The panzanella was the most meh. Kale and anchovy salad was good, about what I expected. But then....THE  PINSA!!!! It's like a delicious fluffy, airy (almost buttery? Not buttery, but just so tasty that buttery is the best adjective I can think of) thick flatbread with really tasty ingredients. 

If I'm ever in the area for a show especially, I'll be happy to return to this gem.
author: Adele A.

description:
I came here having high expectations from the stellar reviews- in SD we have an awesome, traditional little pizza place down the street from us and I was thinking a pinseria place would be something a bit different yet familiar in a big city.  Not so...

I will start by saying that the drinks were 5-star.  My red blend was excellent and the hubby got a spanish cider unlike anything we've tried before.  But that's about where the ratings dropped.  The service was incredibly slow.  We had a reservation, and so were seated promptly, but it was a busy time of night and so we had to wait 15min to put in a drink order and another 15min to get our food order taken.  The food, thankfully, came fast, though the check did not- a 30min game of trying to catch the eye of passing waiters (and we were in the middle of the restaurant, so I can't imagine how slow it might have been in a back corner...)

The different pinserias we ordered were definitely let-downs.  I'm not sure what I expected- this is the food that used to be served to the poor outside Rome so I probably shouldn't have had high expectations, but since this meal comes with a definitely non-peasant worthy $20+ price tag I definitely expected more for the price!  I was surprised by how tasteless the crust was, and all the edges were charred on my meal, so I had a plate of black crust scrapings after working my way through the dish.  One of the staff came by to talk to us about the dishes near the end of the meal, emphasizing how unique pinserias are, though his major selling point was the fact that it's better metabolized so you don't feel as full after the meal, like you do with pizza.  Well, he was certainly right, because I was still hungry after an entire pinseria!  We cleaned our plates and were still ravenous- and that with a hefty dinner bill!  I think I can see why this is the first pinseria place in the U.S., and something tells me that the dish won't be catching...
author: Sophia G.

description:
If you are in the area even 20 minutes away and want to sit down and truly enjoy a meal, you must stop by here. Rustic italian foods plus cured meats. The atmosphere is equally rustic and relaxing. They serve perfectly complimentary Italian wines along with the food. I was not disappointed, and if you appreciate wonderful food you will not be disappointed either. The pinsas are a light rustic flatbread similar to pizza but more delicate. The toppings are very similar and high quality. 
I had the Pignola which was wonderfully balanced with the salt of anchovies. I also haf the wild boar sausage which was served with salted filberts (I think). Again they paid atten to how the combination of flavors work together so you can vary the food experience by eating bits alone or in combination for different flavors. 

Well done, I think this may be my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Brian M.

description: Interesting place. Authentic cuisine and wine list, pizza dough unexpected but very savory, and staff exceptionally nice. In a really spooky neighborhood, but the string lights across the street outside harken to something different going on here. Try it.
author: A C.

description:
Really surprisingly good, and such nice staff.  It's like eating at a neighborhood restaurant in Rome.  I had the titular pinsa, the Montesacro, which has kale, peppers, cresenza and ... of all things ... fish sauce.  Yes, I know it sounds strange, but try it, it's good.

They have a great happy hour, btw; discounts on pinsas and two-for-one on glasses of wine.  So between 5 and 6pm is really the time to visit.  That also lets you get there before dark, which makes 6th street less scary.
author: Josh B.

description:
I love it.
Their burrata was so creamy and luscious I wanted to use it as face cream!
author: Susan D.

description:
This was our first time here, and all of the staff made us feel very welcome!  We were catching The Book of Mormon at the Orpheum theatre, and I'm glad we found this place.  Based on very high Yelp ratings, we decided to try this place out, and book on Open Table to ensure we got a place to sit.

Since it was our first time, we asked our waitress for some recommendations.  She was very helpful and suggested to try the Sottoli and Pinsa, which is some of their top specialties. 

We ordered the following, making it a nice 3-course dinner:

- Eggplant Sottoli
- Rapette Insalate
- Maranella Pinsa

The Sottoli was extraordinarily delicious!  Especially from my Fiancé who does not like eggplant at all really liked this dish!  Very tasty with all the different subtleties like the parsley, chili flakes and olive oil to help augment the lightly grilled eggplant.  I would recommend to try this.

The Rapette Insalate was also very good--  Think of it as a gourmet beet salad.  Again, we're not really beet folks, but both of us enjoyed this lightly dressed salad  with beets, farmer's greens, sunflower seeds, goat cheese and chives.  

Now to the main event-- The Maranella Pinsa.  The Pinsa is a very light, flatbread that's much less dense than a traditional pizza crust.  It was crunchy on the outside and a little fluffy on the inside--  It was topped with Burrata cheese, Broccolini and a spicy pork sausage.  The combination of the seemingly weightless crust and the ingredients melding together made for a very enjoyable and tasty flatbread-- I'd definitely recommend to try :)   (Also on a side note, the spicy sausage was not overwhelmingly spicy, it was just hot enough for a slight kick)

Service was great, our waitress and I believe the owner checked up on us regularly.  

While we didn't have enough time to try their desserts (the show was starting in 15 mins), we'll certainly going to come back again!

It's located right around the corner from Dottie's, which makes that two great places to eat in the same neighborhood-- I just wish the neighborhood caught up with how awesome this place is!
author: Anthony R.

description:
Montesacro--Whoa!

If you want a delicious meal with fantastic wine and a super cool ambiance--this is it!

The menu selections look so good that we need to go back in a couple of days. We couldn't possibly eat everything we wanted in one visit, but we made progress! We texted just about every Italian we know with photos of our courses.

What a wonderful addition for SF's foodie crowd--this is definitely a pleaser!
author: Shelley C.

description: Great Italian pizza in SF. Service was great. We ordered three pizzas (montesacro, quarticciolo, and pietralata), house wine (surprisingly good), and the burrata for four of us. Everything was incredible, but what really stood out was the crust and the quality of ingredients. I will be back.
author: James D.

description: The food is delicious.  The service has been great--not too intrusive, but super knowledgeable and very passionate- and I have really enjoyed my night here.  The wines are actually reasonably priced for the area, and the pinsa was perfect- just the right amount of crunch and softness to the bread, fresh veggies, homemade sauces.  Can't speak well enough about this place!  Thank you, Christian, tonight was great!
author: Amber H.

description:
Very friendly place for a casual meal.   Great selection of cheeses and meats and Italian and Spanish wines.   The Pinsa is a delightful lightness with lots of flavor. 

Great service and cozy environment.
author: Duffy T.

description:
Dis place so fancy!

Don't let 6th Street frighten you. I might say that this place is more Italian than most of the spots you'd find in North Beach. 

Rustic. Cozy. Accommodating. Deliberate. These are Italian ideals to the utmost.

Oh, and did I mention the food is ridiculously good?
author: Selwyn-Lloyd M.

description:
Fantastic people great atmosphere,discover this place yesterday by Italian friends.
The food it's a surprise rapette salads to start and porchetta fresh and tasty 
For the Pinsa I suggest the Centocelle!!!!
The only problem it's the location not the nicest and safest.
author: Alessandro B.

description:
Absolutely amazing. Went in with a business party of 14, the restaurant being as small in size as it is, only seats maybe a maximum of 37 persons, they had no problem taking the reservation for my party, and had half of the restaurant organized and ready to go when we got there! Most places, especially in this area will usually wait to see the party before holding a table to garentee service to as many as possible. I really was amazed. 

Hope you get Salvatore as your server when you come, he was awesome! Took alcoholic drink orders for almost all 14 people with no problem and was very prompt on service, always wearing a smile, and REALLY knew his stuff with Italian food. He was even able to remember everyone's unique wine and always confirmed the choice before pouring the glass. 5star service. Manager Julia was very friendly and helped with selections constantly. After we finished the pizza provided on the flat rate she brought more for the table! She monitored the table to make sure everyone on the 8 seat long table was able to try every pizza! 

I asked Salvatore for parmisian to put on top of the pizza and he took the time in the middle of rush hour with 3 wine glasses in hand to explain to me why these authentic Italian pies were better with no sprinkle cheese, but reassured me that i could still have some on my request. He was right! It tasted fantastic without the additional cheese! 

Once we were ready to leave he took the liberty of taking the extra slices and boxing them for the party without even asking. Love initiative!!! So much more to say about the amazing service! 

Did i mention it was some of the best pizza I have ever had?

 PS. My stepdad is a head Italian chef of a five start restaurant. Very impressed. If your in the area, get your rear here and eat some amazing authentic Italian pizza pie!!!!!
author: Emon A.

description:
As much as I love little hole-in-the-wall spots, this place was pretty much your above-average Italian-style eatery: Good, but not amazing. The refurbished warehouse look creates a kind of 2nd-world atmosphere and the menu is barely written in English. You may interpret this as having found an authentic location in an unlikely spot but I felt that everything was too carefully choreographed and unnatural and I didn't like that.This restaurant's big push is their PINSA. Pinsa is pizza. The wait staff will tell you that it is not pizza, and technically they are correct, but to your average joe it is a $17 loaf of flatbread with a couple vegetables and way too much cheese in the middle (a not enough cheese on the crusts). A poorly-tossed oval pizza with toppings strewn about. PINSA. 

On the other hand, the appetizer platter for $22 was a good deal split among three people and paired well with the wine we ordered. A suggestion for the wait staff: keep a large pitcher of cool water on the table and stay attentive to the glasses of your patrons. If either their water or wine is running low, as if you may pour for them.This will add value to your service.
author: Drago F.

description:
Stunning place, decor and staff. Only challenge, location.
We started with a beet salad (Rapette), amazing, fresh and not overly sweet. Next we had the Mandrione pinsa, think flat bread pizza, but way better. We finished our meal with a piece of Robiola Due Latti (cheese).

Let me help you make a decision on where to eat tonight. If I could give 6 stars, it would be easy. I hope you all find this wonderful place. 

Just got the check, can you say affordable.
author: C4 Farms ..

description:
-location is a bit sketch, but that adds to the personality of the restaurant
-good portion sizes and the bread for the pinsas is amazing
-pretty hip restaurant that has a rustic feel to it
author: Derrick W.

description: Had lunch here today...and I would go back every day if I could afford it.  I shared the carpaccio and the Caprese with my boss and we each had a pinsa to follow up.  I had the Maranella with buffala mozzarella, broccolini, spicy Italian sausage and it was DELICIOUS.  the brick fired oven cooks the crust to perfection with little air bubbles that help make it crispy and the toppings are extremely fresh.  The broccolini still had a crunch to it and the fresh mozzarella was just wonderful.  I was too busy enjoying the flavors that I forgot to grab photos.  Anyway...if you're in SOMA give it a try.  We got there early for lunch and still could only get a seat at the bar.  The restaurant tables were already reserved for lunch groups.  I recommend making a reservation if you can, but the bar seating was just fine.  Don't let the dodgy street put you off...once you get inside you'll be glad you ventured down Stevenson!
author: Annette B.

description: Wow!  What is this awesome place doing in this location?  A diamond in the rough!  Service was great/engaged (maybe from Italy?), and accommodating on a busy night.  I loved the decor/lighting in here, it's a post-war Rome theme, so there are cool antiques and some historical posters, plus a cool huge oven.  We started with a cheese app, then went  with the standard margarita pinsa for reference, plus a second one with Porcini mushrooms.  Pretty good size pies for the price!  I'll definitely be going back
author: Charles C.

description:
Overhyped. 

The ambiance is great. Rustic modern interior, servers with a thick Italian accent, fresh pinsas in the oven... I had high hopes. 

I remember eating pinsa for the first time in Rome. The perfectly chewy and flavorful dough with fresh rucola and fragrant olive oil left me forever romanticizing Rome. 

Unfortunately, the pinsas at montescaro left me feeling like a hopeless romantic still fantasizing about the real deal. 

Beet Salad: 3.5 stars -- Nothing special, but the quality of the goat cheese was memorable. Slightly underdressed but that is my preference so I welcomed it.

Margherita pinsa: 3.5 stars -- meh. As a Margherita pizza fanatic, I can confidently tell you you will find better Margherita pizza in the city from at least three different locations. The dough was underseasoned, and there wasn't enough tomato sauce or basil. Overall tasted a bit bland. Decent pizza but not worth the hype..

Anchovy pizza: 3 stars -- my friend got the anchovy pizza which looked and tasted very similar to mine, but a shit ton saltier. The flavor fell flat for me, maintaining only the one salty note throughout. 

Overall, disappointing experience. Might give it another try in a bigger group setting so I can try their meat and cheese plates and a few other dishes.
author: Michelle K.

description: Good restaurant in a rough neighborhood. Food was really good - we had the pinsa with salad and pecorino, and the waiter recommended a nice glass of sangiovese. Deducting a star for the ambiance, as it gets really loud and our meal was interrupted by a homeless man wandering in from the street...
author: Tian B.

description:
Totally cute casual eatery (think pinseria = pizzeria or trattoria) with great food. I've heard it's quite popular with the Zendesk crowd at lunch so try and come on the early side. I came with a friend from Zendesk and he kept waving throughout lunch as his coworkers filed in.

We started out with the prosciutto - the good stuff. Soft, delicate, fatty and delicious. Not that dried chewy stuff you get at the supermarket deli. This was followed by two pinsas - the Infernetto ($17 smoked buffalo mozzarella, 'nduja) and Quadraro ($17 tomato, red onion, pancetta, pecorino). Pinsas are like thin crust pizzas but the crust is more yeasty and chewy. It's crisped up enough to eat by hand but delicate enough to eat with a fork/knife if that's your preference. The topping is pretty light but rich. The infernetto was a white pizza with a nice smokiness from the mozzarella and spiciness from the 'nduja. I thought it was great. The Quadraro was more standard tomato sauce but still fresh tasting and good.

Though the pinsas are personal sized I wasn't able to finish mine. 

Definitely a diamond in the rough and possibly the star restaurant of the neighborhood.
author: Jean K.

description: Came late at 9pm, no wait but the place was busy. The Flatbreads were amazing. We had the rebbibia and the special. Crispy yet doughy and you could taste the different flavours of the ingredients. The service was a bit curt and inattentive but I didn't really care - too busy eating my pinsa!
author: Suzy T.

description:
I heard about this place from a Friend who knows my love affair with truly good Italian food, Pizza especially.  

He told me it was not a NY style pizza like Lane Splitter's but a flatbread pizza.  I have seen many California style flatbread pizza's but none that I felt 'put the place on the map'.  So I had my doubts but said I would try the place one day. 

A month later we had tickets to 'Act of God' and went here for dinner.  When you walk-in the place has a great old tile floor that leads into a concrete floor which I found interesting.  I asked our server about and she said it used to be a real working Bakery and pointed to the two HUGE old wood fired ovens in the back.  I hadn't noticed them because I was distracted by the cheese case which is just in front that had these massive wheels of very handsome looking cheeses.  The rest of the interior is intimate and casual with wine bottles on the walls from all over - Italy, Spain... as well as some ciders and beers.  

The seating was comfortable and informal but casual and the staff was very knowledgeable about the wines, the beers, and the foods.  They were also very relaxed and at no point in our 2 hours (I was amazed we spent that much time but we talking and sipping most of the time) did we ever feel rushed.

The food was simple with lots of flavors with perfect sized portions for the 3 of us.  We started with the PORCHETTA FATTA IN CASA (Slow roasted Pork),  a CAVOLO NERO (Kale Salad) and charcuterie.  It came with a cherry jelly and honey 2 cheeses, Salami and spicy sausage (I wish I could remember which ones but I can't).   We then had two PINSA's the INFERNETTO and RABIBBATA (Wild Boar sausage I think this is seasonal).  

The Pinsa's came out on a rustic dough that big bubbles, a nice crunch and some charring on the bubbles.  The dough was perfectly seasoned with salt (you'd be amazed how many dough's are bland) The toppings from the wild boar to the nudja were packed with a so much flavor but not heavy and not too much.  Each bite was so good.  

We had several glasses of wine during our meal and I had a dessert wine as well.  I can't wait to go back and try some more options in the future.
author: Scott S.

description:
now open on weekends, and quite a unique place -- both for its historical oven and antique decor collection as well as introducing pinsa to the area, which is more like a crisp airy bubbly oval flatbread but still with a good chew.  Rome inspired, back alley location.  3 people can share two pinsas.  light toppings.
Marcella - Burrata , Broccolini, Spicy Pork Sausage -- excellent spicy sausage, slightly superior to the lamb sausage
Trullo - Tomato, Lamb Sausage, Mushroom, Yogurt, Mint -- also great but a bit much on the yogurt which added a lot of tang.  overall good but not able to eclipse the top brick oven pizzas.
author: Rob C.

description:
Loved this place. I've had crazy-good pizza in Rome, and this is the closest to it I've had in the States. Even better than Baonecci's, Tony's, etc.

THE MARGHERITA pinsa (Mozzarella, Tomato, Basil) gets 5 stars. So simple, so good. The Corviale pinsa (Buffalo Mozzarella, Porcini Mushroom, Lardo, Parsley) was double the price and not nearly as amazing as the former.

Only difference between this and Roman pizza is that they're slightly heavier on the cheese here, which is understandable given American preferences, but I'd say go for more sauce, less cheese, and let the impeccable crust shine. Because it's impeccable.

As for the formaggi - out of the selection of cheeses/meats we ordered, the STRACCHINO - "Delizie Casearie" Puglia-Italy was the best. The jam it's paired with *works*. The crostini with housemade veggies was alright, filling. Next time, I'd skip it. 

As a mostly gluten-free diner (not Celiac), this place was perfect. The crust is made from mainly non-wheat flours, and the small amount of wheat flour they do use is friendly: non-GMO and Italian.

With the Austrian red wine by the glass (really good) and some smooth espressos, we're talking a European-style blissed-out meal. That usually means way-better-than-here. But not anymore! :D
author: Maria A.

description: Great pizza, fresh ingredients, traditional Italian meets creative california. We were lucky to get a table without a reservation on a Saturday night, but the safe bet would be to make a reservation.
author: Catheryn K.

description: This tiny place looks great but the menu is confusing for a first timer.  It was a last minute substitution place so no idea what to expect.  Seated at the bar, I tried to get an explanation on the Ensalda portion of the menu without success.  So you will pay $16 for a few thin slices of cured meat. It was good but the prices here are really high for what you received.  I realize it is SF but still high.  The flatbread  Marenella was $21 & not the best flatbread I have had. So for 2 small plates of meat & cheese one flatbread plain & one with toppings plus 3 sodas (no booze) it was $75.  Not sure why everyone raves about this place.
author: Naomi H.

description:
Overall 4.5 Star Rating

Decor: 4/5
-Small dining area, best for parties of 2
-Gets very warm from the oven

Service: 5/5
-from the time we ordered to finishing the pizza, less than 19 mins. Now that's efficient 
-yes to reservations

Food: 4/5
-Margherita pinsa ($15) dough was light and fluffy. The ingredients were fresh and flavorful however a bit on the pricy side. 
-The pinsa comes in an oval shape with a pizza cutter to satisfy both triangle and square pizza eaters.
author: P H.

description: Got a glass of wine, pizza and $5 artichoke side for $45 total. It was really expensive, IMO. Pizza crust was solid but the pizza was not good. I don't feel good from the pizza. Service was solid.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
I am giving this place 3 stars because I was honestly underwhelmed by my experience here. That being said, I do assume that the rave reviews are for a reason and given how close it is to where I live, I do plan to give it a second shot.

First time I tried to come here, it was a week night and fairly crowded. I tried again a few days later when I was working from home and needed to eat lunch. At lunch time, it was not too busy at all (I don't remember exactly but I think it was a little after normal lunch hours, maybe 1:30). 

Tried to start with the eggplant sottoli (marinated eggplant) but they were out so I got zucchini instead. I found it to be very underseasoned and oily. It just needed a lot more salt and a lot more flavor in general. I would like to try the eggplant if they have that in the future, and a few of their salads look interesting as well. 

For pinsa (not pizza!), I ordered the Maranella- burrata, pork sausage, and it was supposed to come with broccolini but I think they were out so they used broccoli. The broccoli was not good (it was also not cooked very well)- I think broccolini would have been so much better and I wish they'd told me about this substitution because I would have asked them to leave off the broccoli and/or substitute another vegetable. The pinsa as a whole was alright, but I was not a huge fan and I think the ingredients just didn't complement each other well. The best part of it was definitely the burrata. It was very big and pretty filling though- should be enough for 2 people, especially if you get it with an appetizer or one of the cheeses or meats on the menu. I tried the biscotti for dessert as well; it was alright but again, nothing special. I should have probably tried one of the chocolate desserts though, so this was my bad. 

Not the best first impression but I am definitely willing to give it another try and order something else. Hopefully the second time will be better and I will understand why people love this spot so much.
author: Seema U.

description: Oh wow. This is an authentic place. They're very accommodating and welcoming and let us customize our order. We had the margarita with lamb and it was the best tasting "pizza" I've ever had. So fluffy, light, flavorful. Loved it!! Will be back for more.
author: N G.

description:
Food (4/5): Between the 8 of us, we shared 2 tagliere misto platters, 1 radicchio salad, and 5 pinsas. Each platter came with 3 different types of meat and 3 different types of cheeses, all of which were tasty. However, it came with cold bread that could have done with a good toasting. Each platter is a good size for ~3 people. The radicchio salad was just okay, although I don't think it was a good idea to share it among 8 of us. 

The pinsas, however, were really good. Out of the five we got, three were memorable: Maranella (burrata, broccolini, and spicy pork sausage), Carviale (buffalo mozzarella, porcini mushrooms), and Trullo (tomato, lamb sausage, mushroom, yogurt sauce). The crust was light and chewy, but supported the toppings well.

Service (5/5): Amazing service - our waiter was friendly and hospitable without being overbearing, and he had some great recommendations for us. The restaurant was also accommodating of our lactose-intolerance friends!

Value (3/5): As solid as the food was, I think the prices are a bit on the higher side, especially for the quantity of food you get. Each pinsa is basically the size of a personal pizza, so your bill can add up fast if you add appetizers or wine.
author: Abby S.

description:
We used Yelp to find this place while we were on vacation.  It was a little off the beaten path, so pay attention to the map. 
We had a super picky eater with us, and this was very traditional Italian pizza.  We told our waitress what our picky friend normally eats, and she recommended something for us.  Although hesitant before the first bite, she actually ate practically the whole thing by herself.   
Being a non-picky eater, I loved the spicy sausage and broccolini.  Highly recommend.
author: Allyn V.

description:
I found this random hole in the wall after work one day. Its a little tucked away in a random alley. I do wish the location was a little better. There were some strange people hanging around outside after it got dark.

However, the pinsa is to die for! The bread is so light and pulls away beautifully. The sauce, omg, I'm sure is freshly made. And the cheese and toppings are perfect. It really can't be described. You just have to come and taste for yourself. 

The service was great as well. The staff is attentive and make some great recommendations. I'm definitely coming back soon!
author: E C.

description:
This spot may be hard to find, hard to pronounce, but it is not hard to absolutely love.

I was there last night with a friend. We were trying to scrounge up decent grub close to our last-minute theatre tickets across the street, and burst in at around 7 with an 8 curtain time. We explained our situation/shenanigans: could we order/eat in like 30-40 minutes???

Julia and team were PHENOMENAL.

I have literally NEVER been received with such a request like the team at Montesacro Pinseria-Enoteca did. They made us feel like *family* in the best way. 

We met Julia immediately, and she heard and understood our plight. Rather than giving us a vague "we can't seat you" response, she evaluated every table to see if they were candidates. Once we got seated, she had already prepped her waitstaff team that we were on a time budget. AND STILL she shared a complimentary bit of the daily salad (so damn good!) after our basic order. She was so lovely, and her team was as well. The Maranella pizza gives me dreams. I can't wait to go back when I can spend more time (and drink more wine!).
author: angela s.

description: We were looking for a place to have  a good pizza.  It was pouring rain in the city. Walking was out of the question, so we took an uber but they couldn't find the place.  It was down an alley way looking street and the some of the blocks were closed due to police activity. So I'm thinking what did we get ourselves into?  The neighborhood looked a bit sketchy on the corner we got dropped off on.  I didn't know what to expect.  Once we found it,  I felt transformed to Italy.  Loved the vibes inside the place. It was buzzing with people and chatter.  Good thing we made a reservation or we would have been waiting forever. And this was lunchtime. The wine was fabulous, the service superb, and the pizza was incredible. Authentic tasting marinara sauce.I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Sophia K.

description:
A hidden gem close to union square. For two people, we ordered: 
- sott'oli (grilled vegetables).... absolutely amazing & flavorful
- cheese plate (with waiter's recommendations)... also delicious!
- Maranella pinsa ... not sure how i felt about the broccolini, but the sausage was delicious. the star of pinsa is definitely the bread base.
- pannacotta & chocolate mousse for dessert... smooth and silky texture for both!

Definitely recommend to any Italian-food lover who is interested in trying something new.
author: Aditi P.

description: This pizza just changed my life. Best pizza I've ever had in my life other than pizza in Italy- and it's pretty hard to tell which was better. We got two pizzas- one with eggplant and one with broccolini and sausage. They were both perfectly crunchy, perfectly flavored and melt in your mouth delicious. You can tell all the food here is authentic because everyone who works here is Italian. Service was perfect and the food was even better. GO HERE if you're looking for the best pizza in San Francisco! Can't wait to come back to SF in a few years and see this place grow because it certainly deserves it!!
author: Samantha W.

description: Pretty yummy flat breads. The wines are okay but nothing to rave about. The Happy Hour is pretty lite, only 2-3 wines that are half price, no food. Would come again and make sure you reserve a table (or seats in the bar area). I was told you couldn't reserve bar seats but when I showed up I discovered otherwise.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
What a great find! Thank you yelp for showing me this place because I would have never discovered it on my own! Was in the Union Square area and was looking for a good restaurant to satisfy my hunger and I came upon this place. After reading just a couple of reviews, I was convinced and headed down to the sketchy 6th street. Right as we approached the restaurant, I could smell the aromas of the freshly bakes Pinsas and I couldn't wait to eat.

We ordered a couple of glasses of Italian wine - nothing looked too familiar on the menu so we just asked our server for recommendations. The only thing that was really important about this meal were the Pinsas - they were delicious! When you first look at the menu as a Vegetarian, it looks like most of them have meat, but they are very accommodating and will substitute meats for veggies if you ask! We ordered the Centocelle without the prosciutto and Maranella substituting the sausage for eggplant. My favorite of the two was the Centocelle - all the veggies and egg mixed with the flavorful red sauce created a perfect dish which I would definitely recommend! The Maranella was good, but not amazing. In my opinion, it didn't have as much flavor as the other one, but the sausage probably makes it better. 2 pinsas was just the right amount of food for 2 famished people. One interesting thing is the pinsas don't come cut into pieces; instead, you have to cut them yourself with a pizza cutter that is provided. 

We were unbelievably full after eating the pinsa, but we didn't want to stop there. We ended up ordering the buidino for dessert and it was PERFECT! Best end to a great meal!! 

Come here for a hole-in-the-wall-ish dining experience! It's a smaller restaurant in an alley way with amazing food; definitely an experience to be had!
author: Malika R.

description:
Things you hear while casually walking down 6th Street: "Man, I been drinking so much lately my right kidney hurts."

I first saw Riverdance (note: NOT the Lord of the Dance with Michael Flatley, the guy who dances without a shirt on) when I was 9 or so.  The music, the foot/leg work, everything was impressive.

Fast forward 20 years, and Riverdance just happens to be touring in SF for their 20th anniversary at the SHN Golden Gate Theater.  I decided to drag along my husband since he's never seen it before, and I made a reservation at Montesacro since it was right around the corner from the show.

Due to the massive traffic jam that is San Francisco on a Friday night, we were about 15 minutes late for our reservation; I called to let them know, and they said no problem.  We were seated once we got there, but it took awhile for our order to get taken because there was a large party taking their sweet time, and it seems like there were only two waitstaff that night.

We ordered two pinseras - Margherita for me, Maranella for Husband (broccolini, sausage, burrata), along with a cheese and charcuterie plate.  Everything was really delicious, though I was expecting the pizza-like dough to be a little thinner and crisper - a pinsera is branded as a flatbread, and ours were neither flat nor crispy.  Also, my Margherita (which is my FAVORITE type of pizza ever) had some spots where the salt obviously missed, as the tomato sauce was bland, but then there were some sections that seemed to be a little oversalted.  Generally great though - my husband rated Montesacro higher than Pizzetta and Zero Zero (his favorite is still Tony's).

Service is amazing; really friendly and personable.  However, be forewarned that this doesn't translate to quick and speedy - if you're in a rush, your best bet would be to go somewhere quick-service, because that's not the nature of this place.  Have a glass of wine, take your time eating, and pretend like you're in Rome.

Montesacro a great date night place if you're willing to brave the seediness of this neighborhood.  If you're coming pre-show, make sure you budget enough time so you're not in a bind for time.
author: Tori S.

description: Such a hidden gem! Not in the absolutely best part of town, ended up picking this place for a work lunch, close to our building. Place, as soon as you walk in, feels authentic! The food was sooo good. We all had different variety of Pinsas....all very tasty. Service was great, very friendly. Definitely will be returning and bringing more coworkers along.
author: Jennifer A.

description: Just tried it for the first time last night but can't wait to go back. We had 3 Pinsas, all excellent. Oh the crust!!!we had the porcetta - Devine! And the Cavelo Nero salad ( the only weak spot) plus marinated veggitables. Just wonderful. Favorite Pinsa  ( can't remember the name) had hot sausage, burrata & broccolini. So good it makes me want to go back as I'm writing this!!!
author: M. O.

description:
A diamond in the rough, Montesacro is a delightful place I like to take both small and large groups for a relaxed, authentic Italian experience.  Also ideal for an intimate dinner for two, if you've never been!

What I appreciate most, apart from the tasty pinsas and wine selection, is the hospitality of the staff.

Julia is fantastic and recently hosted a large group of my friends and I for an informal birthday gathering in the bar area.  The overall ambiance, tied with quality food and attentive staff & service makes this one of my go-to spots.  Thank you, Montesacro Team!  Keep up the great work.
author: Maria A.

description:
I don't know where to begin.

What won me over?

Was it the the fantastic attention to detail and warm, personal service? Maybe.

Was it the perfectly chewy and fluffy pinsa dough topped with fresh cheese, crisp veggies, and juicy prosciutto? Perhaps.

Was it the excellent wine pairing suggestion made for those unfamiliar with Italian wines? Could be.
