Something made me give this place five stars. Guess I'll never know what.
author: Ananya M.

description:
I've walked by here a million times and never even noticed the restaurant - it's hidden on Stevenson alley just off of 6th street. Came in for lunch and the food was excellent. The Trullo flatbread/pizza with lamb sausage, mushrooms and yogurt was delicious. The dough is light and fluffy, just like you find in Italy. 

Very excited to have this place in the neighborhood. I'll definitely be back for their cocktail hour, "aperetivo" sometime which they run from 4-6pm Mon-Saturday.
author: Anthony M.

description:
This place was incredible, absolutely incredible! The alley where it is located looks like it is straight out of Italy, but just don't venture out to the main road because it's a little dicey. The male waiter and lady who helped us were beyond nice. Ok, food time...

We ordered 2 salads to share between 3 people, and there was plenty! The salads are actually a decent size. One salad was with baby beets and goat cheese, where the other was arugula, pear and blue cheese. We ordered the meat and cheese plate, with 3 types of cheese and wild boar, prosciutto, and speck. The presentation was delightful and tasted amazing. 

Ok ok ok the "pinsa". Tasted a lot like pizza, haha. Was freaking delicious. I think it was the best crust I've ever had, and I imagine it is how pizza is done in Italy. We got 2 pizzas and it was perfect between the 3 of us with the other food too. One pizza had lardo and mushrooms and buffalo mozzarella, and the other had prosciutto and artichoke hearts and hard boiled egg. I would definitely return to this place, and I recommend you try this if you're going to sf
author: Mike S.

description:
Fantastic roman style pizza place with very above average charcuterie.  Service can be a little uneven but the food was great.  Been there a few times and like to go back...nice treasure in middle of Market despite the "lively" clientele you will encounter outside on 6th St.

Note: Beware holiday prix fixe meals which based on Valentine's Day was very overpriced ( 2 glasses of wine, pizza, starter and small dessert for $60 each-  OUCH)
author: Steinbeck H.

description:
I've been back here twice more, and am planning another visit tonight. I loved the Maranella with Burrata, Broccolini and Spicy Pork Sausage last time I visited in September. 

But before we could be seated in September, a homeless woman followed us in and asked me for money. I had no cash. She got down on her knees in the foyer of the restaurant and pleaded with me. The staff acted like this was a normal occurrence, which made it more surreal. Just in case you need another reminder of the gulf between classes in this city, you could get a serving with your pinsa.
author: Sarah J.

description: great pies. a little pricy, but really convenient for the theater district. the pie with the egg and the spicy italian were good. the mushroom was OK.
author: Ryan C.

description:
There's only one reason to give 5 stars... Everything is perfect.

From the expertly chosen wine list, to the delicious cheeses and creatively topped pinsas and even the authentic old school decor, I felt genuinely transported to southern Italy.
author: Erin G.

description:
I do not write this review lightly, but I've had enough. I've been here 4 times or so for lunch with a coworker. The food is pretty solid but it's some of the worst service I have ever received in my life (I swear I'm not exaggerating - see below).

We are always there right at 11:30 (we are early eaters) and don't book a reservation because it has never been even remotely busy (we would book one if we thought it necessary). Every time we walk in, we are asked if we have a reservation...despite the fact that the restaurant is empty. The previous 3 episodes, they have grudgingly given us a table and one time the waiter asked us to be quick because our table was reserved for noon. Remember, it's 2 of us in a nearly empty restaurant with seating for at least 30 folks...and it has never even remotely filled up while we eat.

Today, we were refused seating all together despite there being 4 people in the entire restaurant. We were told there were no open tables. Shocked, I commented to the host that there appeared to me to be a lot of open seats and he said he couldn't help us. So we walked out, and out of curiousity went onto OpenTable on our phones. There were open reservations for 11:45, Noon, 12:15. It was so ridiculous. While I was initially upset about being treated badly, I then felt sad for the restaurant because their wait staff is costing them money (both in denying customers and only accepting customers who come through online bookings that will take a cut).

To those folks who are looking for a great pizzeria and want a friendly/nice wait staff, go to Pizzeria Del Fina on Fillmore. Pizza is just as good and the wait staff is super fun and friendly unlike this place. 

Never going back. Get off your high horse guys.
author: Rahul B.

description:
Make Reservations!  Theater nights can fill this small authentic Italian restaurant to capacity!

We ordered the Margarita Pizza, and added Lamb Sausage.  This is a thin crusted pizza, made in the  Italian fashion, so more about flavor, and no gloppy cheese.  Pizza was great!

For dessert, we enjoyed the Chocolate Mousse, and a Vanilla Bean Fennel Panna Cotta.  Yummy, yummy!  

Our neighbor table enjoyed their food, and it looked great too!
author: Sonya B.

description:
Amazing pinsas/ pizza! Definitely one of the top 3 in the city, and we eat a lot of pizza.

Unfortunately, the starters were really lackluster-- we ordered the porchetta which tasted like store-bought deli turkey (sigh-- maybe it's unfair to compare to Roli Roti?)-- flabby, thiny sliced, cold, slimy. And the "farmers market" salad which was really just $9 for a spring mix.

The pizza made up for it though! I will still be back.TL Location had broken glass right out in front, and plenty of homeless/ interesting characters, but still worth the trek.
author: Amy D.

description:
I was there last week with four friends. We came for first time because it was close to GG Theatre, where we were to see Cabaret. The restaurant is very unique, like a little discovery in the East Village in NYC, food of a Roman speciality you won't find elsewhere in the city, very tasty. We would all highly recommend it.

The main point of enjoyment was Angela, who was at the front--she is the feature that made the restaurant stand out, so gracious, so charming, so very helpful! We'll go back because of Angela!
author: Dale W.

description: Can't believe I only found  this place after three years of living in SF! As a Roman living in SF, Montesacro pinseria is the only place that makes me feel like I'm back home in one of my cozy neighborhood restaurants. The atmosphere, the smells, the interior design, the service, but most important of all the food (pinse, salumi e formaggi), are real Roman authentic and distinguish this place from the many wanna-be Italian restaurants that I've tried around the city. Just with one dinner this place is now at the top of my restaurant list, I'll definitely become a usual customer!
author: Bianca O.

description:
All I can say is... this is the hidden gem of all hidden gems out there. Right off of chaotic sixth street, just look for the european oning and follow that good energy... It's so warm and inviting. 

I've come here on several occasions, and also ordered pizza to-go, but I would highly recommend eating in and enjoying the vibes. Great customer service, and the best part, they don't rush you through your meal. The staff is very knowledgable about how they make their pizza and love sharing whats on the menu. 

If you are gluten-sensitive, chat with the server about what goes into making the dough for their pizza. Most people don't have a bad reaction, and although I don't indulge in a lot of wheat, I was not sensitive to it. 

Thank you Montesacro for caring so much about your amazing food (and wine!)
author: Courtney M.

description: From the quiet, sleepy street to the welcoming room, to the friendly servers, to the delicious food, this place is a winner! We had a prosciutto plate, parm cheese plate, 2 salads, 2 pinsas, wine, and a wonderful olive oil and lavender cake. We will definitely be back!
author: Robin A.

description: Service was moderately slow considering it was a Tuesday night. The zucchini app was good but very strong taste of olive oil. I ordered the Margherita pizza and it was decent. The food is very Italian based and true to its culture.
author: Carlie B.

description: I was very impressed by this restaurant and have recommended it many times. What a find. Authentic - Saves you the round trip ticket to Rome! Food was delicious. Service great. Neighborhood - well, be aware. Great spot for a bite before the theater.
author: T F.

description:
Still loving this warm, inviting Italian space. And the food is amazing!!! Make reservations so you do not have to wait if possible.

Everything from the formaggi & salumi to the vegetable side dishes and of course the pinsas are to die for. I am in love with this  place! Also the owner, Eros, is super sweet and very attentive. Cannot wait to go back!
author: Theresa T.

description: This lovely little cafe & market was a wonderful find. Tucked away in an alley off 6th Street, just south of Market, walking through the doors delivers a Narnia-esque surprise. Though the neighborhood may be a bit grungy, the charming cafe reminded me of the sort of cosy family trattoria one stumbles across in the more modest neighborhoods of cities in Italy. The menu is simple (platters of cheeses and cured meats, salads and cold plates, flat bread pizzas, etc.) and perfect for noshing while sharing a bottle of reasonably-priced wine.  The service is warm and attentive (we never felt rushed or ignored) and the food is delicious. I highly recommend the panna cotta as a finishing touch.
author: Mishka L.

description: The wine listed for $12 was charged for $44. No explanation. Outrageous!!! Pizza was okay though.
author: Shantanu D.

description:
Don't be scared when walking to Montesacro - it's worth the little alleyway and minor sketchiness :).

Montesacro's took over the space of an old bakery and the pizza oven in the back is the same one that they had used to bake bread in. FYI - the "pizza" here isn't really pizza, but it's pinsa - pizza from Rome. The two that I had - centocelle (mozzarella, tomato, artichokes, mushroom, olives, egg) and their special of the night (shrimp with zuchinni) were really good, though the centocelle was my favorite of the night :). I'd love to come back to try the one with the burrata cuz 1) burrata is amazing and 2) Montesacro is amazing!

Dessert wise: cherry tart was the bomb and I normally don't like cherry tarts!

Plus Giulia works here so another plus!
author: Christina C.

description:
I enjoyed the food and the ambiance within the restaurant. The service was okay. The 2 star review is because of an incident that happened while we were eating that was not handled very well by the staff. 

A homeless woman wandered into the restaurant and approached our table twice (we were close to the door). The first time we asked her to leave and when she didn't, she was eventually escorted out. The second time she came right up to us, aggressively grabbed a beer bottle off our table and drank from it; upon realizing the bottle was empty she grabbed a glass of water and drank from that. My friend asked her to stop and tried to get the attention of someone who could ask her to leave. 

It was startling to say the least and it could have been handled better. It's obviously not the restaurant's fault that this happened but they didn't even acknowledge it to our table or attempt to prevent this woman from entering the restaurant until after she came in for the second time and helped herself to our beverages. It seemed unusual to me that the staff didn't say anything AT ALL to our table regarding this after it happened and just carried on as if it was a totally normal occurrence. It makes me think that these types of things must happen frequently....
author: Jessica C.

description:
I am writing this review as a request to all my neighbors. PLEASE go eat here. I need for this place to stay open for a long time so I can keep getting my fix on pinsas. 

My wife and I went here yesterday, and we will soon be returning. We live in the neighborhood, so we knew where to walk on 6th. Once we got inside the restaurant and sat down, we both felt like we had been teleported out of the TL into some magical kingdom of yumminess. The smells of Montesacro can be noticed from around the corner, and as you approach, it just gets better. We had done our research, so we knew all about the "pinsas", but we were not prepared for how delicious they were. 

We started off with a watermelon, basil, feta salad that was perfectly refreshing on a warm afternoon. We followed with the leanest bresaola (think prosciutto but made of beef tenderloin) and the creamiest manchego. The bresaola only came with three pieces, and the manchego wasn't exactly a healthy slice. In retrospect, we should have listened to our waiter and gone with the bresaola carpaccio. The table next to us ordered it and it looked amazing. They also ordered the caprese salad which looked to be a healthy serving as well.

Then, ohhhhh, then came out the pinsa. You can be a brat and call it a pizza, but the difference is truly the crust. A combination of wheat, soy, and rice, it tasted so much lighter to me than pizza dough. We went with the Montesacro pinsa and I confess that I was thrown at first by the ingredients. Straciatella, kale, fermented fish sauce. I had no idea what straciatella was, kale...meh, and fermented fish..forget it. We asked the waiter, he said it was his favorite. Sure it is...fermented what now? "it's deceiving, you can't even taste fish" sure, buddy.  But what is straciatella? "It's the center of buratta." So basically, you take little pillows of heaven - buratta - that you extract their inner essence of deliciousness, and throw that on your dough to serve as a sauce. I don't care what they fermented, I was getting that pizza.

To wrap this up, one of the best pizzas I've ever eaten - hands down the best pinsa I've ever eaten (also the only one). My wife woke up this morning, and instead of saying "good morning, my love" she said "can we have another pinsa for breakfast"? The answer was no, because she wouldn't let me buy one for the road, so there.
author: David C.

description:
The 30 minute wait for a 2nd glass of wine almost ruined this experience for me, but when the food arrived, my mind was changed. Unfortunately there is no one who works the bar full time, so if you're sitting there, expect to have to flag down a server. (The servers were incredibly kind and attentive once they realized I'd been overlooked, for the record). However, it's more of that European style of dining, where the servers are not overly attentive, but happy to help you out when you flag them down. Just don't expect that putting an empty glass at the edge of the bar will bring them over.

Despite the lag in service, this may be the most delicious meal I've had all year (aside from a sailing trip around Greece). I had 2 kinds of wine, the gruner veltliner and pinot grigio, both delicious. The pinot grigio was especially nice, despite being more of a rose. The marinated artichokes, olives and zucchini were scrumptious - had to order a second round of artichokes. The beet salad with greens, goat cheese and pistachios was a very generous size, and very delicious. The flatbread with squash and speck was the perfect combination of salty and sweet. The Italian bacon on it was much more delicious than the usual American bacon. The bread was to die for (both the flatbread, and the dinner bread), and I'm not even a "bread" person. I could not stop eating the bread here. It's so soft and warm and tasty. Yum and a double thumbs up! 

The ambiance is nice, though the restaurant was quite warm, due to the ovens. I would recommend wearing layers if it's a cold night, so you can take a few off.
author: Sunshine D.

description: We had a lovely dinner for 2 and the service was exceptional. The food did not disappoint.  Definitely worth a visit it you're in the area.
author: 3LegalBros S.

description:
I went to this place while traveling from San Diego. This place is special in that it delivers great service from multiple fronts. Great atmosphere and amazing food.

Absolutely amazing "Pinsa". I have never had this type of Italian before and was very pleased.
I got the "Trullo" or "Trulla" (forgot how it was spelled) which isn't on the web menu yet. It had mushroom, pork and yogurt. Was eye-roll good. 

If I new more about wine, I would have gone down that road here. They have wine for days and excellent service.

I highly recommend this place.
author: Daniel M.

description: Hidden gem.  Unfortunately, it is located in not-so-great part of town, but their food is always very good!
author: Koun H.

description: An unexpected gem off of 6th Street.  Loved the Pinsa.  Be sure to have the Expresso, they serve it so nicely.  We will be back!
author: Brenda B.

description:
This place is an absolute gem, and it'd be one even if it was in Italy.

The things that blew me away:

The "Pinsa", a bit like an oval shaped neapolitan-style pizza. The crust has a subtle crunch to it. The dough is just perfect: it's flavourful, has got a slight sourdough taste, with a thick border and just the right amount of chewy. You can tell it's leavened slowly and to perfection. This makes it delicious to eat (even alone, without condiments), but also easy to digest.

The ingredients. Those are the best of the best. I had a "Maranella" with burrata, broccolini, spicy pork sausage. Everything was so fresh and authentic.

The location. The place used to be a bakery some 100 years ago. You can dine next to the original ovens, dreaming of all the loaves of bread they must have produced in their time. Montesacro continues their legacy, bridging SF with Italy, carrying on the art of baking.

The lovely staff, the drinks selection, the list goes on and on.

I wish I wasn't in SF for such a short period of time and could get all my friends to try a Pinsa at Montesacro, they'd love it I'm sure.
author: Giuliano C.

description: Great pinsa!  The pinsa is like a pizza where the crust is light and crispy!  It's our second time here and everything was great just like the first!
author: Amy C.

description: Delicious, unique food (they are not kidding about the Pinsa being full of flavor but lighter than a typical pizza). Fabulous service (attentive, helpful with information on the menu, provided great history of the physical building as well as the business). And a great location close to the theatre district (we were a block away from the Golden Gate Theater, but ACT's Strand is just around the corner as well).  I will definitely be back. With a reservation - the line can get long at peak times.
author: Cynthia F.

description: Absolutely amazing "pinsa" as they call it and incredible-friendly service to boot. This place had a good atmosphere albeit it is in kinda a rough area, although I had no problem with it my friends from out of town were worried. Anyway, these are essentially flat bread pizzas that are well made and also very authentic. It seemed like it took hardly anytime at all for them to cook  them up, which I also appreciated due to somewhat inebriated state. We had the infernetto (smoked buffalo mozzarella and a spicy pork spread) it seemed very light but not in a bad way, more like a easy on the stomach type feeling. The quality of ingredients and the way they prepared the pinsa was like nothing I've had before, unique in its styling and presentation. Being that we also had a couple drinks, one pinsa did not suffice and we ended up getting a margherita as well because it is usually a staple of any good pizza place and it did not disappoint. I would like to thank our servers for being so accommodating and helping us with suggestions, dealing with our requests but also giving us a welcoming feeling. This is probably the closest I will get to having a pizza in Italy unless I ever end up traveling there.
author: Damien A.

description: We ordered some vegetables and one pinsa each which was really good even if a bit expensive for being a pizza. Fast service. We recommend it to everyone who wants something simple and tasty. My personal favorite was the bell peppers. We found the staff really friendly and service minded!
author: Karolina E.

description: Delicious!!! Amazing crust, flavor and vibe. authentic Italian feel right in the middle of SF.
author: Colby O.

description:
We had dinner last night at this incredible restaurant and were blown away! The service, delicious food and ambiance of the interiors were perfect for our group of 10. They are located on Stevenson Alley right by ACT, Orpheum and Golden Gate theatre- a 5 min walk to each. That area is going to boom soon and this restaurant will soon have a months wait list! 
We are always in this area going to shows and I feel so fortunate to find something so intimate and yummy...I'm going again tonight!
author: Caroline S.

description:
Go here if you like pizza but occasionally wish that eating it felt more like biting into a delicious fluffy cloud. Hello, pinsa. 

Also, go here if you want to eat somewhere close to bart and don't mind that it's ensconced in an alleyway off of 6th street.

Finally, go here soon. It will likely become really busy and popular but so far it's still fairly easy to get a table and the service is great; no pressure to leave and the best water refilling service I've seen in a while.

Other notes:
-You probably don't want to linger around the area waiting for friends. Just go in and ask for a table. 
-Was recommended the marinated veggies and they were delicious and came with good bread.
author: Sydney M.

description: Go here! You haven't had pizza until you try this.  Real thing.  Best I've ever had.  period.  Go!
author: Shannon M.

description: Well this wasn't a bad spot but no way I would rate it as highly as everyone else. Maybe there is a lack of choices here.. The pizza like pinseria were ok, . Nice and light.  However the toppings were also light and not great quality I don't feel.  Just really underwhelming.  Pop was overpriced too. I just thought it was OK. I wouldn't be in a rush to go back there...
author: Peter T.

description:
3.5 but rounding up.
Their margherita pinsa (which is supposed to be the predecessor to pizza) was not bad. The sauce was slightly too acidic for my taste but acceptable. The cheese was very good, though and so was their crust. 

The CENTOCELLE (- mozzarella, tomato, artichokes, mushroom, olives, egg, prosciutto) was just Ok. I thought the egg was going to be over easy or sunny side but it was a hard-boiled one. It actually went well with the pizza I though but I did not care of all the other toppings on there. 

The carpaccio was different that what I'm used to. I'm used to the raw uncured kind but here their carpaccio is cured beef tenderloin with arugula, shaved parmigiano, and lemon. It was good but different. I also liked the arugula, it had a nice spice to it.

The decor theme is shabby, rustic? And it is sort of stuff inside. They have happy hour from 4-6 but only at the bar.
author: Heejin L.

description: Returned second time in a week after our delicious first experience. Loved the raw ingredient pinsa, the casual atmosphere, wine selection. For a brief moment I forgot I was in SOMA and not back on vacation in Italy.
author: Winnie L.

description:
Go here! No need to even read further, just go here.

Came for dinner with a friend before a show at the Golden Gate theatre a few weeks ago. We were extremely lucky to get a spot without a reservation - the people who came in after us were told it would be more than a hour wait!

We had a short wait during which the super kind hostess started us out with glasses of wine, and even made recommendations and let us taste a few first. The exceptional service continued throughout our entire meal. I was not even mad about sitting at the counter on a stool even though my short legs were dangling. :) 

We shared the carpaccio salad and the Corviale pinsa - both insanely delicious. The two glasses of wine + two food items came to about $70 before tip, but it was well worth it. Only subtracting one star because it was absolutely, indescribably sweltering inside - I felt like I was baking along with the pinsa!
author: Lauren R.

description:
Have to look for this place.  Located in historic former San Francisco bakery.  Stevenson is one of those 'half-blocks' between major streets.  From the corner, looks like an alley.....but don't be fooled, it's there.  

Very authentic Roman Italian cuisine with simple, but top quality ingredients.  Top quality meats and cheeses on board.  2 for 1 happy hour pricing on select wines. Authentic thin crust style pizzas.  Focused staff that enjoy talking about their philosophy, foods, and wines.  Wine list looks like one you'd find in an Italian village cafe, not in a major U.S. city.  You won't find too many familiar names and that's a good thing.
author: Dwight A.

description:
Finally somewhere near the Orpheum for dinner! and so good, that despite the sketchy neighborhood, even sans a show to see, I will go back again and again and again...

The staff were outstanding - friendly, efficient but not too so, and they clearly enjoy what they have created here.  The pinsa, of course, is delicious. But what I keep craving are the sott'oli - vegetables marinated in olive oil and a little seasoning.  This is such classic Italian fare - a simple concept... fresh veggies, oil, a little garlic, salt, pepper... leave them alone for awhile and you end up with a succulent bite too simple to be so delicious. Our salad was also very fresh and delightful. I would gladly make a leisurely meal of a bottle of wine, the sott'oli, a salad, and a selection of cheese and salumi and skip the pinsa altogether.  Well, maybe just a bite of the pinsa...
author: Kathryn E.

description: Love these guys! I have been there a few times and pinsa is great, but I am also well impressed by the selection of typical Italian cheeses and cold meats. I love the restaurant decor and the staff is very friendly
author: Sonia F.

description:
Wow. Started with the Sott'oli, which was very nice. Ordered the porchetta, that was fabulous! Then shared the Pinsa; Centocelle and Margherita. I was impressed with all of it! But there was the Crostatadi Visciole, a wild cherry tart, and Espresso to finish off a delicious dinner. 

On top of all that, service was superb! I've gotta say, I loved it! All of it.

Also gotta say, rather interesting location. The 'hood ain't exactly ready for a joint like this, but somehow you overlook it. Tried desperately to overlook it. Will it prevent me from returning? Doubtful. I plan to return, frequently. 

Great selection of beer, delicious food, positively superb service!! Thanks!
author: Elizabeth Q.

description: The food in this place is delicious, don't miss the chance to eat there, small, casual, fresh, awesome. I will go back
author: Gabi O.

description: Easily a new favorite for delicious, unique pizza in the city. The wine list is extensive, the toppings are fresh, and the crust is fluffy and perfect.
author: Arman N.

description: This is an amazing gem in a really crappy neighborhood, just south of Market near the Orpheum.  We took a chance and showed up early one night without a reservation. They were able to seat us promptly.  We ordered the marenella pinsa, and a  salad, both of which were simply amazing. The sausage on the pizza was delicious -- very spicy and tasty.   It was the best pinsa I've ever had, and rates with the best pizza I've ever eaten (and I've eaten a lot of pizza).  Service was excellent, and we received great advice from the waitstaff.  Prices were quite reasonable.  I can't wait to eat here again!
author: Polly S.

description:
I so want to award more stars, but in good conscience, I just can't.  

It was relatively easy to find a reservation on short notice.  Location is a bit grimy, but definitely up and coming.  The décor is lovely and the staff friendly.  

On a positive note, the food is delicious.  Cheese and Salami plates were great, Kale salad to die for. Pizza (Pinsa) were all unique and tasty.  If it stopped here, I'd offer up 4-stars.  

BUT, the service we received was really really bad.  It was like pulling teeth to place an order (no one came over to us for over 10 minutes when we sat down).  Then, we were aggressively overcharged.  We had prepaid for two bottles of wine while sitting at the bar and yet they were also on our final bill.  So instead of the $250 we owed, they presented a bill for $330.  And, they tried to make us feel like we were wrong. No one apologized but instead we felt judged.  Not cool.  

I may visit again because of how good the food is. But, I will keep a close eye on the check and not order anything at the bar beforehand.  A sincere apology would have been nice.
author: Michael C.

description: Initially hard to find in an alley, but once you find it, it's a really cute dinner spot. The ambiance is great and a perfect spot for a date or for a small group of friends. The burrata with pesto was amazing and the pinsas (spicy pork sausage/burrata or the one with egg) were both perfect with a bottle of red wine. Loved this place!
author: Nicole K.

description: I absolutely love this place. Feels like I'm in a back alley restaurant in Rome or in my grandma's kitchen!  The pinsa is authentic, light and delish!  And the ciambelline al vino!...just like I had it growing up. I can't wait to go again!
author: Tracie P.

description: Great focaccia der muratore! I Will go back for it! Pinza is good, but flavour options could be better and less Americanized.
author: Aurora S.

description: The atmosphere is what you're paying for here. Everyone speaks Italian and the tables are packed with small groups and couples. I definitely get not hip enough for this place. But, I say at the bar and my server was friendly. What you DO need to know is that I Did NOT feel safe walking to and from this place in the evening. There was a heavy police presence outside the restaurant (thankfully), but men lined the sidewalk and I had to walk in between them to get past. It smells of urine and weed and I felt really uncomfortable walking alone. Bring a friend. A big friend.
author: Jenn K.

description:
Food: excellent antipasti and awesome pinsa - 1st pinseria ever in the USA. Think of an improved version of pizza napoletana, fluffier, yet crunchy, and easier to digest thx to longer rising time for the dough (3-4 days vs less than 24 hrs for napoletana doc). Comprehensive wine list w/ some italian gems.

Ambiance: industrial yet cozy setting in an historical building (used to be a bakery), check out the 2 awesome coal-fired ovens in the back.  Also don't forget to read some of Roma's neighborhoods history hanging on the walls.

Will definitely be back for plenty more pinsas!
author: stefano m.

description:
Montesacro, the new restaurant by Gianluca Legrottaglie (who also owns 54 Mint) is the new Italian place you didn't know you were waiting for.  They serve something you've never eaten before, but will be your new favorite food: PINSA!  Pinsa is an ancient Roman cousin of pizza, but it is MORE delicious, LESS fattening, and decidedly MORE addicting. The crust will make you swoon.
Everything served here is fresh, fresh, fresh.  The wine list is extensive and exciting.  The cooler full of cheeses and Italian deli meats is great, and the gigantic old oven in the back of the restaurant is a MUST SEE. The place is decorated in an industrial-but-friendly manner.  The gorgeous tile floor was discovered under layers and layers of muck and wrecked flooring. 
Go check this place out before everyone discovers it and you can't get in! Oh, the neighborhood it's in is kinda sketch, but it is SO WORTH IT!
author: Jane W.

description:
They call them Pinsas, but to us Americans, we'll call it the best pizza you've ever had, seriously. Dough that is made up of a blend of GMO-free wheat, soy and rice, is what gives these addictive, oval, bubbled crisp and slightly nutty pieces of heaven their base, and did I mention that dough has been fermenting for sometimes five friggin days!!  Who does that!?  Owner Gianluca Legrottaglie who was ts to create an addiction for you. 

Dont miss the Kale Salad with the best, not a bit greasy anchovies.  The menu is overall diverse with "all my favorites eats from Rome" (Gianluca told us).

This is one of those places your uber driver will say, "here!?" when dropping you off, but don't worry -you just tell him "shhh, a secret pizza place, I mean Pinsa place".
author: Randy K.

description: Pizza is very small for price, debating what we want for a party of 6 and the waitress said "if you can't afford it don't come here..." Nice. Real nice.
author: Matthew N.

description: Ok.  I know it is basically pizza.  But it is good! Go no further.  Yes the pies were great but so were the simple appetizers - cheese+meat plates.   Nice venue.  A restored 100+ year old bakery retains some of its charm.  Too many times/ Italy pictures for my liking (not very unique) but they deliver with the food.
author: Boris K.

description:
One of my new favorites. Very knowledgeable staff and excellent ambiance. Makes me feel like Rome mixed with a 1920s jazz bar. Had an excellent beef carpacio, thinly sliced, prosciutto like slivers of beef with freshly baked bread and a light coating of arugula. The waiter also came out with a sharp, creamy Parmigianino to complement the dish. 

We had the spicy infinero pinsa. Excellent flaky bubbly dough with great toppings. Also enjoyed a glass of tempranillo and a grape from Sicily I don't think I'd ever tried before. After we ordered a second pinsa and we were equally pleased with it. Was a little surprised by the bill topping $100, but all in all a great meal and a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Michael L.

description: This place is a great find. The location is a bit sketchy, but the pizza (pinsa) is good and the staff friendly. The dough is not as stretchy as the traditional napolitaine pizza, but a bit tougher. I had the maranella(?) which was delicious. The salad was just ok, but then again it was just a salad. I'd like to come back to try other items on the menu
author: Michelle S.

description: We were looking for pizza and the hotel suggested this restaurant-awesome!!!.  The staff-awesome-so personal.  We did not make reservations and lucked out-make reservations.  We ordered:  salad-shaved raw aparagus and pizza w spicy pork sausage, broccollini, burrata-awesome-soooo good.  For dessert: pannacotta with olive oil drizzled on top.
author: Ruth G.

description:
We got: 

- HOUSE-MARINATED VEGETABLES
- CENTOCELLE - mozzarella, tomato, artichokes, mushroom, olives, egg, (-prosciutto)

The veggies were good, but nothing special. The centocelle was surprisingly fluffy and filling. I was pleasantly surprised by it. 

The location is a bit dicey, but the restaurant itself is cute inside.
author: Dimple B.

description:
The best pizza in the area. 
Stopped for happy hour : selection of wine and beers and snacks : charcuterie platter, crostini, mini pizza. It was delicious and freshly prepared in front of you.
On of the staff member did not understand one of our specific request, and we gave up. The main waitress came back later asking what was wrong and she fixed it at no cost (ended up with 2 free beers)
Decorum is unique with old oven, kitchen tools, flower tiles.
Outside is a bit sketchy and you don't hang out in front of the restaurant for a long time.
Food to go too
author: Claire C.

description: The food here is pretty decent. Its close to everything, so i guess thats why it gets busy at times. Their pizzas taste authentic so i cant really complain. Id definitely go back.
author: Jake P.

description: I am italian myself and never even heard of pinsa before, it's amazing! Love the place, love the service, love the people there. Delicious food, maybe a bit pricey but worth it. I highly recomment this place. Mi raccomando non fatevi scappare questo posto!
author: Anna A.

description: Italian wine and very good pizza-(ish) in a charming space, made all the more special because it is a bright spot in a bleak block. This is the first restaurant in this space, which was an industrial bakery that sat vacant for some years. Brave owners opening a new restaurant in one of the most foul alleys in SF. If you have business nearby, this is an amazing find for lunch or dinner. But this alley is so gross (bodily fluids, spent needles, prostitution), it is not a destination meal spot. It may be a destination for 9th Circuit folks since it's right behind the Court. It is but far the best spot for a sit-down lunch near the court.
author: v. C.

description: Upon extreme contemplation, I've decided to give this trendy pizza place five stars. The atmosphere, hipster and the food, excellent. In fact, the restaurant gave a vibe reminiscent to that of the hip pizza places situated in Rome. Now, you might be wondering what about the place sparked for me to even contemplate whether number of stars was appropriate? The answer is simple. We walked to the restaurant from our hotel which was 2/10 of a mile away. However, the seemingly quick and painless walk turned into a traumatic one for the kids - who coming from a suburban upbringing had never been exposed to such environment. Nevertheless, I'd strongly recommend dining at this hip, Italian restaurant because it's deemed to offer an exceptional time with exceptional food.
author: Rafael S.

description: An awesome little spot in a neighborhood you would least expect... The Pinsa's are great and the Cavolo Nero salad is fantastic! It's a gem of a restaurant that I'll go back to again & again!
author: Scott H.

description:
This brand new spot from the folks who brought us 54 Mint is one of our new favorite places in the City. It is a very homey and casual restaurant featuring traditionally Roman food. The specialty is pinsa, a rustic, early version of pizza that sits for leavening for three days and comes out of the oven lighter than air. Porchetta and absolutely perfect veggies made for a fantastic evening. 

And the wine list is affordable and adventurous and accessible. The service could not be nicer.

So, get over any qualms about a dicey street (before we know it, Stevenson will be the chicest street in town) and head down there for a fun and relaxed evening of great food and good wine Roman style.
author: Rick H.

description: It was good, everything was really good but it was also freaking expensive. This is a type of place that in Italy would be cheap and meant for everybody that wants to get out for a cheat but good dinner. This place has the right atmosphere, the people are nice and friendly, exactly like it is supposed to be but again, too expensive.
author: Luca R.

description:
Quick review : great crust, intriguing toppings, decent wine list plus greens or salami & cheese while you're waiting. 
Service - if the place is busy - can seem a bit slow, but the results are sooooooo worth waiting for.
author: Steve J.

description:
Came in on wednesday night around 7 and waited about 15 mins for a table. After being seated, we waited another 10 minutes without being ackowledged. I told the hostess we were ready and heard her tell a waiter we wanted to order. 
Waited anoher 10 minutes without anyone helping before we left. The only time we spoke to a waiter was as we were leaving, over 20 minutes after sitting.
Terrible service and a waste of almost an hour.
author: Danny T.

description:
Just visited this place for the first time for lunch today. It is a great place to get some authentic Roman food. Ordered a Collatina pinsa which has arugula, cherry tomatoes, and fresh mozzarella di bufala.  It tasted great and the ingredients were very good quality.

(By the way the name of the restaurant is actually Montesacro)
author: Michael M.

description: Hands down best pizza in town.  Wish there name was easier to remember.
author: antonio c.

description: Amazing and great staff. Ordered the salmon panini with the mixed greens. Was not disappointed.
author: Ibrahim M.

description:
Red bell peppers as an appetizer. Eye opening for sure. Been awake since 1a, flight to San Fran to set up an office, and the appetizer is amazing! Can't wait for the pizza!

The pizza is delicious. The dough is light and crunchy where it needs to be. They've done well to bring part of Italy here. Brings back memories of past travels. 

Not a common place, if you're looking for a bit of Italy in SF. Then add this location to your list of possibilities.
author: Randall A.

description:
Great Place, Great service on a busy night before a show at the Warfield

Good food, good wine, Great vibe... yummy all around.
author: Oren L.

description:
What a wonderful new restaurant! I have always enjoyed 54 Mint, so when I heard that one of the folks behind that place was opening a new one, I had to check it out. Our host was the charming, effervescent Gianluca. Kudos to him for opening this restaurant, which pays homage to his childhood in Italy and memories of its food. 

We started with a well-curated mixed cheese/salumi plate, as well as an order of the house-made porchetta. Gianluca recounted for us how he and his family would travel to the outskirts of Rome on weekends, and stop at food trucks that roasted a whole pig . . . And out of those trucks came the most delicious, thinly sliced porchetta. His aim is to recreate that porchetta - I can't vouch for how it compares to his childhood, but the one I ate was fabulous! (It is served like a salumi - at room temperature.)

We moved on to two pinsas (shared between three people). We had the spicy Infernetto - which packed a whollop of heat - and the more delicate Collatina. Both were excellent. The crust is puffy like Neapolitan, which was a surprise, because I understood "Roman" pizza to be cracker-thin. But Gianluca explained that his pinsas are made from three different flours, and although they have a thicker crust, the dough ends up very light. I agree, these crusts were fluffy and airy.

The wine list is interesting and well priced. Italian focused (naturally), but with some California and other locales sprinkled in. At the end of the meal, Gianluca poured us another splash of red wine so we could dunk some "ciambelline all'olio e vino" - a semi-sweet round biscotti made with olive oil and glazed with white wine. A perfect ending to the meal for me, as I don't generally order sweet desserts.

One potentially negative aspect of dining here will be navigating the Tenderloin to get there. Not a big deal for me, since I live in SoMa and know what I'm in for, but tourists and others not familiar with the "charm" of 6th Street may be put off. 

This is a terrific addition to the casual dining scene south of Market - I'll be back again soon.
author: Maureen O.

description: Food was very good the staff was very nice.  The pizza I order had anchovies on it which is what I love.  The pizza was small so no one else would have to smell the anchovies.  It was a little hot in there with the pizza oven in the same room.  I would probably come back in the winter time or on a cold day in San Francisco.  I had the moose pudding which is good with wipe cream.
author: Shannon C.

description: Very good variation of the classic pizza. Skeptical at the beginning (never tried it before despite I'm Italian) but super satisfied at the end. Always happy to eat a pinsa every once in a while!
author: Alessio Z.

description:
A great place full of friends old and new , great food , and an amazing wine selection ! 
My good homie Pietro and I had such a great dinner couple of nights ago,
Can't wait to come back! 
The bubbly and crisp pinses are fantastic! 
The chilled fruit afterwards is a must 
So glad to have finally made it in !
author: jet b.

description: Real authentic Italian! Their pizzas and pasta are both great. House wine is also good!
author: Maggie M.

description:
Walking to it you would never guess what is behind that door. Modern, industrial, beautiful music and ofcourse the smell of Pinsa. Pinsa, by the way, is my favorite thing now. Move over deep dish. 

we ordered the margherita and st lorenzo. Best part is we had half a pinsa to take home for breakfast the next day, let me tell you it tasted out of this world even at a day old. I prefered the margherita overall because the cheese and sauce were on point. The service was so warm and friendly which keeps you in around the dinner table longer, perfect for groups. This is truly a slice of Italy, thank you for bringing it here.
author: Nora B.

description:
Great antipasti - fresh and authentic. Delicious cheese and meat board, loved the little bowl of honey. Went with the margarita pinsa and it was perfection - tangy tomato sauce, bits of cheese and basil and a crunchy/airy crust to die for. Nice wine selection. All around cozy spot with great, unfussy food. 

Definitely recommend.
author: Vivian B.

description:
We stopped in for HH and had the margherita pinsa. The crust (combo of rice flour/soy/GMO free dough) is truly like no other I've had in SF. Believe me when I say I've tried every pizza in SF known to man; my hubby is from NYC and has been on a quest for great pizza since planting his roots. Not only was he in heaven but this topped his list of all time favorite joints for an Italian pinsa pie. 

HH drinks are 2 for the price of 1...which also comes with olives, almonds, and bread. What a deal!
author: Maria C.

description:
Slide past skid row and
steal the best pizza you will
have this year. Adore.
author: Paula M.

description: Soooo Good...  Soooo welcoming, not so budget friendly but worth the price for this type of "pizza" experience.  How many people can say they've eaten pizza the way the Roman's did (well the way their breads were baked) over 2000 years ago.  Came in with no reservation (around 5:15) and the sweet hostess happily accommodated us  (they got REALLY busy REALLY quickly too) and when they found out it was a birthday dinner, they gave us a complimentary cherry tart with a candle (very thoughtful!!!).
author: Elizabeth G.

description: DON'T DO THAT! Was screamed at me by the manager (Julette?) when I raised my hand to get the check.  I listened calmly until she continued the harangue...then I was forced to stand up and leave.  WHEN does a manager have the right to chastise a customer for a reasonable behavior:  it's service is lazy, (I asked for her check and then the waitress disappeared), the manager stood in the middle of the restaurant -on a obviously intense personal cell phone call for ten minutes, then marched over to me to bark this order. I wrote to Giancarlo, the GM,  whom I several times who failed to respond. Food OK but who do they think they are treating people this way!!!
author: Kim S.

description:
Good restaurant, bad location.

Warning, there are going to be some unpleasant things in this review.

Went with my sister. We sat at a table by the window perpendicular to the door (this is important). They have a happy hour with discount drinks and snacks (olives, nuts, salty things that make people thirsty!) My sister became unhappy because she said she could smell, sorry, no way to be delicate, human excrement. I could not smell anything, but we moved to a new table more interior. This table was in direct line to front door and whenever the door opened we could both smell it. Even worse, the woman at the next table was loaded with perfume, which makes me sick. We moved again, way inside, near kitchen, so it was hot but what can you do? I felt sorry for the restaurant staff working hard while someone was using the street as a latrine. However, it filled up later (which reduced the odor as fans came on) so people are coming regardless.

OK, to the meal. The 50% of DNA that my sister and I share is apparently not the part that governs food tastes; we frequently don't like the same thing which can be a problem in a share-oriented restaurant. Settled on beef carpaccio as appetizer, very good. I recommend highly. After LONG debate got two pinsas to split, one with mushrooms and lardo, the other with lamb sausage. The mushrooms had a consistency that did not appeal to me but the lamb was quite good. Meal pretty filling due to being heavily bread based.

They lose a point by not serving tea. As vices go, tea is pretty wimpy but it's mine and without tea I don't feel like it's a meal. I had considered coming back alone for lunch and sitting at the window table, but not if I have to carry tea from Starbucks!

For dessert she got the chocolate mousse and I got the cake. I think she got the better choice; after all the bread, cake was a bit much and tasted slightly floury.
author: Carol S.

description:
I am a regular at this amazing spot. Pinsa is something I had never tasted before coming to Montesacro, and I was happily surprised at how good it tastes, while not weighing you down the way regular pizza does. The ingredients used are really fresh and unique also!

Please try the bottarga pinsa (the Pietralata) and the house marinated veggies! I'm craving it now just typing this review... 

Also the staff are a great friendly group of people and passionate about what they do!
author: Amber O.

description: You can smell the quality coming from the kitchen as soon as you walk through the door.   The food is top notch, the menu quite unique just like their style of pizza cooking.  Really really good food and an extensive wine list albeit all Italian with no Californian options.  This place will be a recommendation to my friends living in or visiting San Francisco.
author: Sean B.

description:
Just returned from a trip to Italy and we were excited to find a spot in SF with amazing, authentic Italian/Roman cuisine!

Food: Pinsas change frequently but you can't go wrong! They bake pinsas in their oven so the crust is fresh, fluffy and a bit charred for flavor. I do recommend getting the name-sake Pinsa. I also loved their charcuterie - would recommend this over their veggie antipasti (a tad pricey for what it is). I also love their panna cotta - not too sweet and love the refreshing treat to finish things off. 

Ambiance: Chill, rustic though in a rough neighborhood

Service: Awesome service - Guila is such a charming host!
author: D L.

description:
The pizza is good, unfortunately our experience here with the staff wasn't. I had been here one time before and everything was nice and the pizza was soo good! But this time we had a reservation and we had to wait over an hour for our table. The staff were not friendly and the hostess asked us to wait outside when there was space at the bar. The waiter we had (the only non-Italian speaker) was not friendly or attentive. After bringing the food we were never checked on and half of our table did not have forks. My pizza was cold by the time I got silverware. The pizza did not taste as good as the last time, but maybe it was because it was cold.

I'm so bummed the service was bad and none of the staff apologized for the wait or were friendly. I wanted to add this place to my list of best pizzas in SF to recommend it to friends, but after this experience I won't be back anytime soon and neither will the group of friends I brought with me.
author: Anna Z.

description: just loved it. service was great... food was excellent... ambiance warming...definitely will come back...
author: Cristina B.

description: If you prefer Roman Italian pizza, this is perhaps the best place in SF to get your fill. A few years ago, it was impossible to get authentic Italian pizza in SF. Now there are several options, but IMO, Montesacro does it better than anyone else. Apparently they aren't actually even called "pizza", but "pinsa." Montesacro also has many other appealing menu items. Tried a bite of the meatballs and loved them. Definitely will be my go-to place for pinsa from now on.
author: Reynolds C.

description:
The food was great.  Waitstaff was super helpful and very cool.  One short block from the Golden Gate theater where we saw an 8 o'clock show.

Three of us split two different house-marinated vegetables (eggplant and super delicious sun-dried tomatoes with capers and anchovies), two different pinsa selections ("Corviale" with  buffalo mozzarella, porcini, lardo and parsley, and "Rebibbia" with smoked buffalo mozzarella, braised red Onion, house-made wild boar sausage and thyme).  Both very rich, with very light crispy crust.  More than enough to eat--though next time we would add a third marinated vegetable.  

For dessert we split the chocolate mousse--really, really dark and rich, and the panna cotta which was topped with fennel pollen and extra virgin olive oil.  Both were great, but I think the panna cotta is a "must have".

The only less-than-stellar part of the experience was totally our fault.  Walking a few blocks from the 5th and Mission garage we elected to walk down Stevenson street rather than walk a short block up to Market.  Bad call.  Walk up to Market.
author: Mike W.

description: Fantastic hole-in-the-wall with remarkable pizza (pinsa) and solid wine. The food is every bit as good as the ambiance. Will be back again soon.
author: Jeff S.

description: Rivals Motorino in New York for the best pizza I have ever had.  I just had the basic Margherita and have no basis on which to claim it is the best one there, but the crust on this is the best pizza crust I have ever had.  There is something about the texture on the bottom that is amazing and the mozzarella and tomato sauce are both out of this world.  Do not miss this place.
author: Glen W.

description:
My boyfriend and I happened upon this spot a couple of months ago and had a 4.5 star experience. We had a caprese salad that was out of this world. The buffalo mozzarella was to die for. We waited months to go back, and scheduled it for a date night because we knew it would be special. Sadly, the caprese was no longer on the menu, but we ordered a different appetizer that had the mozzarella in, and the sott'oli (sun dried tomatoes, mushrooms and red peppers). As soon as I cut into the mozzarella my heart sank. It was hard, cold and poorly seasoned, the polar opposite of the last time. Both appetizers were lacking in flavor/seasoning. We decided at that point to skip entree and just get a dessert, a cherry tart, which was tasty, but nothing special. 

They were only moderately busy, but wait staff was slow and not particularly friendly. Both of our appetizers were cold dishes but still took a very long time to come out. The table beside us had ordered before us and still didn't have their food when we got our dessert. 

Expensive for the simple meal we had, although I would have been happy to pay it if the quality had been what we had the first time we were there.
author: Candice G.

description:
good pizza！nice atmosphere（cozy but not crowded or noisy)

The roast pork( a cold dish) with rosemary is very good! Pizza is good too! Menu is mostly written in Italian( I assume ) so it took us a little while to figure what to order. The waiter was very nice to explain to us.
author: Dimin X.

description: Wow.  Just Wow.  Randomly stumbled across this place and so glad that I did!  This was the best flatbread pizza I have ever had.  The dough is freshly made and cooked right in the middle of the restaurant.   I got the Margherita pizza special and I'm still dreaming of it.  I can't wait to come back to San Francisco just for this pizza.  It was THAT good.
author: Christine S.

description:
Amazing! The crust is the best I've had and the owner told me it's made with rice flour and soy, which is what makes it so light. Great flavor and lovely rustic ambiance inside. 

Had this first pizza to go and can't wait to go in for a nice dinner next time!
author: Christine E.

description: What a hidden gem amidst quite a scene of a neighborhood. This was one of the most delicious lunches I have had in SF in a long while - and their lunch special was amazing! (Something like $15 for a pinsa, salad and espresso). Very cute decor, wonderful service, and was quite relaxing and civilized for a little midday business lunch. Will be back for sure.
author: Michelle T.

description: Just great and excellent friendly service. Try the grilled eggplant and the artichoke hearts. Also the pinsa. Will definitely be back. Hidden in an alley in San Francisco.
author: Michael K.

description: Should have written this a month ago when we stumbled on this place before going to the theater. Such an unlikely spot down a dark alley. The food was fantastic, the waiter knowledgeable and helpful. The atmosphere casual, comfortable. Decor a perfect combo of urban and rustic. Can't wait to go back.
author: Sharon A.

description:
Yes yes yes yes yes yes yeah!
First night in SF and I get so lucky to eat at this amazing place!
Everything was perfect and Italian! Not Americanized Italian..  Thank you
author: L. F.

description:
My girlfriend and I came here before a show at the Orpheum one evening around 6pm. There were a lot of seats available, and by 7pm there were only a few left. The hostess greeted us when we walked in and brought us to a table imediately. Our waiter was Italian and taught me some of the less-common Italian words on the menu. He also gave us some advice on portion size.

We got two glasses of the Casale della Ioria Campo Novo, which was (surprisingly) their only red produced near Rome. It went great with the meal.

We wanted to eat light so we went with one appetizer and one pinsa. It was enough for that night, though in the future I think we'll order one pinsa each. We got the olives for an appetizer, and they were great as expected. The oil on the olives was particularly good and it was great to dip the pinsa crust into.

We ordered a margherita pinsa since it was our first time here and we wanted to get an idea for the cooking process. Pinsa dough is like a flatbread, but it's baked with attention and care. Typically when I think of flatbread I think "rustic", or homemade, which I can do in my own oven. But Montesacro has big beautiful ovens and they use them aptly. The dough was light and fluffy on the inside, with a thin crispy layer on the outside. The crust was lightly charred with no areas being completely burned - perfect in my opinion. The texture was course - I originally thought there was cornmeal in the dough, but it turned out to be grainy flour. I liked it because it gave the dough an extra crunch but didn't affect the flavor. The toppings were tasty and fresh, particularly the mozzerella which tasted like milk. The basil they used was delicious, however there wasn't much of it. That's my only complaint, I believe I only got 4 or 5 bites with basil in them - I would've liked more. I don't have much to say about the sauce other than it wasn't very acidic. I generally like all red sauces though.

I'm glad we got to visit this place before it gets popular. I was surprised to see it wasn't on sf.eater's list of up-and-coming pizza spots. Being on an alley off of 6th, I could see how it might be overlooked. Despite the surrounding gritty neighborhood, Montesacro was clean, secluded, and the scent of pinsa and wine filled the air. I will definitely come back and have more pinse!
author: Jimmie T.

description: We started with marinated red peppers, olives, & dried-tomatoes served over the most amazing soft yet rustic house bread. It was a warm evening and much warmer by the ovens so a little pino grigio and proseco lubricated our experience. After a worthwhile wait a Centocelle Pinsa was presented to us. It was fantastic!  The texture of the dough is simply beautiful and toppings were fresh and flavorful.  Cant wait to go back!
author: Moraima P.

description: I live right next to this place, and I feel so lucky! Montesacro is the BEST when it comes to wanting a fresh, flavorful, high-end pizza without the bloated feeling that comes afterward. Not only is their pinsa delicious, it isn't greasy. It's upscale! I also get their chocolate mousse for dessert, and it is the bomb! Their salads are simple, but fresh. I  have only good things to say about this place, and not because I'm their neighbor (believe me, if I could keep this place to myself, I would.), but because I am a food snob, and they pass the test with flying colors. Thank you, Montesacro!
author: R J.

description: Wonderful Ambiance , An Italian Restaurant That Does NOT Serve Any Pasta... Fascinating ! Delicious Salads , Cheeses , Paninnis Etc. A Little High Priced For My Daily Lunch Budget.
author: Gregory P.

description: Saw a show last night at the Warfield and wanted a restaurant close to the venue when we stumbled upon this gem. Apparently they have only been open a couple of months and we almost missed it as its down an ally street on the edge of the Tenderloin. We started with marinated vegetables, but the best plates we got were the prosuitto and melon and buffalo mozzarella and heirloom tomato salad. The show stopper was their pinsa which is unlike any pizza like concoction I've ever had. Like a flatbread but with a fluffy crunchy crust. Absolutely amazing with broccolini and spicy sausage. Although we had no wine, their list was impressive and they have a pretty nice cheese and meat selection. Get there early or make reservations. You won't be disappointed. I'll definitely be back.
author: D H.

description: after a long day of shopping and walking around, this place really hit the spot. they advertised low calorie pizza, so naturally i was skeptical but it lived up to the hype. plus they have a bomb dry cider so that's a win. a little divey but cute authentic decor and delicious food!
author: Stephanie R.

description: I never thought any other type of pizza would question my love for Neapolitan style pizza.  Pinsa did just that.  We tried three different pizzas and they were divine.  Now the hard part....which one do I like better?  The good thing is that I can keep eating both until I make a  decision which will likely be never.
author: Sanket K.

description: This was an interesting experience.  It appears that you have to have a reservation and you cannot just walk in to eat.  The guy seemed miffed.  Then they seemed understaffed and/or not prepared for the busy night.  Oh and the price of my wine was different on my receipt than what it said on the menu.  I did not try to hunt someone down to have them fix my bill because it was busy and I did not feel like waiting even longer.  The food was good and the place is cool.  I will try them again to see if I have a similar experience or not.
author: J J.

description:
If you want to eat what people in Rome eat, you come here.
If you're one of those who think pizza pepperoni, caesar salad, fettuccine Alfredo and spaghetti meatballs is real Italian food, don't even bother stopping by.
Light and delicious pinsa, fine ingredients, rustic and unique ambiance is what you'll find here, Roman owner and Roman pinsa guy at work... A gem in downtown SF.
Forza Roma!
author: Marco P.

description: So glad I found this spot! Montesacro serves pinsa which is close to pizza but much lighter and hands down better. Extremely friendly and warm staff that seemed eager and excited to share their restaurant with us. After ordering, the food was out within 8 minutes and could not have been better prepared. Will definitely be going back!
author: Sammy S.

description: We read reviews and wanted to try MPE.  We took a Lyft ride to get to it.  The driver dropped us off at the alleyway asking "are you sure?"  It is in a sketchy area, but not unsafe.  It is worth the effort.  We returned a second time, walking our elderly parents without any reservations about getting safely to and from.  The old oven discovery in the remodel was a find for sure.  It adds so much to the ambiance.  Pinsa is amazing.  It is thin crust and lighter than pizza.  The flavors of everything are amazing.  Service is friendly.  We have gone without reservations but early evening.  Suggest reservations for anything after 5:30.   Highly recommend you searching this one out!
author: Jeri G.

description: I have a new favorite dinner spot! They have fantastic food and service! I would highly recommend the tiramisu if they have it on special and the cotto e mozzarella was amazing. It's a great small group or date night spot.
author: Tori R.

description:
The food is pretty good but the portions are small for the price.  We got a $15 meat plate with 3 types of meat.  We got 4 very thin pieces of each, some nuts and an herb sprig.  One of the meats was was literally the size of a quarter.  The pinsa was tasty but again, smaller than most 1 person entree portions.  We also got the beet salad and the portion was small as well.   

Seating can also be an issue there- they have communal table that we had no choice but to sit at because there were no other available seats though we had a reservation.  The metal stools were uncomfortable so see if you can specify when you make a reservation.  The server was apologetic they could not give us another table and the service was generally good.  The street it's on, coming from 6th or 7th (esp. 6th) can be a bit sketchy. I would not recommend walking alone when it's dark.

For the price, I'd rather go to Zero Zero, where the portions are bigger and just as tasty (albeit, it's pizza v. a pinsa).   It is close to the Orpheum so if you're optimizing for convenience, it's a good pre-show option.
author: C T.

description: The pinsa was light, fluffy, crisp.  When you eat it doesn't sink in your stomach.  Became fond of the Montesacro pinsa, kale with fish sauce.  I've already gone twice, sitting at the bar was a little more comfortable than the metal super upright chairs.  It is also incredibly warm in the restaurant.  I will say the vegetable appetizers are rather pricey, and when you get the artichoke you only get one!  Will go back to try more pinsie (plural in Italian?).
author: Mirba E.

description:
Everything here is DELICIOUS! We had the Pinsa Maranella and the Pinsa Collatina. To start we had the panzanella. Everything was extremely fresh and tasted like authentic Italian. The service was also fantastic. They were really friendly and helpful. Since the neighborhood isn't the greatest, they even waited with us outside until our cab arrived. 

Highly recommend this place!
author: Melissa M.

description: This place was awesome! Perfectly decorated, adorable green chairs, deeeelicious authentic pizza. Also, the wonderful Italian woman who served us told me I was beautiful and made me feel more special than my date did. Holla!
author: Annie F.

description:
Neat little restaurant tucked away on a seedy little street in the seedy part of downtown. It's definitely off the beaten path so once you get through the cocaine deal on the corner, needles, feces, etc. - It's not so bad!  (Yes, we saw all of those things as soon as we got off Market St.) Even as a native San Franciscan, I wasn't a huge fan of the location. There was just a 'bit' of culture shock for our guests from Arizona.

Service: A+ I don't remember her name but she was extremely pleasant and helpful throughout dinner.

Food: A - Don't recall exactly but enjoyed everything! Pinsa was DELISH.

Location: Eesh.. Hate to say it but I don't know if I'd go back just because of that. If this were in the Mission, the line would be out the door and around the corner hands down. We arrived at 5:30p and were the only people there until 6p.

One random note: Their chairs are really small and I'm not exactly a huge person. If you weigh more than 125lbs, you'll probably slide off the little green chairs.
author: Con L.

description: AMAZING!! This is the ONLY Pinsa restaurant in the country, owned by a delightful Italian man, Gianluca, who brought his authentic Pinsa recipe to the states. Pinsa is similar to pizza, but it uses 1/3 of the flour, which makes it a lighter. The selections are all well thought out, with flavors perfectly complementing each other. They have other delicious dinner items, but I guarantee once you try the Pinsa, you will come back for more. Amazing wine selection as well, with knowledgable friendly staff, willing to accommodate you. Great place to celebrate or gather. The decor is fun, antiques all over. Good lighting and wonderful vibe. Highly recommended.
author: M J.

description: Wow really delicious! Neighborhood not that sketchy. Service delightful and friendly. Well worth the trip from my hotel.
author: Mimi H.

description: Authentic Italian food run by Italians.  My experience was slightly marred by my observation that their wood oven is only for shown and is not used for cooking.  (They actually put orange lights in it to make it look like it is working).
author: Will T.

description: Wow - this was tasty - perfect for pre-theatre meal.  It got a little warm in the small restaurant when it got slammed - too many people and the hot oven.  Great service, interesting menu and I'm sold on an easier to digest yet tasty crust.
author: Nicole O.

description: Hidden gem, tucked away in an alley. I can't agree that this type of pizza is the best ever, but ti was delicious.  I also liked the hole-in-the-wall atmosphere and great service.  Lots of great charcuterie and cheeses to choose from as well.
author: B. Y.

description: Total score! Great little spot tucked away in SoMa. Perfect for sharing and groups. Super efficient reservation. Wine list is perfectly paired.
author: Brandi S.

description: Delicious food, pleasant staff, would definitely recommend!
author: Karina A.

description: We went here for pizza before a show at the Orpheum.  The ambiance and food were wonderful- it felt very authentic Italian.  I like that they left you alone- Italy style- however, we did need to hunt the service down for a few things- check, etc.  I would definitely go back.  YUM!
author: Diana P.

description: Pinsa is more chewy and crunchy than regular Italian pizza. One of the best I've ever had in my life. Further, the chocolate mousse dessert was affordable and FANTASTIC!
author: Chris K.

description: I really liked the pinsa with sausage. Dessert was ok.
author: Iop A.

description:
i came here on fri night, and it was yummy!  it's not in the best part of town, so be mindful while walking.  tucked in a tiny street off of 6th is this hidden gem.  

we shared 3 apps of olives, roasted tomatoes and zucchini.  the portion was small, but it reminded me of how we ate in italy.  we also got a beet salad, which was super fresh and delicious.  for the pinsa, we shared the margherita, and it was perfect for 2.  i didn't have pinsa at all in rome, but it was pretty much like a lighter pizza.  the crust was super crispy and not heavy at all.

for dessert, we just got the biscotti, which came w/ a shot of wine.  ;)  the biscotti is traditional roman style and are shaped as rings rather than long strips.  they look plain but tasted great!

i would definitely come back.  if you are a meat eater, there is a lot of charcuterie as well.
author: Helen T.

description: Nothing but great things to say about this place (besides it's sketch location in the Tenderloin). The server was super friendly and knowledgable about the beers, and the beet salad was great. Of course, we came for the Pinsa (which we had never heard about before discovering this restaurant) and it was AMAZING. We got one with a spicy sausage and broccolini, and a margherita. Both were to die for, and we left satisfied but not over-stuffed. I will definitely be coming back for some of the best pizza (pinsa) I have had in SF!
author: Alexandra W.

description: Great service - perfect food. Popped in for lunch and had Rome in the palm of my hands. Being a bit of A diamond in the rough, this place has enough heart to shine through. So pleased to see such quality and care and attention. Can't wait to be back with friends and loved ones.
author: Raquel F.

description: This place is UNBELIEVABLE! Get the margarita pizza you must . A bit sketchy walking there but totally worth it.
author: Hilary D.

description: Crazy good, authentic Italian recipes.  Do not miss it.
author: Jeff O.

description: Pinsa was really amazing!  We had the special with porcini mushroom and it was delicious.  My only complaint was it took 15 minutes for anyone to come over and take our order.  Appetizer arrived quickly but after that service was non existent.  Not sure if our original server fell ill but we never saw her again and had to flag down another random server to get anything.    My wine glass sat empty for a long time.  Go for the delicious food but make sure you have plenty of time and patience..
author: Scott S.

description: Great food. Lovely environment once you get inside. Lasting impression however is the Pathetic service. Very nice people but way under staffed. Some tables appeared to matter while we were invisible. Unacceptable.
author: N B.

description: Yes, it's a bit pricey and yes, 6th Street is scary, but...the crust. The crust. $20 pizza is worth $20 for crust this good.
author: Jason M.

description: Close to work, coworkers and I stopped in for a team lunch. We made reservations and our table was ready immediately. Good thing- place was packed by noon! Delicious pizzas, good wine selection and great recommendations for meat and cheese selections. Would definitely come back for lunch specials deal!
author: Kaley S.

description: Just WOW. Definitely the best hidden gem I've found in SF so far. Their pinsa is just perfect, thin and crispy on the outside, nice and soft on the inside. The flavors are fresh, the ingredients are premium and the service is outstanding. Our waitress was very well versed with the menu and was very comfortable making suggestions. In addition, the cured meats, cheeses, olives and bread were outstanding. I was too full to get dessert but can't wait to go back for more Pinsa and maybe have room for dessert.
author: Marlon F.

description:
5 stars for the food

2 stars for the price (portions are pretty small)

Negative 5 stars for location (I would not recommend going here at night.)

People were nice but wait was very long.
author: Dan S.

description: New favorite laid back eating establishment.  Love it all.
author: Alex S.

description:
We were a group of 14 postdoctoral research fellows attending a big conference at the Hilton Union Square hotel. We wanted to sit altogether to have lunch amid the bustling event. I was in charge of making this happen. In practice we would have a bit over 1 hour inside the restaurant, so it was utterly important that everything was prearranged and swift.

A week before the event I talked on the phone with Ms. Giulia from the restaurant, and she was thoroughly kind. She took upon herself all the work of organizing a fixed price per person lunch, as I said I preferred, of selected items from the menu. I didn't know the menu so I just trusted her to make everyone happy about the food.

We arrived on the scheduled time, were greeted by the very owner of the place, and were seated at the wide communal table plus one more table. Very few minutes after we sat, the waiters started bringing food in a deliciously orchestrated sequence of cheeses, breads, salads, fine charcuterie, and then the glorious pinsas which are similar to pizzas but better. The lunch also included one soft drink per person, and they have truly authentic soft drinks there!

Everyone was delighted with the food and the communal experience of not having to choose individual dishes. We simply ate altogether from the foods on the table and chatted all along. "An Italian family lunch experience". The stress of the conference disappeared inside the restaurant. At my request, while we ate the waiters slowly proceeded with charging each guest the fixed price of the lunch, which already included taxes and gratuity. When our time was up, the bill was already paid, the full receipt was already in my hands, so we simply thanked everyone and left. Not a single precious minute was wasted with waiting!

I sincerely thank Montesacro for making every effort to maximize our time, minimize my stress as the organizer of the "event", and deliver a lunch that was super enjoyable not only for the superb food but also for its familial, communal style. The price we paid was also very fair, even more if considering how expensive San Francisco is.

Now I have a problem: it was a big success so my colleagues will want me to be again the person organizing our lunch in the Conference next year! :)

Highly recommended restaurant!
author: Fabricio P.

description:
I started to write a bad review of the restaurant and then realised I was really just annoyed with other reviewers, who had been misleading with their descriptions. So I have upgraded from 2 to 3 stars. In order therefore:
Restaurant ambience: 1 Star. Acoustics of the room are terrible so it is difficult to have a conversation or hear your server. The area is horrid, so it is not a nice place to get into or out of. The decor is fine, but sound protectors / dampers would help out no end. I also felt like the decor was confused - at one end, it looks like a high-end restaurant (albeit with exposed concrete around the pipes) and at the other like a grocery shop. My preference is to have one theme in a restaurant.
Restaurant service: 2 stars. Could have been more forthcoming and friendly than it was.
Food: 3 stars. Sott'oli (mushrooms, tomatoes, courgettes), Formaggi (brie), Mandiare Pinsa. Pinsa is just pizza, not a new type of pizza. I took issue with that description. Pinsa comes from the Latin pinsere. Vegetables sottolio were fine - the portion was generous BUT the were not infused with the oil; the oil had just been poured over at the end, and I didn't think it was the best quality olive oil I had ever had. The vegetables should have been marinaded in the oil.
The brie was good although I hated the presentation (with two tiny teaspoons of honey and blueberry compote - make them decent sized accompaniments or don't provide them).
The pinsa was fine - a generous hand with the radicchio was appreciated. However (and this is nothing to do with the restaurant, more with other reviewers) this is NOT a thin crust pizza. It is a pillowy base, more the thickness of a naan than a thin crust pizza. So don't go expecting a high topping to base ratio, as I did.
author: Shyam G.

description: This place is consistently solid.  The beet salad is great.  And I've enjoyed every Pinsa I have had.
author: Amjad S.

description: We found this place due to Yelp and was more than happy. We ordered the Pinsa, a salad and wine. We will be back to try more entries.
author: Ryan R.

description: Fresh basic ingredients - fabulous. We loved the Maranella and Collatina pinsas and the various sottoli options. Friendly and attentive service - staff is passionate about their work. Nice vibe.
author: Vicki L.
